aeger: <entryFree id="n1162" type="main" key="aeger"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aeger</orth>, <itype>gra, grum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Curtius proposes to connect it with <foreign lang="greek">e)p-ei/gw</foreign>, to press, drive; <foreign lang="greek">ai)gi/s</foreign>, storm-wind; <foreign lang="greek">ai)=ges</foreign>, waves; and Sanscr. egāmi, to tremble; trembling, shaking, being a common symptom of illness</etym>, designates indisposition, as well of mind as of body (while aegrotus is generally used only of physical disease; class.; in Cic. far more frequent than aegrotus; Celsus uses only aeger, never aegrotus). <sense id="n1162.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of the body, <hi rend="ital">ill</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sick</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unwell</hi>, <hi rend="ital">diseased</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suffering.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1162.1" n="(a)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Of men</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">homines aegri morbo gravi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">graviter aegrum fuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:25" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 25</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:25:61" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 25, 61</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">infirma atque aegra valetudo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=48" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 48 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegro corpore esse,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ad Quir. 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex vulnere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vulneribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 59:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 59, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 38</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">Wernsd. Poët. L. Min. 6, 197, 8: stomachus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 2, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anhelitus,</quote> <trans><tr>shortness of breath</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:432" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 432</bibl></cit>.—At a later period constr. with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> or <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Psyche aegra corporis, animi saucia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 4, 86, p. 310</bibl></cit> Oud. (cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 102</bibl>, p. 360 Oud.: Psyche corporis et animi alioquin infirma; and Liv. Andron. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 725</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">inops, aegra sanitatis, where, however, Bothe suspects aegra to be a gloss.): memini, me quondam pedes tunc graviter aegrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 10</bibl></cit>.—<pos>Subst.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">a sick person</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne aegri quidem omnes convalescunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 4</bibl></cit>: aegro adhibere medicinam, id. <cb n="AEGE" /> de Or. 2, 44, 186: <cit><quote lang="la">vicinum funus aegros exanimat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:4:126" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 4, 126</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ungebant oleo multos aegros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:6:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Marc. 6, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:5:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 5, 16</bibl>. —Hence, ab aegris servus, <hi rend="ital">an attendant on the sick</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a nurse</hi> (cf. ab): <cit><quote lang="la">D. M. SEXTORIO AVG. LIB. AB AEGRIS CVBICVLARIORVM,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 2886</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1162.2" n="(b)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Of brutes</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sues aegri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:496" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 496</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:5:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 5, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">avidos inlidit in aegrum Cornipedem cursus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>wounded</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:11:517" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 11, 517</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1162.3" n="(g)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Of plants</hi>, <hi rend="ital">diseased</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">seges aegra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:142" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 142</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegra arbor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> Febr. 25, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Mart. 7, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1162.4" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n1162.5" n="A" level="2"> Of the mind, <hi rend="ital">troubled</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anxious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dejected</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sorrowful</hi>, etc., of any agitation of the passions or feelings, of love, hope, fear, anxiety, sorrow: <cit><quote lang="la">aeger animus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegris animis legati superveniunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 3, 5</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Drak. ad h. l.: scribendi cacoëthes aegro in corde senescit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:52" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 52</bibl></cit>: aegri mortales, i. e. miseri (<foreign lang="greek">deiloi/ brotoi/, o)izuroi/, polu/ponoi</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:268" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 268</bibl>; constr. with <case>abl.</case>, <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">ab.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1162.6" n="(a)" level="5"> With <case>abl.</case>: Medea animo aegra, amore saevo saucia, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 8</bibl> (the later edd. <hi rend="ital">animo aegro</hi>, as B. and K.): <cit><quote lang="la">animus aeger avaritiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">curis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:208 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 208 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1162.7" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">gen. of respect</hi> (cf. Drak. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:15:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 15, 9</bibl>; Rudd. II. p. 73; and Roby, II. § 1321): aeger consilii, <hi rend="ital">infirm in purpose</hi>, Sall. Fragm. ap. Arusian, p. 212 Lind., and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:9:141" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 9, 141</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 58</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:36" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:3:11" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 3, 11</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Of cause</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rerum temere motarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:17:9" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 3, 17, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">morae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:7:240" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 7, 240</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">delicti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:13:52" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 13, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pericli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:15:135" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 15, 135</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">timoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:3:72" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 72</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1162.8" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">A morbo valui, ab animo aeger fui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:1:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 26</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1162.9" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of a diseased condition of the state, <hi rend="ital">suffering</hi>, <hi rend="ital">weak</hi>, <hi rend="ital">feeble</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">maxime aegra et prope deposita rei publicae pars,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui et semper aegri aliquid esse in re publica volunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:23 al" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 3, 23 al.</bibl>— Of the eyes, <hi rend="ital">evil</hi>, <hi rend="ital">envious</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">recentem aliorum felicitatem aegris oculis introspicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 20</bibl></cit> (Halm here reads <hi rend="ital">acribus</hi>). —Of abstr. things, <hi rend="ital">sad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sorrowful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grievous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unfortunate</hi> (class., but for the most part <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">numquam quidquam meo animo fuit aegrius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:3:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 3, 2, 29</bibl></cit> (where <hi rend="ital">aegrius</hi> may be the <pos>adv.</pos>; <cit><quote lang="la">v. aegre below): dolores aegri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:905" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 905</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">luctus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:933" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 933</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:464" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 464</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mors,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 512</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spes,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>faint</tr>, <tr>slight hope</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:9:543" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 9, 543</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fides,</quote> <trans><tr>wavering</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:2:392 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2, 392 al.</bibl></cit>—As <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aegrum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>: <cit><quote lang="la">plus aegri ex abitu viri quam ex adventu voluptatis cepi,</quote> <trans><tr>more pain</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 2, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed cui nihil accidit aegri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:171" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 171</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aegrē</orth>.— <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1162.10" n="a" level="4"> Object. </sense><sense id="n1162.11" n="(a)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Uncomfortably</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nescio quid meo animost aegre,</quote> <trans><tr>disturbs my mind</tr>, <tr>vexes</tr>, <tr>annoys me</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:3:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 2, 3, 35</bibl></cit>; so, aegre esse alicui, often in Plaut. and Ter. (like bene or male esse alicui); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 1, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:5:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 3, 5, 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:2:1:63 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 2, 1, 63 al.</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">opp. volupe, volup: si illis aegrest, mihi quod volup est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:152" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 152</bibl></cit>.— <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:2:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 1, 2, 57</bibl></cit>.—Also: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre facere alicui,</quote> <trans><tr>to vex</tr>, <tr>hurt</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:3:4:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 3, 4, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:5:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 5, 31</bibl>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre audire aliquid ex aliquo,</quote> <trans><tr>any thing annoying</tr>, <tr>disagreeable</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:1:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 5, 1, 39</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1162.12" n="(b)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">With difficulty</hi> or <hi rend="ital">effort</hi> (opp. facile): <cit><quote lang="la">omnis conglutinatio recens aegre, inveterata facile divellitur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 20, 72</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">inveteratio, ut in corporibus, aegrius depellitur quam perturbatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:37:81" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 4, 37, 81</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">omne bellum sumi facile, ceterum aegerrime desinere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 83:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 83, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec magis versutus nec quo ab caveas aegrius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:1:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 1, 106</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre rastris terram rimantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:534 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 534 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non aegre persequi iter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:8:9" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 8, 9</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">haud aegre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:3:10" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 3, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:10:8:22" default="NO">10, 8, 22</bibl>. —More freq., </sense><sense id="n1162.13" n="(g)" level="5"> = vix, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">mo/gis</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">hardly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">scarcely</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre nimis risum continui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:2:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 2, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre me tenui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 16, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre fero, v. fero: aegre abstinere quin, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre stantes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:36 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 36 al.</bibl></cit>—Hence often vix aegreque in connection, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:10" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> Somn. Scip. 1, 7</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 7</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 1, p. 111</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1162.14" n="b" level="4"> Subject., <hi rend="ital">with grief</hi>, <hi rend="ital">regret</hi>, <hi rend="ital">displeasure</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">dislike</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unwillingly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">reluctantly</hi>: discessit, aegre ferens, <hi rend="ital">distempered</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vexed</hi> (opp. laetus), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:33" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 33 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre pati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 9</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre tolerare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si alibi plus perdiderim, minus aegre habeam, i. e. feram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 1, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegre carere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 5, 13</bibl></cit>. —<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod aegrius patimur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 13</bibl></cit>: <cb n="AEGI" /> aegrius accipere, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Ann. 4, 71</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegerrime ferre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 87</bibl></cit>: aegerrime pati Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:44:105" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 44, 105</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegeria: <entryFree id="n1163" type="main" key="Aege^ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegĕrĭa</orth>, i. q. Egeria, q. v.</entryFree>
aegeus: <entryFree id="n1164" type="main" key="Aegeus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegeus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">dissyl.</orth>), <itype>ĕi</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)geu/s</foreign>, <sense id="n1164.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">son of Pand on</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Athens</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and father of Theseus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 37:41" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 37, 41</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 3, 74</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:402 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 402 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:41 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 2, 41 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
<entryFree id="n1165" type="main" key="Aege_us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype> (trisyl.), <pos>adj.</pos>, i. q. Aegaeus.</entryFree>
aegiale: <entryFree id="n1166" type="main" key="Aegi^a^le_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegĭălē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1166.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">daughter</hi> or <hi rend="ital">granddaughter of Adrastus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wife of Diomedes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Argos</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:3:5:48" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 3, 5, 48</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 8, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegialeus: <entryFree id="n1167" type="main" key="Aegi^a^leus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegĭăleus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">quadrisyl.</orth>), <itype>ĕi</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)gialeu/s</foreign>. <sense id="n1167.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Son of Æetes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brother of Medea</hi>, <hi rend="ital">commonly called Absyrtus;</hi> he was cut to pieces by his sister in her flight, and scattered upon the sea-shore, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:19:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 19, 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:43:3" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 43, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1167.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Son of Adrastus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">one of the Epigoni before Thebes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">slain by Laodamas</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 71" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 71</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegides: <entryFree id="n1168" type="main" key="Aegi_des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegīdes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <sense id="n1168.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">patr. m.</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)gei/dhs</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a descendant of Ægeus.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1168.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Theseus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:4:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 4, 59</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:4:26" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 5, 4, 26</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1168.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Descendants in gen.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">children</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grandchildren of Ægeus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:2:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 2, 67</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegienses: <entryFree id="n1169" type="main" key="Aegi^enses"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegĭenses</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, v. Aegium.</entryFree>
aegilopa: <entryFree id="n1170" type="main" key="aegi^lo_pa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegĭlōpa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, v. aegilops.</entryFree>
aegilopium: <entryFree id="n1171" type="greek" key="aegi^lo_pi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegĭlōpĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)gilw/pion</foreign>, <sense id="n1171.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a disease of the eyes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a lachrymal fistula</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an ulcer in the inner corner of the eye</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 21, 26, § 54</bibl>: from</sense></entryFree>
aegilops: <entryFree id="n1172" type="greek" key="aegi^lops"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegĭlops</orth>, <itype>ōpis</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">aegĭlōpa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)gi/lwy</foreign>. <sense id="n1172.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A disease of the eyes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a lachrymal fistula</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a tumor in the inner corner of the eye</hi> (so called from <foreign lang="greek">ai)/c, ai)go/s</foreign>, goat, and <foreign lang="greek">w)/y</foreign>, eye, since goats are most subject to this disease), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:7:7:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 7, 7, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 6, 14, § 34</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">the form aegilopa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:132" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 19, 77, § 132</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n1172.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A kind of oak with edible acorns</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quercus aegilops, Linn.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 6, 8, § 22</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:33" default="NO" valid="yes">16, 8, 13, § 33</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1172.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A weed</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tare among barley</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Avena sterilis, Linn., or Aegilops ovata, Linn.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 13, 93, § 146</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:155" default="NO" valid="yes">18, 17, 44, § 155</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1172.3" n="IV" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A kind of bulbous plant</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 5, 30, § 95</bibl> (Sillig, aegilipa).</sense></entryFree>
aegimurus: <entryFree id="n1173" type="main" key="Aegi^mu^rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegĭmŭrus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)gi/moros</foreign>, <sense id="n1173.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an island situated over against Carthage</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Zowamour</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Zimbra</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 7, 7, § 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:24:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 24, 9</bibl>; Auct. B. Afr. 44; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:2:30" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 2, 30</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegina: <entryFree id="n1174" type="main" key="Aegi_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegīna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/gi=na</foreign>. <sense id="n1174.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An island in the Saronic gulf</hi>, <hi rend="ital">earlier called Œnone</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Œnopia</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Eghina</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:7:10" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 7, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 19, § 57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:11:46 al" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 11, 46 al.</bibl>—Hence. <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegīnensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of Ægina.—Subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a native</hi> or <hi rend="ital">an inhabitant of Ægina</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:9:2:8" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 9, 2, 8</bibl> <hi rend="ital">ext.</hi>—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegīnēta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, i. q. the preceding, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 11</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegīnē-tĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Ægina</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 2, 3, § 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1174.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The mother of Æacus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:474" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 474</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeginiensis: <entryFree id="n1175" type="main" key="Aegi^ni^ensis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegĭnĭensis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1175.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an inhabitant of Æginium</hi> (see the foll. art.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:46:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 46, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeginium: <entryFree id="n1176" type="main" key="Aegi^ni^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegĭnĭum</orth>, <itype>ĭi</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)gi/nion</foreign>, <sense id="n1176.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a fortress in Thessaly</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Stagūs</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 79</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 32, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:13" default="NO" valid="yes">36, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:46" default="NO" valid="yes">44, 46</bibl>; 45, 27; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 10, 17, § 33</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegipan: <entryFree id="n1177" type="main" key="Aegi^pa_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegĭpān</orth>, <itype>ānis</itype>, or Gr. ānos (<sense id="n1177.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">dat. plur.</hi> Aegipanis, <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 6, p. 215</bibl>), <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)gi/pan</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n1177.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Goat-Pan</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">goat-shaped Pan</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a well-known sylvan deity with goat's feet and rough body</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Astr. 2:28" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Astr. 2, 28</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1177.2" n="II" level="1"> Acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:4:10" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 4, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:8:10" default="NO">1, 8, 10</bibl>; and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 8, 8, § 46</bibl>, <hi rend="ital">a kind of goat-shaped men in Africa</hi>, perh. <hi rend="ital">the baboon.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aegira: <entryFree id="n1178" type="main" key="Aegi_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegīra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/geira</foreign>. <sense id="n1178.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in Achaia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:3:10" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 3, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 5, 6, § 12</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n1178.1" n="II" level="1"> Another name of <hi rend="ital">the island Lesbos</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 31, 39, § 139</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegis: <entryFree id="n1179" type="main" key="aegis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)gi/s, i/dos</foreign>. <sense id="n1179.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The œgis.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1179.1" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The shield of Jupiter</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:354" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 354</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:12:720" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 12, 720</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1179.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The shield of Minerva</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with Medusa's head</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:435" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 435</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">contra sonantem Palladis aegida,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:4:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 4, 57</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:753" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 753</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 78 al.</bibl>—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1179.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1179.4" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A shield</hi>, <hi rend="ital">defence.</hi>—So only Ovid of the jewelry by which maidens try to conceal their ugliness: decipit hac oculos aegide dives Amor, R. Am. 346.—</sense><sense id="n1179.5" n="B" level="2"> In the larch-tree, <hi rend="ital">the wood nearest the pith</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:187" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 39, 73, § 187</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegisonus: <entryFree id="n1180" type="hapax" key="aegi^so^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegĭ-sŏnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aegis</etym>, <sense id="n1180.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sounding with the œgis</hi>: pectus (of Pallas) Val Fl. 3, 88. <pb n="54" /> <cb n="AEGR" /></sense></entryFree>
aegisthus: <entryFree id="n1181" type="main" key="Aegisthus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegisthus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/gisqos</foreign>, <sense id="n1181.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the son of Thyestes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who murdered Atreus and Agamemnon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with whose wife</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Clytœmnestra</hi>, <hi rend="ital">he lived in incest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and was finally slain by Orestes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 38</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 161</bibl>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Hence, Pompey called Cæsar Ægisthus, on account of his adulterous connection with Mucia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:50" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 50</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aegithus: <entryFree id="n1182" type="greek" key="aegi^thus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegĭthus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)/giqos</foreign>, <sense id="n1182.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small bird</hi>, considered by some <hi rend="ital">the titmouse</hi>, Parus caeruleus, Linn.; by others <hi rend="ital">the red linnet</hi>, Fringilla linaria, Linn., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:206" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 74, 95, § 206</bibl>; cf. Aristot. Hist. An. 9, 15.</sense></entryFree>
aegium: <entryFree id="n1183" type="main" key="Aegi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegĭum</orth>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegĭon</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n1183.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Achaia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">one of the twelve Achœan cities</hi>, <hi rend="ital">situated on the river Selinus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Vostitza</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:5:10" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 5, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 5, 6, § 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:585" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 585</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 30</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1183.1" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegĭenses</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Achaia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1183.2" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Ægium</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitis,</quote> <trans><tr>a kind of vine</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 3, 4, § 42</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aegle: <entryFree id="n1184" type="main" key="Aegle_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeglē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)/glh</foreign> (brightness). <sense id="n1184.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A nymph</hi>, <hi rend="ital">daughter of Jupiter and Neœra</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aegle Naïadum pulcherrima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:6:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 6, 21</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1184.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">One of the Hesperides</hi>, <hi rend="ital">daughter of Atlas</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 4, 484</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1184.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A daughter of the Sun</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sister of Phaëthon</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 154" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 154</bibl> and 156.</sense></entryFree>
aegocephalos: <entryFree id="n1185" type="greek" key="aego^ce^pha^los"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegŏcĕphălos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)goke/falos</foreign> (goat's head), <sense id="n1185.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an unknown bird</hi>, in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:204" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 80, § 204</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegoceras: <entryFree id="n1186" type="greek" key="aego^ce^ras"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegŏcĕras</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)go/keras</foreign> (goat's horn), <sense id="n1186.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the fenugreek</hi> (in pure Lat.: <hi rend="ital">silicia</hi> or <hi rend="ital">siliqua</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">Trigonella foenum graecum, Linn.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:184" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 19, 120, § 184</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aegoceros: <entryFree id="n1187" type="greek" key="aego^ce^ro_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegŏcĕrōs</orth>, <itype>ōtis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)go/kerws</foreign>, <sense id="n1187.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the wild goat</hi> (in pure Lat. <hi rend="ital">capricornus</hi>), used only <usg type="style">poet.</usg> as a sign of the zodiac, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:615" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 615</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">humidus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:9:536" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 9, 536</bibl></cit>.!*? Also <orth extent="full" lang="la">aegŏcĕrŏs</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, sedem aegoceri, <bibl default="NO"><author>Caes.</author> Germ. Arat. 213</bibl>: Aegoceron Cancrumque tenet. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:10:213" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 10, 213</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegolethron: <entryFree id="n1188" type="greek" key="aego^le^thron"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegŏlĕthron</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)go/leqros</foreign> (goat's bane), <sense id="n1188.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant in Pontus</hi>, prob. Azalea pontica, Linn., <hi rend="ital">injurious to cattle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and esp. to goats</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 13, 44, § 74</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegolios: <entryFree id="n1189" type="greek" key="aego_li^os"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegōlĭos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)gw/lios</foreign>, <sense id="n1189.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an unknown bird;</hi> acc. to Harduin, <hi rend="ital">a kind of screech-owl</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:165" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 60, 79, § 165</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegon: <entryFree id="n1190" type="main" key="Aegon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegon</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/gwn</foreign>. <sense id="n1190.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The Ægean Sea</hi> (only in the poets), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:56" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 5, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:629" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 629</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:4:715" default="NO">4, 715</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1190.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a shepherd</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 3, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 72</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegonychos: <entryFree id="n1191" type="greek" key="aego^ny^chos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegŏnychos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)go)nuc</foreign> (goat's hoof), <sense id="n1191.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, usu. called lithospermon, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 11, 74, § 98</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegophthalmos: <entryFree id="n1192" type="greek" key="aegophthalmos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegophthalmos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)go/fqalmos</foreign> (goat's eye), <sense id="n1192.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an unknown gem</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:187" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 11, 71, § 187</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegos: <entryFree id="n1193" type="main" key="Aego^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegŏs Flūmen</orth>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>trans, of <foreign lang="greek">*ai)go\s *i*iotamoi</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">Goat-rivers</hi></etym>, <sense id="n1193.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river and town in the Thracian Chersonesus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not far from the Hellespont</hi>, <hi rend="ital">where Lysander defeated the Athenians</hi>, 404 B.C., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,006:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Lys. 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,007:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Alc. 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,009:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Con. 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:2:7" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 2, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 58, 59, § 149</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegre: <entryFree id="n1194" type="main" key="aegre_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegrē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. aeger <sense id="n1194.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aegreo: <entryFree id="n1195" type="hapax" key="aegre^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegrĕo</orth>, <itype>ēre</itype> <etym>aeger</etym>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n1195.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be ill</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">morbis cum corporis aegret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:824" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 824</bibl></cit>; cf. Lachm. and Munro ad h. l., and <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 826</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
aegresco: <entryFree id="n1196" type="main" key="aegresco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegresco</orth>, <itype>ĕre, 3</itype>, <sense id="n1196.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n.</hi> [aegreo], <hi rend="ital">to become ill</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to grow sick</hi> (not in Cic.). </sense><sense id="n1196.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: morbis aegrescimus ĭsdem, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:349" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 349</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegrescunt corvi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 12, 15, § 32</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1196.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n1196.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To grow worse</hi>: violentia Turni exsuperat magis, aegrescitque (i. e. asperior fit) medendo, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 45</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in corde sedens aegrescit cura parentis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:1:400" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 1, 400</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1196.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To be troubled</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anxious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">afflicted</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grieved</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rebus laetis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:2:18" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 2, 18</bibl></cit>: his anxia mentem Aegrescit curis (mentem, <hi rend="ital">Gr. acc.</hi>), <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 193</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sollicitudine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 25 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
aegrimonia: <entryFree id="n1197" type="main" key="aegri^mo_ni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegrĭmōnĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aeger; as acrimonia from acer</etym>. Only of the mind, <sense id="n1197.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sorrow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anxiety</hi>, <hi rend="ital">trouble</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem aegrimoniā afficere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:3:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 3, 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum abscedat a me haec aegrimonia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:4:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 4, 4, 146</bibl></cit>: ferrem graviter, si novae aegrimoniae locus esset, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:38:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 38, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tristis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:17:73" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 17, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deformis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vetus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 8, 27, § 103</bibl></cit>. (For its distinction from aerumna, v. that word.) <cb n="AEGR" /></sense></entryFree>
aegritudo: <entryFree id="n1198" type="main" key="aegri^tu_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegrĭtūdo</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aeger</etym>, <sense id="n1198.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">illness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sickness</hi> (both of body and mind; while aegrotatio denotes only physical disease). </sense><sense id="n1198.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of the body of men and brutes (only after the Aug. per.): <cit><quote lang="la">visi sunt (elephanti) fessi aegritudine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 1, 1, § 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metu et aegritudine fessus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 29</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 69</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:5" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:7" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 7</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Eutr.</author> 9, 5 al.</bibl>— <cit><quote lang="la">Also of plants: sunt enim quaedam aegritudines (ficorum) et locorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:223" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 24, 37, § 223</bibl></cit>.—Far oftener, </sense><sense id="n1198.2" n="II" level="1"> Of mind, <hi rend="ital">grief</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sorrow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">care</hi>, etc. (class.; freq. in the Ciceronian philos.), Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 322, 18</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegritudo animam adimit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:3:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 4, 3, 84</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 5, 1, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 2, 1, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:prol. 35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. prol. 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:3:24 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 2, 3, 24 al.</bibl>: praeclare nostri, ut alia multa, molestiam, sollicitudinem, angorem propter similitudinem corporum aegrorum, aegritudinem nominaverunt; <cit><quote lang="la">and soon after: ut aegrotatio in corpore, sic aegritudo in animo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 10</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 7</bibl>; 9; 12; 13; 14; 26; 4, 7; 15; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 13 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> al.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 84</bibl>.—In the <number>plur.</number>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:2:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 2, 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 19</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 50" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 50</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegror: <entryFree id="n1199" type="main" key="aegror"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegror</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>aeger; as acror from acer</etym>, <sense id="n1199.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">illness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sickness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disease</hi>, only in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1132" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1132</bibl> (for in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1259" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 1259</bibl>, the correct read. is <hi rend="ital">maeror</hi>, v. Lachm. ad h. l.).</sense></entryFree>
aegrotaticius: <entryFree id="n1200" type="main" key="aegrotaticius"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegrotaticius</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aegroto</etym>, <sense id="n1200.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that is often ill</hi>, Gloss. Isid.</sense></entryFree>
aegrotatio: <entryFree id="n1201" type="main" key="aegro_ta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegrōtātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aegroto</etym>, <sense id="n1201.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">illness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sickness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disease</hi>, <hi rend="ital">infirmity</hi> (prop. only of the body, while aegritudo also desig. that of the mind; <cit><quote lang="la">much used in the philos. writings of Cic.): ut aegrotatio in corpore, sic aegritudo in animo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum sanguis corruptus est, morbi aegrotationesque nascuntur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegrotationes nostras portavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:8:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 8, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,049:16:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Jer. 16, 4</bibl>.—The distinction between aegrotatio and morbus Cicero gives as follows: <cit><quote lang="la">Morbum appellant totius corporis corruptionem, aegrotationem morbum cum imbecillitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:13:29" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 13, 29</bibl></cit>.—Only by catachresis, of the mind, <hi rend="ital">morbid state</hi> or <hi rend="ital">condition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disease</hi>, but never strictly for aegritudo.—Thus Cicero says, after giving, in the passage above quoted, the distinction between morbus and aegrotatio, in reference to the body: <cit><quote lang="la">sed in animo tantum modo cogitatione possumus morbum ab aegrotatione sejungere.— So also: nomen insaniae significat mentis aegrotationem et morbum, id est insanitatem et aegrotum animum, quam appellārunt insaniam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 4</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">aegrotationes animi, qualis est avaritia, gloriae cupiditas, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 37, 79</bibl></cit>.—In Pliny, of plants, 17, 24, 37, § 231.</sense></entryFree>
aegroto: <entryFree id="n1202" type="main" key="aegro_to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegrōto</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>aegrotus</etym>, <sense id="n1202.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be ill</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sick.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1202.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of men and brutes: <cit><quote lang="la">vehementer diuque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gravissime aegrotans,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:13" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">graviter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:35" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">leviter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">periculose,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 8, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegrotavit usque ad mortem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:38:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 38, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegrotare timenti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 7, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">morbo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:6:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 6, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegrotare coepit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,012:13:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Reg. 13, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quia armentum aegrotet in agris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 8, 6</bibl></cit>.—Of plants: <cit><quote lang="la">(vites) aegrotant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:226" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 24, 37, § 226</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegrotant poma ipsa per se sine arbore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:228" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 17, 24, 37, § 228</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1202.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n1202.3" n="A" level="2"> Of the mind: <cit><quote lang="la">ea res, ex qua animus aegrotat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:37:79" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 37, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegrotare animi vitio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:307" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 307</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1202.4" n="B" level="2"> Of other abstr. things, <hi rend="ital">to languish</hi>, etc. (cf. jaceo): <cit><quote lang="la">in te aegrotant artes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 1, 8</bibl>: languent officia, atque aegrotat fama vacillans, <hi rend="ital">duties are neglected</hi>, <hi rend="ital">reputation sickens and staggers</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1124" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 1124</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegrotus: <entryFree id="n1203" type="main" key="aegro_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegrōtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aeger</etym>, <sense id="n1203.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">ill</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sick</hi>, <hi rend="ital">diseased</hi> (in Cic. rare). </sense><sense id="n1203.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop., of the body: <cit><quote lang="la">facile omnes, cum valemus, recta consilia aegrotis damus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 1, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegroto, dum anima est, spes esse dicitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum te aegrotum non videam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> 2</bibl></cit> Esdr. 2, 2; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:34:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Ezech. 34, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">leo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1, 73</bibl></cit> al.—</sense><sense id="n1203.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of the mind: <cit><quote lang="la">omnibus amicis morbum inicies gravem, ita ut te videre audireque aegroti sient,</quote> <trans><tr>sick of seeing and hearing you</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 39</bibl></cit> (for the constr. of the <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> here, v. Roby, II. § 1360 sq.): animus, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 469, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 2, 22</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 3, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 4</bibl>.—So of the state: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc remedium est aegrotae et prope desperatae rei publicae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,004:21:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Div. in Caecil. 21, 70</bibl></cit>. <cb n="AEMI" /></sense></entryFree>
aegyptiacus: <entryFree id="n1204" type="main" key="Aegypti^a^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegyptĭăcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1204.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Egyptian</hi> (a later form for the class. Aegyptius): <cit><quote lang="la">libri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 10, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lingua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:41:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 41, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">incantationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:7:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Exod. 7, 11</bibl></cit>: partes, Cod. Th. 13, 5, 14.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegyptĭăcē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">after the Egyptian manner</hi>: loqui, Treb. Poll. 30, Tyr. 30.</sense></entryFree>
aegyptilla: <entryFree id="n1205" type="main" key="aegyptilla"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aegyptilla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1205.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a precious stone once found in Egypt</hi>, prob. <hi rend="ital">a kind of onyx</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:148" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 10, 54, § 148</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 16, 11, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegyptini: <entryFree id="n1206" type="gloss" key="Aegypti_ni"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegyptīni</orth>: Aethiopes, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=28" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 28</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
aegyptius: <entryFree id="n1207" type="main" key="Aegypti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegyptĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)gu/ptios</foreign>, <sense id="n1207.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Egyptian</hi> (the class. word for the later Aegyptiacus in Gell., Plin., and Treb.): <cit><quote lang="la">rex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 21</bibl></cit>: acetum, <hi rend="ital">a superior kind of vinegar</hi>, id. Hortens. ap. Non.: <cit><quote lang="la">bellum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">litus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:142" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 28, 32, § 142</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 9, 10, § 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">classes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:39" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vir,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:39:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 39, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ancilla,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 16, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:21:38 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 21, 38 al.</bibl>—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1207.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegyptĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an Egyptian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid igitur censes? Apim illum sanctum Aegyptiorum bovem, nonne deum videri Aegyptiis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:29" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 29</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 3, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 110</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 2, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 7</bibl>. 22 al.</sense></entryFree>
aegyptus: <entryFree id="n1208" type="main" key="Aegyptus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegyptus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/guptos</foreign>, <sense id="n1208.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Egypt</hi>, sometimes reckoned by the ancients as belonging to Asia: <cit><quote lang="la">Asiae prima pars Aegyptus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:9" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">proxima Africae incolitur Aegyptus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 9, 9, § 48</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 106</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:12:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 12, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 2, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1209" type="main" key="Aegyptus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegyptus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, acc. to the fable, <sense id="n1209.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a king of Egypt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son of Belus</hi> (acc. to others, of Neptune), <hi rend="ital">and brother of Danaüs. He had fifty sons</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to whom the fifty daughters of Danaüs were espoused</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 168" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 168</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aelianus: <entryFree id="n1210" type="main" key="Aeli^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aelĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1210.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">originating from an Ælius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oratiunculae,</quote> <trans><tr>composed by the Stoic philosopher L. Ælius</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 56 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">studia, of the same,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:43:193" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 43, 193</bibl></cit>: jus, <hi rend="ital">a code of laws</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now lost</hi>, <hi rend="ital">compiled by Sext. Ælius Pœtus</hi>, in the sixth century A. U. C., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:2:2:section=7" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 1, 2, 2, § 7</bibl>; cf. Teuffel, Rom. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> § 114.</sense></entryFree>
aelinos: <entryFree id="n1211" type="greek" key="aeli^nos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aelĭnos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)/linos</foreign> (from the interj. <foreign lang="greek">ai)=</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">*ai/nos</foreign>; cf. Su<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:II. p. 449" default="NO"><author>id.</author> II. p. 449</bibl> Kust.), <sense id="n1211.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a song of lament</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a dirge</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aelinon in silvis idem pater, aelinon, altis Dicitui invitā concinuisse lyrā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:9:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 3, 9, 23</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aelius: <entryFree id="n1212" type="main" key="Aeli^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aelĭus</orth>, a. <sense id="n1212.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a Roman</hi> gens.—</sense><sense id="n1212.1" n="II" level="1"> <pos>Adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Aelian;</hi> hence, </sense><sense id="n1212.2" n="1" level="3"> Lex Aelia de comitiis, named after Q. Aelius Paetus, by whom it was proposed. A. U. C. 596, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:15:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 15, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,023:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Vatin. 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:9 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 9 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n1212.3" n="2" level="3"> Lex Aelia Sentia, proposed by the consuls Sext. Aelius and C. Sentius, A. U. C. 757, containing regulations concerning the limitation of manumission; cf. Ulp. Fragm. tit. 1; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:40:2:12" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 40, 2, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:15" default="NO">15</bibl> and 10, etc.; Zimmern, Hist. of Law, 1, 81, and 761 sq.</sense></entryFree>
aello: <entryFree id="n1213" type="main" key="A^ello_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăëllō</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aellw/</foreign>. <sense id="n1213.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a harpy</hi> (from <foreign lang="greek">a)/ella</foreign>, tempest, because she came like it upon her prey): <cit><quote lang="la">ales Aëllo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:710" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 710</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1213.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a swiftrunning dog</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:219" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 219</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aelurus: <entryFree id="n1214" type="greek" key="aelu_rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aelūrus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)/louros</foreign>, <sense id="n1214.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a cat</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:8" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Astr. 2:28" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Astr. 2, 28</bibl>; cf. Rupert. Excur. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:15:7" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 15, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aemidum: <entryFree id="n1215" type="gloss" key="aemidum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aemidum</orth>: tumidum, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=24:4" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 24, 4</bibl> [<foreign lang="greek">ai(=ma</foreign>, blood]; cf. aemidus <foreign lang="greek">pefushme/nos</foreign>, Gloss. Labb.</entryFree>
aemilianus: <entryFree id="n1216" type="main" key="Aemi^li^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aemĭlĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Aemilius</etym>, <sense id="n1216.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">relating to the Æmilian</hi> gens, <hi rend="ital">Æmilian.</hi> Thus Scipio Africanus Minor, the son of Paulus Aemilius, was called Aemilianus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:10" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:15" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 15</bibl>.—In <hi rend="ital">neutr. plur.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aemĭlĭāna</orth> (sc. aedificia or loca), <hi rend="ital">a place just out of Rome</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not far from the Campus Martius</hi>, perh. thus named in honor of Scipio Aemilianus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 2</bibl>. There was also, in the seventh region of the city of Rome, an Aemilian street, Sext. Ruf. do Reg. Urb. Rom.; from</sense></entryFree>
aemilius: <entryFree id="n1217" type="main" key="Aemi^li^us1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aemĭlĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aemulor</etym>, <sense id="n1217.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a Roman</hi> gens, <hi rend="ital">greatly distinguished for the illustrious men whom it furnished.</hi> The most celebrated of them was L. Aemilius Paulus, the conqueror of Perseus, and the father of Corn. Scipio Africanus Minor: <cit><quote lang="la">domus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 1, 794</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 36</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Aemĭlĭa Vĭa</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the name of three several public roads.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1217.1" n="1" level="3"> One, constructed by M. Aemilius Lepidus, as consul, A. U. C. 567, began at Placentia, and passed <pb n="55" /> <cb n="AEMU" /> through Parma, Regium, Mutina, Bononia, Forum Cornelii, Faventia, Forum Livii, and Caesena to Ariminum, where it joined the Via Flaminia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1217.2" n="2" level="3"> One, constructed A. U. C. 645, by M. Aemilius Scaurus, as censor, led from Bononia, through Pisa and Luna, to Dertona, Strab. 1, 5.—</sense><sense id="n1217.3" n="3" level="3"> One extending from Ariminum to Aquileia (some, however, consider this as the same with the first), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:3:4" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 3, 4</bibl>.—Sometimes <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aemĭlĭa</orth>, instead of Via Aemilia: in ipsā Aemiliā diu pugnatum est, Galba ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 30</bibl>.—From the public way, Martial calls the region between Ariminum and Placentia (commonly Gallia Cispadana) regio Aemilia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:6:85" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 6, 85</bibl>.—Aemilius pons, so called after its builder, M. Aemilius Scaurus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:32" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 32</bibl> Rupert.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aemilia ratis,</quote> <trans><tr>the ship on which the booty acquired by L. Æmilius Paulus</tr>, <tr>in the war with Perseus</tr>, <tr>was conveyed to Rome</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:2:8" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 2, 8</bibl></cit>.—Aemilius ludus, <hi rend="ital">a gladiatorial exhibition introduced by P. Æmilius Lepidus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 32</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1218" type="main" key="Aemi^li^us2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aemĭlĭus Măcer</orth>, <itype>of Verona</itype>, <sense id="n1218.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a poet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the friend of Virgil and Ovid</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who wrote</hi> De Serpentibus et Volucribus (and perh. De Virtutibus Herbarum), <hi rend="ital">of which nothing is extant</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:10:43" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 4, 10, 43</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. E. 5, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aemonia: <entryFree id="n1219" type="main" key="Aemo^nia"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aemŏnia, Aemŏnides, Aemŏ-nis</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Aemŏnius</orth>, v. Haemonia, etc.</entryFree>
aemula: <entryFree id="n1220" type="main" key="aemu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aemŭla</orth>, v. aemulus.</entryFree>
aemulanter: <entryFree id="n1221" type="main" key="aemu^lanter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aemŭlanter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. aemulor <sense id="n1221.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aemulatio: <entryFree id="n1222" type="main" key="aemu^la_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aemŭlātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aemulor</etym>, <sense id="n1222.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an assiduous striving to equal</hi> or <hi rend="ital">excel another in any thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">emulation</hi> (it denotes rather the mental effort, while <hi rend="ital">imitatio</hi> regards more the mode of action; but <hi rend="ital">rivalitas</hi> is a jealous rivalry, and therefore used only in a bad sense, while <hi rend="ital">aemulatio</hi> is employed both in a good and bad sense) Cic. thus explains this word: aemulatio dupliciter illa quidem dicitur, ut et in laude et in vitio nomen hoc sit; <cit><quote lang="la">nam et imitatio virtutis aemulatio dicitur ... et est aemulatio aegritudo, si eo, quod concupierit, alius potiatur, ipse careat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:8:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 8, 17</bibl></cit>. So, </sense><sense id="n1222.1" n="I" level="1"> In a good sense, <hi rend="ital">emulation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">laudis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:17" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 17</bibl>: gloriae, Just. praef.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 44</bibl>, id Agr. 21; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:19" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:11" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tib. 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">secundum aemulationem,</quote> <trans><tr>in zeal</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,011:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Phil. 3, 6</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of the imitation of nature in painting: <cit><quote lang="la">pictura fallax est et in aemulatione naturae multum degenerat transcribentium sors varia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 2, 4, § 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1222.2" n="II" level="1"> In a bad sense, <hi rend="ital">jealousy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">envy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">malevolence</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">duszhli/a</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">aemulatio vitiosa, quae rivalitati similis est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:26:56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 26, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">infensa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">municipalis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 3, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversariorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:23" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 23</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aemulatio nasci tur ex conjunctione, alitur aequalitate, exardescit invidiā, cujus finis est odium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:84 al" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 84 al.</bibl></cit>: ad aemulationem eum provocaverunt, <hi rend="ital">to jealousy</hi> (said of God), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:77:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 77, 58</bibl>. contentiones, aemulationes, <hi rend="ital">rivalries</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2</bibl> Cor, 12, 20.</sense></entryFree>
aemulator: <entryFree id="n1223" type="main" key="aemu^la_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aemŭlātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1223.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a zealous imitator</hi>, <hi rend="ital">emulator</hi> (in a good sense), <foreign lang="greek">zhlwth/s</foreign>: ejus (sc. Catonis), * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus aemulator Dei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 124" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 124 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">virtutum aemulator fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:6:3" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 6, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aemulatores sunt legis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:21:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 21, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1</bibl> Cor. 14, 12.—Eccl., of God as jealous of his honor: Deus est aemulator, (<hi rend="ital">the Lord</hi>) <hi rend="ital">is a jealous God</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:34:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 34, 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aemulatrix: <entryFree id="n1224" type="main" key="aemu^la_trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aemŭlātrix</orth>, <itype>īcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aemulator</etym>, <sense id="n1224.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a female emulator</hi> (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Var. 7, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aemulatus: <entryFree id="n1225" type="main" key="aemu^la_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aemŭlātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> Perh. only in Tac. for the class. aemulatio, <sense id="n1225.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">emulation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rivalry</hi>, Hist. 3, 66.—In <number>plur.</number>, Ann. 13, 46. (But in Agr. 46, aemulatu is only a conjecture of Heinsius; Orell. and Halm read <hi rend="ital">similitudine</hi>).</sense></entryFree>
aemulo: <entryFree id="n1226" type="hapax" key="aemu^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aemŭlo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> An active form for aemulor (q. v.), <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 1, p. 112</bibl>.</entryFree>
aemulor: <entryFree id="n1227" type="main" key="aemu^lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aemŭlor</orth>, <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>aemulus</etym>, <sense id="n1227.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to rival</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to endeavor to equal</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to excel one</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to emulate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vie with</hi>, in a good and bad sense; hence (as a consequence of this action). <hi rend="ital">to equal one by emulating.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1227.1" n="I" level="1"> In a good sense, constr. with <case>acc.</case>, v.
