II.: <cit><quote lang="la">quoniam aemulari non licet, nunc invides,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 2, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes ejus instituta laudare facilius possunt quam aemulari,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 26</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Epam. 5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Epam. 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 18</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 81</bibl>: Pindarum quisquis studet <cb n="AENE" /> aemulari, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:62" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 62</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">severitatem alicujus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">virtutes majorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 15</bibl></cit> et saep.—<usg type="style">Transf.</usg> of things: <cit><quote lang="la">Basilicae uvae Albanum vinum aemulantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 2, 4, § 30</bibl></cit>.—Prov.: <cit><quote lang="la">aemulari umbras,</quote> <trans><tr>to fight shadows</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:32:19" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 32, 19</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:15:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 15, 20</bibl>: qui umbras timet).—</sense><sense id="n1227.2" n="II" level="1"> In a bad sense, <hi rend="ital">to strive after</hi> or <hi rend="ital">vie with enviously</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be envious of</hi>, <hi rend="ital">be jealous of</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">zhlotupei=n</foreign>; constr. with <case>dat.</case>, while in the first signif. down to Quint. with <hi rend="ital">acc.;</hi> v. Spald. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:122" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 122</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">Rudd. II. p. 151: iis aemulemur, qui ea habent, quae nos habere cupimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 19</bibl></cit>; cf. 4, 26; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:6:9" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 6, 9</bibl>.—Also with <hi rend="ital">cum</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne mecum aemuletur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inter se,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 81</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aemulabantur corruptissimum quemque pretio inlicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 62</bibl></cit>.—Hence, * <orth extent="full" lang="la">aemŭlanter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">emulously</hi>, Tert. c. Haer. 40.</sense></entryFree>
aemulus: <entryFree id="n1228" type="main" key="aemu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aemŭlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>cf. <foreign lang="greek">a(milla/omai</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">a(/ma</foreign>, imitor, imago, Germ. ahmen (Eng. aim) in nachahmen = to imitate</etym>, <sense id="n1228.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">striving after another earnestly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">emulating</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rivalling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">emulous</hi> (cf. aemulatio and aemulor), in a good and bad sense; constr. with <case>dat.</case> or as <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1228.1" n="I" level="1"> In a good sense, Att. ap. Auct. Her, 2, 26, 42: <cit><quote lang="la">laudum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">laudis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aemulus atque imitator studiorum ac laborum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Marc. 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Timagenis aemula lingua,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 19, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">itinerum Herculis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 41</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">ne</hi> and <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi>: milites aemuli, ne dissimiles viderentur, Aur. Vict <bibl default="NO"><author>Caes.</author> 8, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1228.2" n="II" level="1"> In a bad sense, both of one who, with a hostile feeling, strives after the possessions of another, and of one who, on account of his strong desire for a thing, envies him who possesses it; <hi rend="ital">envious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">jealous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grudging.</hi>— With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: Karthago aemula imperii Romani, Sall C. 10; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:1" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Triton,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:173" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 173</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem remoto aemulo aequiorem sibi sperabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Britannici,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:6" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1228.3" n="III" level="1"> <pos>Subst.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">a rival</hi> = rivalis: mihi es aemula, <hi rend="ital">you are my rival</hi> (i. e. <hi rend="ital">you have the same desire as I</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:1:4:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 1, 4, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 1, 9</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 8</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">si non tamquam virum, at tamquam aemulum removisset,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Verr 2, 5, 31</bibl></cit>: et si nulla subest aemula, languet amor, Ov A. A. 2, 436.—By meton. (eccl.), <hi rend="ital">an enemy</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">videbis aemulum tuum in templo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 2, 32</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">affligebat eam aemula,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1, 6</bibl></cit>.— In gen., mostly of things without life, <hi rend="ital">vying with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rivalling a thing</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">comparable to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">similar to</hi>, with <case>dat.</case>, v. Rudd. II. p. 70 (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>, and in prose after the Aug. per.): <cit><quote lang="la">tibia tubae Aemula,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:203" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 203</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">labra rosis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:4:42" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 4, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tuscis vina cadis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:13:118" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 13, 118</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 17, 29, § 63</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:68 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 15, 18, 19, § 68 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Dictator Caesar summis oratoribus aemulus, i. e. aequiparandus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 3</bibl></cit>.!*? Facta dictaque ejus aemulus for aemulans, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:Fragm. Hist. 3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> Fragm. Hist. 3</bibl> (cf. celatum indagator for indagans in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 1, 15</bibl>, unless celatum be here a <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>).</sense></entryFree>
aenaria: <entryFree id="n1229" type="main" key="Aena_ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenārĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1229.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an island on the western coast of Campania</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the landing-place of Æneas</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Ischia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:10:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 10, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:92" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 92</bibl>; Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=20" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 20</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
aenea: <entryFree id="n1230" type="main" key="Aene_a1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenēa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, v. Aeneas.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1231" type="main" key="Aene_a2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenēa</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenīa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/neia</foreign>, <sense id="n1231.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of Chalcidice</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in Macedonia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">opposite Pydna</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:10" default="NO" valid="yes">44, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32" default="NO" valid="yes">32</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1231.1" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenēātes</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Ænea</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 4, 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1231.2" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenēātĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">belonging to Ænea</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">abies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:197" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 39, 76, § 197</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aeneades: <entryFree id="n1232" type="main" key="Aene^a^de_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenĕădēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype> (<sense id="n1232.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> Aeneadūm, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:2:261" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 2, 261</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">patr. m.</hi> [Aeneas]. </sense><sense id="n1232.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A descendant of Æneas; his son Ascanius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:653" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 653</bibl> (<hi rend="ital">Aenides</hi>, Rib.).—</sense><sense id="n1232.2" n="II" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">those who are related in any manner to Æneas;</hi> nence, </sense><sense id="n1232.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A Trojan</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:616" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 616</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 565</bibl>; but oftener, </sense><sense id="n1232.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A Roman</hi>, Verg. a. 8, 648; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:682:695 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 682, 695 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n1232.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">An adulatory epithet of Augustus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:1:1:35" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 1, 1, 35</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">of Scipio</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:13:767" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 13, 767</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeneaeportus: <entryFree id="n1233" type="main" key="Aene_ae Portus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenēae Portus</orth>, <sense id="n1233.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a harbor near Torone and Mount Athos</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:30:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 30, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeneas: <entryFree id="n1234" type="main" key="Aene_as"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenēas</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (also in the <case>nom.</case> Aenea, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 50</bibl> P.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:61" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 5, 61</bibl>; <sense id="n1234.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> sometimes Aeneā, Apul. Orth. § 23 Osann.; <case>acc.</case> Aenean often, after the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">*ainei/n</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:568" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 568</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:7:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 7, 36</bibl>; <case>voc.</case> Aenēā, Poët. ap <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=60" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 60</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 7, 9</bibl>), = <foreign lang="greek">*ai\nei/as</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">Æneas</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son of</hi> <cb n="AENU" /> <hi rend="ital">Venus and Anchises</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the hero of Virgil's epic poem</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and ancestor of the Romans</hi>, <hi rend="ital">worshipped after his death as</hi> Juppiter Indiges; cf. Nieb. Röm. Gesch. 1, 207 sq.</sense></entryFree>
aeneates: <entryFree id="n1235" type="main" key="Aene_a_tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenēātes</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, v. 2. Aenea, A.</entryFree>
aeneaticus: <entryFree id="n1236" type="main" key="Aene_a_ti^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenēātĭcus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, um v. 2. Aenea, B.</entryFree>
aeneator: <entryFree id="n1237" type="main" key="aene^a_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aenĕātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>aes</etym>, <sense id="n1237.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who blows a horn in war</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a trumpeter</hi>: Aeneatores cornicines dicuntur, id est cornu canentes, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=20" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 20</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:32" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 32</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeneis: <entryFree id="n1238" type="main" key="Aene_is"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenēis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis or ĭdos</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>Aeneas</etym>, <sense id="n1238.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the Æneid</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Virgil's celebrated epic</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the hero of which is Æneas</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the progenitor of the Romans</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aeneïdos auctor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:2:533" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 2, 533</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec tu divinam Aeneïda tenta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:12" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 12 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">morbo oppressus (Vergilius) petivit a suis, ut Aeneïda quam nondum satis elimavisset, adolerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 17, 10</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aeneius: <entryFree id="n1239" type="main" key="Aene_i^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenēĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype> (quadrisyl.), <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1239.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Æneas</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nutrix, Verg A. 7, 1: virtus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:581" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 581</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pietas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:799" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 4, 799</bibl></cit>: fata, <hi rend="ital">his death</hi>, Stat S. 5, 3, 37.</sense></entryFree>
aeneolus: <entryFree id="n1240" type="main" key="a^e_ne^o^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăēnĕŏlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n1240.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. dim.</hi> [aeneus], <hi rend="ital">made of bronze</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeneoli piscatores,</quote> <trans><tr>little figures of fishermen in bronze</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0972,001:13" default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> S. 13</bibl></cit>; cf. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=28" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 28</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
aenesi: <entryFree id="n1241" type="gloss" key="Aene_si"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenēsi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1241.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the companions of Æneas</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=20" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 20</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
aeneus: <entryFree id="n1242" type="main" key="ae_ne^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aēnĕus</orth> (less freq. <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăhēn-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1242.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of bronze</hi> [aes]. </sense><sense id="n1242.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of copper</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bronze</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">equus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:9" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">statua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:9:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 9, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">candelabra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">loricae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Iphicr. 1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Iphicr. 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:3:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 3, 65</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 9, 18</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 16, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 248</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ahenea proles,</quote> <trans><tr>the brazen age</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 125</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aëneus (quadrisyl.) ut stes,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>that a bronze statue may be erected to thee</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sat. 2, 3, 183</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1242.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of the color of bronze</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">barba,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:2" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 2</bibl></cit>; cf. Aenobarbus.</sense></entryFree>
aenianes: <entryFree id="n1243" type="main" key="Aeni^a_nes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenĭānes</orth>, <itype>um</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1243.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people of Thessalia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">west of the</hi> Sinus Maliacus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:chapter=2" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2</bibl> 4; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:5:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 5, 15</bibl> (the <foreign lang="greek">*)enih=nes</foreign> of Homer, II 2, 749).</sense></entryFree>
aenides: <entryFree id="n1244" type="main" key="Aeni_de_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenīdēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <sense id="n1244.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">patr. m.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1244.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A son of Æneas</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:653" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 653</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1244.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A descendant of Æneus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king on the Propontis.</hi>—In the <number>plur.</number>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Cyzicus</hi>, because a son of Æneus was the founder of that city, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:3:4" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 3, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aenigma: <entryFree id="n1245" type="greek" key="aenigma^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aenigmă</orth>, <itype>ătis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)/nigma</foreign> (<case>dat.</case> and <sense id="n1245.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">abl. plur.</hi> aenigmatis, <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 38</bibl> P.), <hi rend="ital">that which is enigmatical</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dark in a figurative representation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an allegory;</hi> accto Quintilian's expl.: <cit><quote lang="la">allegoria, quae est obscurior,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inst.</author> 8, 6, 52</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 42</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1245.1" n="II" level="1"> Of other things. </sense><sense id="n1245.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">That which is dark</hi>, <hi rend="ital">obscure</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">inexplicable; a riddle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">enigma</hi>, <hi rend="ital">obscurity</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">regina Saba venit temptare eum in aenigmatibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,013:10:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Reg. 10, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obscuritates et aenigmata somniorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:64" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 64</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">aenigma numero Platonis obscurius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">legum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:50" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">palam et non per aenigmata Dominum videt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,004:12:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Num. 12, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1</bibl> Cor. 13, 12.—</sense><sense id="n1245.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A mystery; a mystical tenet</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dogma in religion</hi>, Arn 3, p. 109.</sense></entryFree>
aenigmaticus: <entryFree id="n1246" type="main" key="aenigma^ticus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aenigmăticus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aenigma</etym>, <sense id="n1246.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">like an enigma</hi>, <hi rend="ital">obscure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">enigmatic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille clarum esse somnium dixit, et nihil aenigmaticum, nihil dubium continere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> H. Eccl. 9, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aenigmatista: <entryFree id="n1247" type="greek" key="aenigma^tista"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aenigmătista</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">-tes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)nigmatisths</foreign>, <sense id="n1247.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one that proposes riddles</hi>, <hi rend="ital">one that speaks in riddles</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an enigmatist</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 8, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Quaest. in Num. 4:45" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Quaest. in Num. 4, 45</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aenipes: <entryFree id="n1248" type="main" key="a^e_ni^pes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăēnĭpes</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăhēnĭpes</orth>, <itype>ĕdis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aeneus-pes</etym>, <sense id="n1248.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that has feet of bronze</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bronzefooted</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">xalko/pous</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">boves,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:6:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 6, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> adv. Symm. 1, 531</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aenitologium: <entryFree id="n1249" type="main" key="aenitologium"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aenitologium</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> In metre, <sense id="n1249.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a dac tylic verse with an iambic</hi> penthemimeris, e. g. Carmina bella magis vellem sonare, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> in Centim. 1825</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
aenobarbus: <entryFree id="n1250" type="main" key="A^e_no^barbus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăēnŏbarbus</orth> (earlier, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăēn-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>aeneus, II., and barba. Red-beard</etym>, <sense id="n1250.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a family name of the Domitian</hi> gens, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:1" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 1</bibl> Oud.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3793</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aenulum: <entryFree id="n1251" type="main" key="ae_nu^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aēnŭlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>aenus</etym>, <sense id="n1251.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small bronze vessel</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=28" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 28</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
aenus: <entryFree id="n1252" type="main" key="Aenus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-os</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)=nos</foreign>, <sense id="n1252.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of Thrace</hi>, <hi rend="ital">south-east of the</hi> Palus Stentoris, <hi rend="ital">through which one of the mouths of the Hebrus falls into the sea</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Enos</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:2:8" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 2, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 11, 18, § 43</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 16</bibl> 4.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1252.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenĭi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Ænus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:41" default="NO" valid="yes">38, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:27" default="NO" valid="yes">45, 27</bibl>. <pb n="56" /> <cb n="AEQU" /></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1253" type="main" key="Aenus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aenus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1253.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the river Inn</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1254" type="main" key="a^e_nus3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăēnus</orth> (trisyl.; less freq. <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăhēn-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aes</etym>, <sense id="n1254.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of copper</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bronze</hi> (only <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for aheneus; yet Hor. uses the latter oftener than the former). </sense><sense id="n1254.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: signa, <hi rend="ital">the bronze images of the gods</hi>, Lucr 1, 316: <cit><quote lang="la">ahënis in scaphiis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 1045</bibl></cit>, falcīs, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 5, 1293</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:513" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 513</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">lux, i. e. armorum aënorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 470</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">crateres,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 165</bibl></cit>.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăēnum</orth> (sc. vas), <hi rend="ital">a bronze vessel</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">litore aëna locant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:213" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 213</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:645" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 645</bibl>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:15:81 al" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 15, 81 al.</bibl>, of the bronze vessels in which the purple color was prepared, <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F 3, 822</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Oet. 663" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Oet. 663</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:2:151" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 2, 151</bibl> (hence, aenulum).—</sense><sense id="n1254.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1254.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Firm</hi>, <hi rend="ital">invincible</hi> (cf. adamantinus): <cit><quote lang="la">manus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:35:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 35, 18</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1254.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Hard</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rigorous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inexorable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">corda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:3:380" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 3, 380</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aeoles: <entryFree id="n1255" type="main" key="Aeo^les"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeŏles</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeolīs</orth>, Varr.), <itype>um</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)olei=s</foreign>, <sense id="n1255.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the Æolians</hi>, orig. in Thessaly, later in the Peloponnesus, on the coast of Asia Minor, in Lesbos, and other places, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=25" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:102" default="NO">102</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:1:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> R. R. 3, 1, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:3:12:6" default="NO">3, 12, 6</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 27</bibl>, Their more usual name is Aeolii; v. Aeolius.</sense></entryFree>
aeolia: <entryFree id="n1256" type="main" key="Aeo^li^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeŏlĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)oli/a</foreign>. <sense id="n1256.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A group of islands near Sicily</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so called after Æolus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who is said to have once reigned there</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">the Lipari Islands</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:92 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 8, 14, § 92 sq.</bibl>— </sense><sense id="n1256.1" n="II" level="1"> In mythol., <hi rend="ital">the abode of Æolus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the god of the winds.</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 52</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1256.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A country of Asia Minor</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,009:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Con. 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeolicus: <entryFree id="n1257" type="main" key="Aeo^li^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeŏlĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)oliko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n1257.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Æolians</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Æolian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Æolic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 2, 2, § 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">digamma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:4:7" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 4, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">littera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:7:27" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 7, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:59" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8, 3, 59</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aeolides: <entryFree id="n1258" type="main" key="Aeo^li^des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeŏlĭdes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <sense id="n1258.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">patr. m.</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)oli/dhs</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a male descendant of Æolus: his son Sisyphus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 26</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">Athamas</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:4:511" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 511</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">Salmoneus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:473" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ib. 473</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">his grandson Cephalus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:7:672" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 672</bibl>; also <hi rend="ital">Ulysses</hi>, whose mother, Anticlea, is said to have had intercourse with Sisyphus before her marriage with Laertes, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:529" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 529</bibl>; also <hi rend="ital">Phrixus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:286" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 286</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeolipilae: <entryFree id="n1259" type="hapax" key="aeo^li^pi^lae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aeŏlĭpĭlae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aeolus-pila</etym>, <sense id="n1259.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">vessels</hi> (or <hi rend="ital">instruments</hi>) <hi rend="ital">for investigating the nature of the wind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">eolipiles</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 1, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeolis: <entryFree id="n1260" type="main" key="Aeo^lis1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeŏlis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)oli/s</foreign>, <sense id="n1260.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a country in Asia Minor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">north of Ionia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:38:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 33, 38, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:8:12" default="NO" valid="yes">37, 8, 12</bibl>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 29, 27, § 103</bibl></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1261" type="main" key="Aeo^lis2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeŏlis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <sense id="n1261.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">patr. f.</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)oli/s</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a female descendant of Æolus;</hi> so <hi rend="ital">his daughters: Halcyone</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:579" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 11, 579</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">Canace</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:11:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 11, 34</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeolius: <entryFree id="n1262" type="main" key="Aeo^li^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeŏlĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)o/lios</foreign>, <sense id="n1262.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to Æolus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Æolia</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">Æolis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Æolian.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1262.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Pertaining to Æolus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the god of the winds</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">to his posterity;</hi> Euri, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:12:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 3, 12, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">venti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:4:1:58" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 4, 1, 58</bibl></cit>: aurum, <hi rend="ital">the golden fleece</hi> (of the ram) <hi rend="ital">on which Phrixus and Helle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the grandchildren of Æolus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fled</hi>, Vai. Fl. 8, 79: virgo, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Arne</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Canace</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:116" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 116</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">postes, i. e. fores domūs Athamantis Aeoli filii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:4:486" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 486</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n1262.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Pertaining to Æolia</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Æolis</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">insulae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 21, 42, § 154</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pontus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:233" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 233</bibl></cit>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeŏlii</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = Aeoles, <hi rend="ital">the Æolians</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Æolia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in Asia Minor</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:4" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 4</bibl>; Mela, 1, 18, 1.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1262.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Pertaining to the Æolians</hi>: puella, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Sappho</hi>, as a Lesbian woman, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:9:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 9, 12</bibl>: carmen, <hi rend="ital">a Sapphic</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Alcaic ode</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 3, 12</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Aeoliis fidibus querentem Sappho,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 13, 24</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">lyra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:15:200" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 15, 200</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plectrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:3:19" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 3, 19</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aeolus: <entryFree id="n1263" type="main" key="Aeo^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeŏlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/olos</foreign>. <sense id="n1263.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The god of the winds</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son of Jupiter</hi> (or Hippotas) <hi rend="ital">and of Menalippa</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ruler of the islands between Italy and Sicily</hi>, <hi rend="ital">where he kept the winds shut up in caverns</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at the bidding of Jupiter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">let them loose</hi> or <hi rend="ital">recalled them</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 52</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aeolon Hippotaden, cohibentem carcere ventos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:224" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 224</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n1263.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A king in Thessaly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son of Hellen and Doreïs</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grandson of Deucalion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">father of Sisyphus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Athamas</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Salmoneus</hi>, etc., <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 6, 585</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeon: <entryFree id="n1264" type="greek" key="aeo_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aeōn</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)w/n</foreign> (age, eternity). Often used by <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Haer. 33</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">34</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">49</bibl>, and adv. Valentin., who invented much concerning the Thirty Æons, whom he maintained to be gods.</entryFree>
aepy: <entryFree id="n1265" type="main" key="Aepy"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aepy</orth>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)=pu</foreign>, <sense id="n1265.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of Elis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mentioned by Homer</hi> (II. 2, 592), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:180" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 180</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequabilis: <entryFree id="n1266" type="main" key="aequa_bi^li^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequābĭlĭs</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequo</etym>, <sense id="n1266.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that can</hi> <cb n="AEQU" /> <hi rend="ital">be made equal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">similar</hi>, <hi rend="ital">like</hi> (“aequalis alterius staturae par; aequabile quod aequari potest,” <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Differ. 2198" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Differ. 2198</bibl> P.); class.; in Cic. very freq. (syn.: aequalis, aequus, planus, par, similis). </sense><sense id="n1266.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">vis hostilis cum istoc fecit meas opes aequabiles,</quote> <trans><tr>has made my property equal to his</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">par (sc. est jus), quod in omnes aequabile est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:22:68" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 22, 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praedae partitio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:11" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in descriptione aequabili sumptus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 14</bibl></cit>, so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> N D. 1, 19</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">mixtura vitiorum atque virtutum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:3" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Dom. 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1266.2" n="II" level="1"> Transf </sense><sense id="n1266.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Equal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">consistent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uniform</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equable;</hi> ut haec patientia dolorum ... in omni genere se aequabilem praebeat, <hi rend="ital">may appear as constantly equal to itself</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 27</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">motus certus et aequabilis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">moderati aequabilesque habitus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin 5, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fluvius,</quote> <trans><tr>which always continues with the same current</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 2, 5</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">pulvis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequabilior firmitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 74" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ver aequabile,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 2, 11, 2</bibl></cit>.—Hence, of discourse: aequabile et temperatum orationis genus, <hi rend="ital">even and moderate style</hi> (opp vis dicendi major in orationibus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 1</bibl>); <cit><quote lang="la">tractus orationis lenis et aequabilis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:13:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 13, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">genus orationis fusum atque tractum et cum lenitate quadam aequabile profluens,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 64</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1266.4" n="B" level="2"> In relation to morals, <hi rend="ital">equitable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">just</hi>, <hi rend="ital">right;</hi> constr. with <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <case>acc.</case> or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">status rei publicae. non in omnes ordines civitatis aequabilis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fidus Romanis, aequabilis in suos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jus aequabile,</quote> <trans><tr>that deals alike with all</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:2" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 1, 2</bibl></cit>: aequabilium legum conditor, Aur, Vict. <bibl default="NO"><author>Caes.</author> 20, 23</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 20</bibl>.— <hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aequābĭlĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">uniformly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equally</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in like manner</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 103</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:6:6" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 6, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:45" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 45</bibl> et saep. —<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 2</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> does not occur either in the <pos>adj.</pos> or <pos>adv.</pos></sense></entryFree>
aequabilitas: <entryFree id="n1267" type="main" key="aequa_bi^li^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequābĭlĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aequabilis</etym>, <sense id="n1267.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the quality of</hi> aequabilis, <hi rend="ital">equality</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uniformity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">evenness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equability</hi> (in the class. per., perh. only in Cic.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 5, 14</bibl>). </sense><sense id="n1267.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">motūs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">universae vitae, tum singularum actionum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:31:111" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 31, 111</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 26</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1267.2" n="II" level="1"> Of law, <hi rend="ital">equity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">justice</hi>, <hi rend="ital">impartiality</hi> (cf. aequabilis, II. B.): <cit><quote lang="la">in rebus causisque civium aequabilitatis conservatio,</quote> <trans><tr>impartiality</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:42:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 42, 188</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in laude justitiae explicandum est quid cum fide, quid cum aequabilitate factum sit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 85</bibl></cit>. —Of the administration of the state, <hi rend="ital">an equal claim</hi> or <hi rend="ital">title of all to the same political equality</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipsa aequabilitas est iniqua, cum habeat nullos gradus dignitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 27</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1267.3" n="III" level="1"> Of discourse, <hi rend="ital">uniformity of style</hi> (cf. aequabilis, II.): <cit><quote lang="la">elaborant alii in lenitate et aequabilitate et puro quasi quodam et candido genere dicendi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:16:53" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 16, 53</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
aequabiliter: <entryFree id="n1268" type="main" key="aequa_bi^li^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequābĭlĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. aequabilis <sense id="n1268.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aequaevus: <entryFree id="n1269" type="main" key="aequaevus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequaevus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequus-aevum</etym>, <sense id="n1269.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of equal age</hi>, <hi rend="ital">just as old</hi>, <hi rend="ital">coeval</hi> (in gen. only <usg type="style">poet.</usg>; <cit><quote lang="la">esp. freq. in Claudian): amicus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5</bibl></cit>. 452; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 561</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequaevi gregis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Agam. 673" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Agam. 673</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">majestas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> IV. Cons. Hon. 121</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbs aequaeva polo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Bell. Get. 54</bibl></cit> et saep.—In prose: <cit><quote lang="la">lotos aequaeva Urbi intellegitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:236" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 44, 86, § 236</bibl></cit>: auditor, Suet. Vit. Pers.</sense></entryFree>
aequalis: <entryFree id="n1270" type="main" key="aequa_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequo</etym>, <sense id="n1270.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that can be put on an equality with;</hi> conseq., <hi rend="ital">equal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">like;</hi> constr. with <case>dat.</case>, <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> and as <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> (syn.: aequus, aequabilis, planus, par, similis). </sense><sense id="n1270.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">partem pedis esse aequalom alteri parti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:56:188" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 56, 188</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paupertatem divitiis etiam inter homines aequalem esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:10:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 10, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequalem se faciens Deo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:5:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Joan. 5, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequales angelis sunt,</quote> <trans><tr>like</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:20:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 20, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec enim aut linguā aut moribus aequales abhorrere (Bastarnas a Scordiscis),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:57:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 57, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut sententiae sint membris aequalibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:3:80" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 3, 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequalis ponderis erunt omnes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:30:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 30, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:19:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Deut. 19, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:21:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Apoc. 21, 16</bibl>.—As <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Creticus et ejus aequalis Paeon,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:64:215" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 64, 215</bibl></cit>. (Another constr., v. II.)—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1270.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1270.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">That can be compared in respect to age</hi>, <hi rend="ital">of the same age</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equally old.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1270.4" n="1" level="3"> Of persons. </sense><sense id="n1270.5" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Of the same age</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equal in years</hi>: cum neque me aspicere aequales dignarent meae. Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 470, 20</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 97 Rib.): patris cognatum atque aequalem, Archidemidem, nostine? Ter Eun. 2, <cb n="AEQU" /> 3, 35: <cit><quote lang="la">adulescens ita dilexi senem, ut aequalem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:4:10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">P. Orbius, meus fere aequalis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=48" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 48 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aristides aequalis fere ruit Themistocli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Arist. 1 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Arist. 1 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1270.6" n="b" level="4"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">contemporary</hi>, <hi rend="ital">coeval;</hi> and <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a contemporary</hi>, without definite reference to equality in age; <cit><quote lang="la">Livius (Andronicus) Ennio aequalis fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Philistus aequalis illorum temporum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div 1, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 40</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1270.7" n="c" level="4"> In the comic poets, esp. in connection with amicus, <hi rend="ital">of the same age</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">O amice salve mi atque aequalis, ut vales?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 1, 8</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 3, 4, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne cuiquam suorum aequalium supplex siet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:6:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 5, 6, 47</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1270.8" n="2" level="3"> Of things, <hi rend="ital">coexal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">coexistent</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">Deiotari benevolentia in populum Romanum est ipsius aequalis aetati,</quote> <trans><tr>is as old as himself</tr>, <tr>has grown up with him</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:11:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 11, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in memoriam notam et aequalem incurro,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>which belongs to our time</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=69" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 69</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 2</bibl>: ne istud Juppiter sierit urbem in aeternum conditam fragili huic et mortali corpori aequalem esse, i. e. <hi rend="ital">should exist for an equally short time</hi>, Liv 28, 28.—Rarely with <hi rend="ital">cum</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequali tecum pubesceret aevo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:491" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 491</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fuit cum ea cupressus aequalis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:236" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 44, 86, § 236</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1270.9" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">That can be compared in respect to size</hi> or <hi rend="ital">form; of equal size</hi>, <hi rend="ital">looking alike</hi>, <hi rend="ital">resembling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">similar</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">florentes aequali corpore Nymphae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> Cir. 435</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">chorus aequalis Dryadum,</quote> <trans><tr>a chorus of Dryads alike</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:460" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 4, 460</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1270.10" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Uniform</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unvarying;</hi> virtutes sunt inter se aequales et pares, Cic. de Or, 1, 18; <cit><quote lang="la">3, 14, 55: nil aequale homini fuit illi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">imber lentior aequaliorque,</quote> <trans><tr>and more uniform</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequali ictu freta scindere, Ov M. 11, 463: Euphranor in quocumque genere excellens ac sibi aequalis,</quote> <trans><tr>always equal to himself</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 11, 37, § 128</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">opus aequali quadam mediocritate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:54" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 54</bibl></cit>.—Hence, but rarely, = aequus, of place, <hi rend="ital">equal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uniform</hi>, <hi rend="ital">level</hi>, <hi rend="ital">smooth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even</hi>, <hi rend="ital">plain</hi>, both in a horizontal and ascending direction: <cit><quote lang="la">loca,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gentes esse sine naribus aequali totius oris planitie,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:187" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 30, 35, § 187</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mons aequali dorso continuus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 47</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi> prob. not used.—* <hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequalissima porticus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 17</bibl></cit>.— <hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aequālĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">equally</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uniformly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in the same manner</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 70</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:16:58" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 16, 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:19:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 19, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,015:24:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Par. 24, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,033:6:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Sap. 6, 8</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 21</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> not used.</sense></entryFree>
aequalitas: <entryFree id="n1271" type="main" key="aequa_li^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequālĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aequalis</etym>, <sense id="n1271.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">equality</hi>, <hi rend="ital">similarity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uniformity</hi> (syn.: similitudo, planities, aequitas). </sense><sense id="n1271.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">similitudo aequalitasque verborum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Part. Or 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fraterna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:chapter=12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Lig. 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,008:8:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Cor. 8, 13</bibl>, 14.—</sense><sense id="n1271.2" n="II" level="1"> In Tac. freq. of <hi rend="ital">political equality</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">i)sotimi/a</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes exutā aequalitate jussa principis aspectare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 74</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 26</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 2, 38</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1271.3" n="III" level="1"> Of <hi rend="ital">equality in age</hi> (cf. aequalis, II.): et aequalitas vestra et pares honorum gradus, Cic <bibl default="NO"><author>Brut.</author> 42</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1271.4" n="IV" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The equality</hi>, <hi rend="ital">evenness of a place</hi>: maris, i. e. mare tranquillum, <hi rend="ital">a calm</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">galh/nh</foreign>, Sen, Ep. 53: <cit><quote lang="la">(Oesypum) carnes excrescentes ad aequalitatem reducit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:113" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 30, 13, 39, § 113</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aequaliter: <entryFree id="n1272" type="main" key="aequa_li^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequālĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. aequalis <sense id="n1272.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aequamen: <entryFree id="n1273" type="hapax" key="aequa_men"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequāmen</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>aequo</etym>, <sense id="n1273.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an instrument for levelling</hi> or <hi rend="ital">smoothing</hi>, as explanation of amussis, and syn. to levamentum, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 9, 18</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequamentum: <entryFree id="n1274" type="hapax" key="aequa_mentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequāmentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1274.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an equalling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">requiting</hi>, translation of hostimentum, <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 3, 26</bibl></sense></entryFree>
aequana: <entryFree id="n1275" type="main" key="Aequa_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aequāna</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (sc. juga), <sense id="n1275.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mountain range near Sorrentum</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:5:466" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 5, 466</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequanimis: <entryFree id="n1276" type="gloss" key="aequa^ni^mis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequănĭmis</orth> <etym>aequus-animus</etym>, <pos>adj.</pos> in Vet. Onomast. = <foreign lang="greek">eu)gnw=mwn</foreign>, <sense id="n1276.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">kind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mild. —Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aequănĭmĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">calmly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with equanimity</hi> (only in later Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sulp.</author> Dial. 1, 14</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 19, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Patient. 8 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
aequanimitas: <entryFree id="n1277" type="main" key="aequa^ni^mi^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequănĭmĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aequanimis</etym> (rare for aequus animus). <sense id="n1277.0" n="I" level="1"> Before the class. per., <hi rend="ital">favor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">good-will</hi> (favor et propitius animus, Don. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:prol. 24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. prol. 24</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">bonitas vestra atque aequanimitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:prol. 34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. prol. 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:prol. 24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. prol. 24</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1277.1" n="II" level="1"> In the post-Aug. per., <hi rend="ital">calmness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">patience</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equanimity</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:123" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 12, 31, § 123</bibl>: patien <pb n="57" /> <cb n="AEQU" /> tia est malorum cum aequanimitate perlatio, <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 5, 22, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequanimiter: <entryFree id="n1278" type="main" key="aequa^ni^mi^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequănĭmĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v aequanimis.</entryFree>
aequanimus: <entryFree id="n1279" type="main" key="aequa^ni^mus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequănĭmus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype> <etym>aequus-animus</etym>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1279.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">even-tempered</hi>, <hi rend="ital">patient</hi>, <hi rend="ital">composed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">calm</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequanimus fiam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Sept. Sap. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nulla fuit res parva umquam aequanimis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Idyll. 3, 9</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
aequatio: <entryFree id="n1280" type="main" key="aequa_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aequo</etym>, <sense id="n1280.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an equalizing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equal distribution</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gratiae dignitatis suffragiorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 23</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 31</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">bonorum,</quote> <trans><tr>community of goods</tr>, <tr>communism</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:21:73" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 21, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">juris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:4 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 4 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
aequatormonetae: <entryFree id="n1281" type="gloss" key="aequa_tor mo^ne_tae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequātor mŏnētae</orth>, <sense id="n1281.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in the coining of money</hi>, <hi rend="ital">examines the equality of its weight</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an assizer</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3228</bibl></sense></entryFree>
aequatus: <entryFree id="n1282" type="main" key="aequa_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of aequo.</entryFree>
aeque: <entryFree id="n1283" type="main" key="aeque_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. aequus <sense id="n1283.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aequi: <entryFree id="n1284" type="main" key="Aequi"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aequi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <sense id="n1284.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A warlike people of ancient Italy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in the neighborhood of the Latins and Volsci</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on both sides of the Anio</hi>, whose cities were Alba, Tibur, Praeneste, Carseoli, etc. They were almost entirely destroyed by the dictator Cincinnatus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:30 al" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 30 al.</bibl>; cf. Nieb. Röm. Gesch. 1, 81.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1284.1" n="II. A." level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aequĭ-cus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Æquian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellum,</quote> <trans><tr>with the Æqui</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 4, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes">10, 1, 7</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1284.2" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ae-quīcŭlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Æquian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:747" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 747</bibl></cit> rura, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:371" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 371</bibl>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aequīcŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">one of the Æqui</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">asper,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:93" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 93</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vit.:1" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vit. 1</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n1284.3" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aequīcūlāni</orth> = Aequiculi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 12, 17, § 107</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequicrurius: <entryFree id="n1285" type="hapax" key="aequi^cru_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭcrūrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequoscrus</etym> = <foreign lang="greek">i)soskelh/s</foreign>, <sense id="n1285.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of equal legs</hi>, <hi rend="ital">isosceles</hi>, in geom. of the triangle, <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 6, p. 230</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequicus: <entryFree id="n1286" type="main" key="Aequi^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aequĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. Aequi.</entryFree>
aequidiale: <entryFree id="n1287" type="gloss" key="aequi^dia_le"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭdiāle</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>aequus-dies</etym>, old form for aequinoctiale, <sense id="n1287.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the equinox</hi>: “aequidiale apud antiquos dictum est, quod nunc dicimus aequinoctiale, quia nox diei potius quam dies nocti annumerari debet. Graeci quoque in hoc consentiunt, <foreign lang="greek">i)shmeri/an</foreign>, id est aequidiale, dicentes,” Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=24" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 24</bibl> Müli.</sense></entryFree>
aequidianus: <entryFree id="n1288" type="hapax" key="aequi^di^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭdĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequidiale</etym>, i. q. aequinoctialis, <sense id="n1288.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">equinoctial</hi>: exortus, App. de Mundo, p 62 (270 ed. min. Hildebr.).</sense></entryFree>
aequidici: <entryFree id="n1289" type="main" key="aequi^di^ci"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭdĭci</orth> (sc. versus) [aequus-dico], <sense id="n1289.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">verses containing corresponding words</hi> or <hi rend="ital">expressions</hi> (<foreign lang="greek">a)ntiqe/tous</foreign>), as (<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 2, 18</bibl>): alba ligustra cadunt, vaccinia nigra leguntur: “Albis enim nigra opposuit, ligustris autem vaccinia attribuit, et cadentibus legenda assignavit,” <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 498</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
aequidistans: <entryFree id="n1290" type="main" key="aequi^distans"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭdistans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequusdisto</etym>. In math. <sense id="n1290.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">parallel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equidistant</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">circuli,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 3, p. 276</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aequiformis: <entryFree id="n1291" type="main" key="aequi^formis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭformis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequus-forma</etym>, <sense id="n1291.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">uniform</hi>: versus, <hi rend="ital">composed of single</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unconnected words</hi>, as (<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:171" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 171</bibl>): urbe fuit media Laurentis regia Pici, where no two successive words are connected, Diom. p 498 P.</sense></entryFree>
aequilanx: <entryFree id="n1292" type="main" key="aequi^lanx"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭlanx</orth>, <itype>lancis</itype> <etym>aequus-lanx</etym>, <sense id="n1292.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">with equal scale</hi>: trutina aequilance ponderare, Fulg. Cont. Verg.</sense></entryFree>
aequilatatio: <entryFree id="n1293" type="hapax" key="aequi^la_ta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭlātātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aequus-latus</etym>, <sense id="n1293.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the equal distance of two parallel lines from each other</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:9:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 9, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequilateralis: <entryFree id="n1294" type="hapax" key="aequi^la^te^ra_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭlătĕrālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1294.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">equilateral</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Censor.</author> de D. Nat. 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequilaterus: <entryFree id="n1295" type="main" key="aequi^la^te^rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭlătĕrus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>. In math. <sense id="n1295.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">equilateral;</hi> triangulus, <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 6, p. 229</bibl> and 230.</sense></entryFree>
aequilatus: <entryFree id="n1296" type="hapax" key="aequi^la^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭlătus</orth>, <itype>ĕris</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>. In math. <sense id="n1296.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">equilateral</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">regula,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Idyll. 11, 50</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aequilavium: <entryFree id="n1297" type="gloss" key="aequi^la^vi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭlăvĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>aequus-lavo</etym>, <sense id="n1297.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a half of the whole</hi>, said of wool, when <hi rend="ital">half</hi> of the weight remains after <hi rend="ital">washing</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=24" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 24</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
aequilibratus: <entryFree id="n1298" type="hapax" key="aequi^li_bra_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭlībrātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequuslibra</etym>, = aequilibris, Tert. c. Hermog. 41.</entryFree>
aequilibris: <entryFree id="n1299" type="hapax" key="aequi^li_bris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭlībris</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1299.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">in perfect equilibrium</hi> or <hi rend="ital">equipoise</hi>, <hi rend="ital">level</hi>, <hi rend="ital">horizontal</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 5, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequilibritas: <entryFree id="n1300" type="hapax" key="aequi^li_bri^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭlībrĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aequilibris</etym> (a word coined by Cic. as a transl. of the Epicurean <foreign lang="greek">isonomi/a</foreign>), <sense id="n1300.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the equal distribution of the powers of nature</hi>: confugis ad aequilibritatem;<cb n="AEQU" />  sic enim <foreign lang="greek">i)snomi/an</foreign>, si placet, appellemus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:39:109" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 39, 109</bibl> (cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 19, 50, 1</bibl>: <foreign lang="greek">i)sonomi/an</foreign> appellat Epicurus, id est, aequabilem tributionem)</sense></entryFree>
aequilibrium: <entryFree id="n1301" type="main" key="aequi^li_bri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭlībrĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>aequilibris</etym>, <sense id="n1301.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a level</hi> or <hi rend="ital">horizontal position</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equilibrium</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaedam ligna ad medium submersa ad aequilibrium aquae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 3:25" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 3, 25</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:Arb. 5:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> Arb. 5, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1301.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a perfect equality</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rumpendi pariter membri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aequimaelium: <entryFree id="n1302" type="main" key="Aequi^maeli^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aequĭmaelĭum</orth> (better than <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aequĭmēl-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n1302.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the open space in Rome below the Capitol</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not far from the</hi> Carcer, <hi rend="ital">where had stood the house of the turbulent tribune of the people</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Sp. Mœlius</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who was slain by Ahala during the dictatorship of Cincinnatus</hi>, now in the <hi rend="ital">Via di Marforio</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aequimaelium, quod aequata Maeli (Meli) domus publico, quod regnum occupare voluit is,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=157" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 157</bibl></cit> Müll.; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:16:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 16, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:28:3" default="NO" valid="yes">38, 28, 3</bibl>. In Cicero's time a lamb-market seems to have been there, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div 2, 17, 39</bibl>. Cf. on this locality, Nieb. Röm. Gesch. 2, 474; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 28</bibl>; and Becker's Antiq. 1, p. 485 sq.</sense></entryFree>
