aequimanus: <entryFree id="n1303" type="main" key="aequi^ma^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭmănus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequusmanus</etym>, <sense id="n1303.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">who can use both hands equally well</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ambidextrous</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">a)mfide/cios</foreign>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Idyll. 12</bibl>; Beda Orth. 2329 P.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">of equal skill in two departments</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in two pursuits</hi>: <foreign lang="greek">peride/cios</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Ep. 9:101" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> Ep. 9, 101</bibl> (110).</sense></entryFree>
aequinoctialis: <entryFree id="n1304" type="main" key="aequi^nocti^a_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭnoctĭālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequinoctium</etym>, <sense id="n1304.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to the equinox</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">the time of equal day and night</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equinoctial</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">circulus,</quote> <trans><tr>the equator</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 9:section=24" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 9, § 24</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">aestus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 3:28" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 3, 28</bibl></cit> (cf. aequinoctium <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>). horae, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2</bibl>. 97. 99, § <cit><quote lang="la">216: meridies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:6:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 6, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aequinoctium: <entryFree id="n1305" type="main" key="aequi^nocti^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭnoctĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>aequus-nox</etym>, <sense id="n1305.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the time of equal days and nights</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the equinox</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:28:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 28, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 36</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 23</bibl>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=8" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 8</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">autumnale, Liv 31, 47: vernum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:33:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 33, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestus duobus aequinoctiis maxime tumentes et autumnali amplius quam verno, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:215" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 97, 99, § 215</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aequipar: <entryFree id="n1306" type="main" key="aequi^par"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭpar</orth>, <itype>ăris</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequus-par</etym>, <sense id="n1306.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">perfectly alike</hi> or <hi rend="ital">equal</hi>, only in later writers, e. g. <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Idyll. 12</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequiparabilis: <entryFree id="n1307" type="main" key="aequi^pa^ra_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭpărābĭlis</orth> (better, <orth extent="full" lang="la">aequipĕr-</orth>), <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequiparo</etym>, <sense id="n1307.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that may be compared</hi>, <hi rend="ital">comparable</hi> (perh only in Plaut.); with <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: diis aequiperabile, Curc. 1, 3, 11.—With <hi rend="ital">cum</hi>, Trin. 2, 4, 65 (also in <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 304</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
aequiparantia: <entryFree id="n1308" type="main" key="aequi^pa^ranti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭpărantĭa</orth> (better, <orth extent="full" lang="la">aequiper-</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1308.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a comparison</hi> (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Val. 16</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequiparatio: <entryFree id="n1309" type="main" key="aequi^pa^ra_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭpărātĭo</orth> (better, <orth extent="full" lang="la">aequīper-</orth>). <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1309.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an equalizing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a comparison</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequiperatio et parilitas virtutum inter se consimilium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:14:3" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 14, 3</bibl></cit>: rex de aequiperatione aestimanda (<hi rend="ital">whether his army could be put on an equality with</hi>) quaesierat, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:5:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 5, 5, 7</bibl></sense></entryFree>
aequiparo: <entryFree id="n1310" type="main" key="aequi^pa^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭpăro</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭpĕr-</orth>; cf. Dietrich in Zeitschr. für vergl. Sprachf. 1, p. 550), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> and <gen>n.</gen> <etym>aequipar</etym>. <sense id="n1310.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to put a thing on an equality with another thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to compare</hi>, <hi rend="ital">liken;</hi> with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cum</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">suas virtutes ad tuas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:1:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 1, 1, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequiperata cum P fratre gloria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:14:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 14, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Jovis Solisque equis dictatorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 23</bibl></cit>: Hadrianus Numae aequiperandus, Frontin. Princ. Hist. p. 317 Rom.—</sense><sense id="n1310.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to place one's self on an equality with another in worth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to become equal to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to equal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">come up to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attain to</hi> (cf. aequo and adaequo); constr. with <case>dat.</case>, but more frequently with <case>acc.</case>, and <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1310.2" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: nam si qui, quae eventura sunt, provideant, aequiperent Jovi, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:14:1:34" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 14, 1, 34</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1310.3" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: nemo est qui factis me aequiperare queat, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:17:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 17, 49</bibl> (Epigr. 8, p. 162 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">urbem dignitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Them. 6, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,007:11:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Alc. 11, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 55</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">voce magistrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:5:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 5, 48</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:2:5:44" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 2, 5, 44</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1310.4" n="(g)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 307, 11</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequipedus: <entryFree id="n1311" type="main" key="aequi^pe^dus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭpĕdus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">aequipēs</orth>, <itype>ĕdis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequus-pes</etym>, <sense id="n1311.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">having equal feet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">isosceles</hi> (of a triangle). <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Dogm. Plat. 1, p. 5</bibl>, and <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 472</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
aequipero: <entryFree id="n1312" type="main" key="aequi^pe^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭpĕro</orth>, v. aequiparo.</entryFree>
aequipollens: <entryFree id="n1313" type="main" key="aequi^pollens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭpollens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequus-polleo</etym>, <sense id="n1313.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of equal value</hi> or <hi rend="ital">significance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equivalent</hi>,<cb n="AEQU" />  a dialectic word, used several times in <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> de Dogm. Plat. 3, p. 36</bibl> and 39.</sense></entryFree>
aequipondium: <entryFree id="n1314" type="hapax" key="aequi^pondi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭpondĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>aequus-pon dus</etym>, <sense id="n1314.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an equal weight</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a counterpoise</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequitas: <entryFree id="n1315" type="main" key="aequi^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aequus</etym>, <sense id="n1315.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the quality of being</hi> aequus (syn.: aequalitas, jus, justitia, fas). </sense><sense id="n1315.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The uniform relation of one thing to others</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equality</hi>, <hi rend="ital">conformity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">symmetry;</hi> portionum aequitate turbatā, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 3:10" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 3, 10</bibl>: commoditas et aequitas (<hi rend="ital">proportion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">symmetry</hi>) membrorum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:79" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 79</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1315.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1315.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Just</hi> or <hi rend="ital">equitable conduct toward others</hi>, <hi rend="ital">justice</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fairness</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">e)piei/keia</foreign> (governed by benevolence, while justitia yields to another only what is strictly due): <cit><quote lang="la">pro aequitate contra jus dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:56:240" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 56, 240</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">belli aequitas sanctissime fetiali jure perscripta est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:11:36" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 11, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a verbis recedere et aequitate uti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Caecin. 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Arist. 2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Arist. 2, 2</bibl> Br.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Milt. 2</bibl>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:15" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 15</bibl>. But it is sometimes used for justitia: <cit><quote lang="la">summa bonitas et aequitas causae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 16, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam habet aequitatem, ut agrum qui nullum habuit, habeat?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:22" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 22 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—Eccl., <hi rend="ital">righteousness</hi>, </sense><sense id="n1315.4" n="(a)" level="5"> of men, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:9:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 9, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,047:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Mal. 2, 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1315.5" n="(b)" level="5"> Of God, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:9:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 9, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:17:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 17, 31</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1315.6" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A quiet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tranquil state of mind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">evenness of temper</hi>, <hi rend="ital">moderation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">calmness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tranquillity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">repose</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equanimity;</hi> often with animus: <cit><quote lang="la">quis hanc animi maximi aequitatem in ipsā morte laudaret, si? etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:40:97" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 40, 97</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">novi moderationem animi tui et aequitatem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Sen. 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 1, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut animi aequitate plebem contineant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Caes.</author> B. G 6, 22</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Thras. 4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Thras. 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi pax evenerat aequitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 9:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 9, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aequiter: <entryFree id="n1316" type="main" key="aequi^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. aequus <sense id="n1316.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aequiternus: <entryFree id="n1317" type="main" key="aequi^ternus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭternus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequeaeternus</etym>, <sense id="n1317.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">equally eternal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">coeternal</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud. Mam.</author> Anim. 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 8, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequivaleo: <entryFree id="n1318" type="hapax" key="aequi^va^le^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭ-vălĕo</orth>, <itype>ēre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>aequus</etym>, <sense id="n1318.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to have equal power</hi>, <hi rend="ital">be equivalent</hi>, Auct. Carm. de Phil. 6.</sense></entryFree>
aequivocus: <entryFree id="n1319" type="main" key="aequi^vo^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭvŏcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequus-voco</etym>; <sense id="n1319.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">in gram.: verba aequivoca,</quote> <trans><tr>of like significations</tr>, <tr>ambiguous</tr>, <tr>equivocal</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 2, 26</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:Cap 4:97" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> Cap 4, 97</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aequo: <entryFree id="n1320" type="main" key="aequo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> and <gen>n.</gen> <etym>aequus</etym>. <sense id="n1320.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to make one thing equal to another;</hi> constr. with <hi rend="ital">cum</hi> and (in gen. in the histt.) with <case>dat.</case>, and with <hi rend="ital">cop. conj.</hi> (cf. adaequo). </sense><sense id="n1320.1" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">cum</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">inventum est temperamentum, quo tenuiores cum principibus aequari se putarent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 3, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum suas quisque opes cum potentissimis aequari videat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numerum (corporum) cum navibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:193" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 193</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1320.2" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Insedabiliter sitis arida, corpora mersans, Aequabat multum parvis umoribus imbrem,</quote> <trans><tr>an unquenchable</tr>, <tr>burning thirst ... made the most copious stream seem to them as only a few drops</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1176" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1176</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per somnum vinumque dies noctibus aequare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequavit togatus armati gloriam collegae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:10:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 10, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cujus magnitudini semper animum aequavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:21:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 33, 21, 3</bibl></cit> (but in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:20:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 20, 8</bibl>, facta dictis aequando, dictis is <case>abl.</case>; v Weissenb. ad h. l.); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:127" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 127</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">aequare solo templum,</quote> <trans><tr>to level with the ground</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 51</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so domum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:7:20" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 3, 7, 20</bibl></cit>, and Aur. Vict. Vir. lllustr. 17. 5; <cit><quote lang="la">and in an extended sense: Scipio Numantiam excisam aequavit solo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:4" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 4</bibl></cit>.—Hence, trop.: solo aequandae sunt dictaturae consulatusque, <hi rend="ital">entirely abolished</hi>, Liv 6, 18.—</sense><sense id="n1320.3" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">cop. conj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Curios aequare Fabriciosque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Caes. 18:2" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Caes. 18, 2</bibl></cit>. —<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">si protinus illum Aequāsset nocti ludum,</quote> <trans><tr>had played through the whole night</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:338" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 338</bibl></cit>.—Hence also, </sense><sense id="n1320.4" n="B" level="2"> In comparison, <hi rend="ital">to place a thing on an equality with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to compare.;</hi> in Cic. with <hi rend="ital">cum;</hi> later with <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequare et conferre scelera alicujus cum aliis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne aequaveritis Hannibali Philippum, ne Carthaginiensibus Macedonas: Pyrrho certe aequabitis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Deum homini non aequabo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 32, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quis in nubibus aequabitur Domino,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:88:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Psa. 88, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1320.5" n="C" level="2"> Of places, <hi rend="ital">to make level</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">smooth</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequata agri planities,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 48</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and trop.: aequato discrimine,</quote> <trans><tr>at an equal distance</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:690" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 690</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequato omnium periculo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequato Marte,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequato jure omnium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 3</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: ibant aequati numero, <pb n="58" /> <cb n="AEQU" /> <hi rend="ital">divided into equal parts</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:698" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 698</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">foedera regum Vel Gabiis vel cum rigidis aequata Sabinis, i. e. aequis legibus icta,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 25</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">si foedus est, si societas aequatio juris est ... cur non omnia aequantur?</quote> <trans><tr>placed in the same circumstances?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1320.6" n="D" level="2"> T. t. </sense><sense id="n1320.7" n="1" level="3"> Aequare frontem, milit. t., <hi rend="ital">to make an equal front</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 38</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequatis frontibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:4:1:102" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 4, 1, 102</bibl></cit>; v. frons.—</sense><sense id="n1320.8" n="2" level="3"> Aequare sortes, <hi rend="ital">to see that the lots are equal in number to those who draw</hi>, <hi rend="ital">of the same material</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and each with a different name.</hi> The classical passage for this phrase is <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:6:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 2, 6, 35</bibl>: conicite sortes: uxor, aequa (sc. eas); v. the preceding verses. So <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,062:Or. Corn. 1, p. 449" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fragm. Or. Corn. 1, p. 449</bibl> Orell.: dum sitella defertur, dum aequantur sortes, dum sortitio fit, etc.—</sense><sense id="n1320.9" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr.</hi> or <hi rend="ital">act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to become equal to one</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to equal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">come up to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attain to</hi> (mostly in the histt.); constr. with <case>dat.</case>, but oftener with <case>acc.</case> (cf. adaequo and aequipero, and Zumpt, § <cit><quote lang="la">389, 1): qui jam illis fere aequārunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:1:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 1, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ea arte aequāsset superiores reges, ni, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 53</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">cursu equum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 31, 35</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">for which Curtius: cursum alicujus, 4, 1: gloriam alicujus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:55" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eam picturam imitati sunt multi, aequavit nemo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:126" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 11, 40, § 126</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:456" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 456</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: sagitta aequans ventos, <hi rend="ital">like the winds</hi> in swiftness, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:248" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 248</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">valet nondum munia comparis Aequare (juvenca),</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>cannot yet draw even with her mate</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 5, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aequor: <entryFree id="n1321" type="main" key="aequor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequor</orth>, <itype>ŏris</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>aequus</etym>. <sense id="n1321.0" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">an even</hi>, <hi rend="ital">level surface</hi> (ante-Aug. <usg type="style">poet.</usg>; only once in Cic. and once in Sallust): speculorum aequor, <hi rend="ital">a plane surface</hi>, as of a mirror, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 106</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:291" default="NO" valid="yes">291</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in summo aequore saxi,</quote> <trans><tr>upon the polished</tr>, <tr>smooth marble surface</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:905" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 905</bibl></cit>: camporum patentium aequora, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:42" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 42</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">campi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:781" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 781</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and without campus: Daren ardens agit aequore toto,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 456</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">at prius ignotum ferro quam scindimus aequor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 1, 50</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 97</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">of the desert,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 105</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">immensum spatiis confecimus aequor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 541</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">primus in aequore pulvis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:61" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 61</bibl></cit>; and once of the heavens: aequora caeli Sensimus sonere, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 505, 8</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 139 Rib.).—</sense><sense id="n1321.1" n="II" level="1"> Esp., <hi rend="ital">the even surface of the sea in its quiet state</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the calm. smooth sea</hi> (“aequor mare appellatum, quod aequatum, cum commotum vento non est,” <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=23" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 23</bibl> Müll.: quid tam planum videtur quam mare? ex quo etiam aequor illud poëtae vocant, Cic. Ac. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 65, 2</bibl> (cf. <foreign lang="greek">po/ntou pla/c</foreign>, Pind. P. 1, 24).— Also, in gen., <hi rend="ital">the sea</hi>, even when agitated by storms, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:719" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 719</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">turbantibus aequora ventis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">silvaeque et saeva quiērant aequora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:523" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 523</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">per undosum aequor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 313</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">contracta pisces aequora sentiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:1:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 1, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">juventus Infecit aequor sanguine Punico,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 6, 34</bibl></cit> al.—Sometimes pleonast. with mare or pontus: <cit><quote lang="la">vastum maris aequor arandum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:780" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 780</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tellus et aequora ponti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:469" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 1, 469</bibl></cit>.—Of the surface of the Tiber, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 89</bibl> and 96 (so, mare of the Timavus, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 246</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and unda of rivers, as of the Simoïs,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 618</bibl></cit>).—In prose writers after the Aug. per.: <cit><quote lang="la">placidum aequor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">penetrare aequora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:9:1:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 9, 1, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:7" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 24, § 76</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:2" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 2</bibl>. Once even in Sallust: aequore et terrā, Sall. Fragm. ap. Don. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 1, 13</bibl> (p. 390, n. 81 Kritz.) dub.</sense></entryFree>
aequoreus: <entryFree id="n1322" type="main" key="aequo^re^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequŏrĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aequor</etym>, <sense id="n1322.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the sea</hi> (only <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">rex,</quote> <trans><tr>Neptune</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:604" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 604</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Britanni,</quote> <trans><tr>the Britons surrounded by the sea</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:15:753" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 753</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">genus,</quote> <trans><tr>the ocean kind</tr>, <tr>fish</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:243" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 243</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aquae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:51 al" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 10, 51 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
aequus: <entryFree id="n1323" type="main" key="aequus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aequus</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">aecus</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0116,001:32" default="NO"><author>Pac.</author> 32</bibl> Rib.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1023" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1023</bibl> Lachm. and Munro; AIQVOS, S. C. de Bacch. 1. 26), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>formerly referred to <foreign lang="greek">*e*i*k*w, e)/oika</foreign>, but Pott connects it with Sanscr. ēka = one, as if properly, <hi rend="ital">one and uniform;</hi> others consider it as akin to aemulor, q. v.</etym>. <sense id="n1323.0" n="I. A." level="1"> Of place, <hi rend="ital">that extends</hi> or <hi rend="ital">lies in a horizontal direction</hi>, <hi rend="ital">plain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even</hi>, <hi rend="ital">level</hi>, <hi rend="ital">flat</hi> (esp. freq. in the strategic descriptions of the histt.; <cit><quote lang="la">syn.: planus, aequalis, aequabilis, par, similis, justus): locus ad libellam aequus,</quote> <trans><tr>level</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:6" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 6 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequus et planus locus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Caec. 17 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aequum locum se demittere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 28</bibl></cit>: legio, quae <cb n="AEQU" /> paulo aequiore loco constiterat, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 51</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aequum locum deducere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 42</bibl></cit> (cf. in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ei)s to\ i)/sov katabai/nein</foreign>, Xen. Anab. 4, 6, 18).—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">sive loquitur ex inferiore loco sive aequo sive ex superiore,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>before the judges</tr>, <tr>sitting on raised seats</tr>, <tr>or in the Senate</tr>, <tr>or in the assembly of the people from the rostra</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:6:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 6, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meos multos et ex superiore et ex aequo loco sermones habitos cum tuā summā laude,</quote> <trans><tr>from the tribune</tr>, <tr>and on private matters</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 8</bibl></cit>.—In the histt., sometimes <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aequum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, with a <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">level ground</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a plain</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">facilem in aequo campi victoriam fore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut primum agmen aequo, ceteri per acclive jugum insurgerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aequum digredi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aequo obstare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 4, 23</bibl>.—Also, <hi rend="ital">an eminence</hi>, if it rises without inequalities: <cit><quote lang="la">dum Romanae cohortes in aequum eniterentur,</quote> <trans><tr>up the slope</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 80</bibl></cit>.—As a level place is more favorable for military operations than an uneven one, aequus has the signif., </sense><sense id="n1323.1" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Favorable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">convenient</hi>, <hi rend="ital">advantageous</hi> (as its opp., iniquus, uneven, has that of unfavorable, etc.). </sense><sense id="n1323.2" n="1" level="3"> Of place: <cit><quote lang="la">locum se aequum ad dimicandum dedisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etsi non aequum locum videbat suis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 5, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non hic silvas nec paludes, sed aequis locis aequos deos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 68</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n1323.3" n="2" level="3"> Of time: judicium aequiore tempore fieri oportere, <hi rend="ital">more propitious</hi>, Cic. Corn. Fragm. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0803,001:page=72" default="NO"><author>Ascon.</author> p. 72</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">et tempore et loco aequo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempore aequo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:35" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 35</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1323.4" n="3" level="3"> In gen., of persons or things (freq. and class.), <hi rend="ital">favorable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">kind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">friendly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">benevolent</hi>, etc.; constr. <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> with <case>dat.</case>, or <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <case>acc.</case> (in poets <hi rend="ital">in</hi> with <case>abl.</case>). </sense><sense id="n1323.5" n="(a)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">consequeris, ut eos ipsos, quos contra statuas, aequos placatosque dimittas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:10:34" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 10, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nobilitate inimica, non aequo senatu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 3 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meis aequissimis utuntur auribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oculis aspicere aequis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:372" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 372</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">O dominum aequum et bonum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:53" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">boni et aequi et faciles domini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:29" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tib. 29</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1323.6" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequa Venus Teucris, Pallas iniqua fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:1:2:6" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 1, 2, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:310" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. A. 2, 310</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1323.7" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quis hoc statuit, quod aequum sit in Quintium, id iniquum esse in Maevium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 14</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1323.8" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">victor erat quamvis, aequus in hoste fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:18:28" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 18, 28</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1323.9" n="4" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">aequus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a friend</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego ut me tibi amicissimum esse et aequi et iniqui intellegant, curabo,</quote> <trans><tr>both friends and enemies</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 3, 6 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequis iniquisque persuasum erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 45</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n1323.10" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">That is equal to another in any quality</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">like;</hi> and of things divided into two equal parts, <hi rend="ital">a half</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequo censu censeri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">partīs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 125</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Orig. 19:1" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Orig. 19, 1</bibl>; and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:30:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 30, 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequa erit mensura sagorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:26:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Exod. 26, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pondera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:19:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Lev. 19, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">portio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2</bibl></cit> Mach. 8, 30: <cit><quote lang="la">aequa dementia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:705 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 705 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequā manu discedere,</quote> <trans><tr>to come off with equal advantage</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 39</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">aequo Marte pugnare,</quote> <trans><tr>with equal success</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:15:29" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 15, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:2:48 al" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 2, 48 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbs erat in summo nubibus aequa jugo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:4:7:24" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 4, 7, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequum vulnus utrique tulit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:719" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 9, 719</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:7:803" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 803</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequales urebant pectora flammae): sequiturque patrem non passibus aequis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:724" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 724</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pars aequa mundi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 19, 17, § 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">utinam esset mihi pars aequa amoris tecum, i. e. aeque vicissim amaremus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non tertiam portionem, verum aequam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:5 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 1, 1, § 5 al.</bibl></cit>—Hence the adverbial phrases, </sense><sense id="n1323.11" n="1" level="3"> Ex aequo, <hi rend="ital">in like manner</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in an equal degree</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equally</hi> ( = <foreign lang="greek">e)c i)/sou</foreign>, Hdt., Dem.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:854" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 854</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dixit et ex aequo donis formaque probata, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:16:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 16, 87</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">20, 123</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:10:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 1, 10, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:682" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. A. 2, 682</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 3, 145</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 62</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 37</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversarum rerum ex aequo socii sunt (Fosi Cheruscis), cum in secundis minores fuissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 36 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1323.12" n="2" level="3"> In aequo esse or stare, <hi rend="ital">to be equal</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui cogit mori nolentem, in aequo est, quique properantem impedit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Phoen. 98" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Phoen. 98</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut naturam oderint, quod infra deos sumus, quod non in aequo illis stetimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 2:29" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ben. 2, 29</bibl></cit>: in aequo ponere aliquem alicui, <hi rend="ital">to make equal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to put on an equality</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to compare</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aequo eum (Philopoemenem) summis imperatoribus posuerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 50 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1323.13" n="B" level="2"> Morally. </sense><sense id="n1323.14" n="1" level="3"> Of <cb n="AEQU" /> persons, <hi rend="ital">fair</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equitable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">impartial in conduct toward others</hi> (diff. from justus, just; v. aequitas, II.); constr. <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, with <hi rend="ital">dat.;</hi> more rarely with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">praetor aequus et sapiens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 65</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 5, 59</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequissimus aestimator et judex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 3, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praebere se aequum alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">absentium aequi, praesentibus mobiles,</quote> <trans><tr>benevolent toward</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 36</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1323.15" n="2" level="3"> Of things, <hi rend="ital">fair</hi>, <hi rend="ital">right</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equitable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">reasonable</hi>: ITA. SENATVS. AIQVOM. CENSVIT., S. C. de Bach. 1. 26: et aecum et rectum est, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 261, 13</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 81 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">aequa et honesta postulatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod justum est et aequum, servis praestate,</quote> <trans><tr>just and fair</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Col. 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">postulo primum id, quod aequissimum est, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequa lex et omnibus utilis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:chapter=27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Balb. 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequissimis legibus monere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Caes. 9:5" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Caes. 9, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequae conditiones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:25" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 25</bibl></cit>; see Fischer, Gr. II. 611.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1323.16" n="3" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">ae-quum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">what is fair</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equitable</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">just; fairness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equity</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">justice</hi>, etc.: jus atque aequum, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 399, 10</bibl> (Trag. v. 224 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">utilitas justi prope mater et aequi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:3:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 3, 98</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequi studium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Caes. 24:6" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Caes. 24, 6</bibl></cit>.—Often with comparatives, <hi rend="ital">more than is right</hi>, <hi rend="ital">proper</hi>, <hi rend="ital">reasonable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lamentari amplius aequo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:966" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 966</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">injurias gravius aequo habere,</quote> <trans><tr>to feel too deeply</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">potus largius aequo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 215</bibl></cit>.—Hence, aequum est, <hi rend="ital">it is reasonable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">proper</hi>, <hi rend="ital">right</hi>, etc.; constr. with <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, in good prose also with <hi rend="ital">dat. pers.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">ut</hi>, Rudd. II. p. 235, n. 21: nos quiescere aequom est, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 382</bibl> P. (Trag. v. 199 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">quae liberum scire aequom est adulescentem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 2, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">significant Imbecillorum esse aecum misererier omnīs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1023" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1023</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non est aequum nos derelinquere verbum Dei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 6, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequius est mori quam auctoritatem imperii foedare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Epit. 12:7" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Epit. 12, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut peritis? Ut piscatorem aequomst (sc. perire), fame sitique speque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 2, 7</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">sicut aequum est homini de potestate deorum timide et pauca dicamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:16:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 16, 47</bibl></cit>.—In Plaut., with <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">plus vidissem quam med atque illo aequom foret,</quote> <trans><tr>would be becoming in me and him</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:3:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 3, 3, 84</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:prol. 47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. prol. 47</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1323.17" n="4" level="3"> Aequum as <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> very freq. with bonum = aequitas, <hi rend="ital">equitable conduct toward others</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fairness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equity</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">neque quidquam queo aequi bonique ab eo impetrare,</quote> <trans><tr>what is right and just</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:1:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 1, 1, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum de jure civili, cum de aequo et bono disputaretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex aequo et bono, non ex callido versutoque jure rem judicari oportere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Caecin. 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fit reus magis ex aequo bonoque quam ex jure gentium,</quote> <trans><tr>in accordance with justice and equity</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 35</bibl></cit>.— Also without <hi rend="ital">et</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">illi dolum malum, illi fidem bonam, illi aequum bonum tradiderunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:chapter=17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 17</bibl></cit>.—So also, aequius melius, <hi rend="ital">according to greater equily</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:chapter=17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Top. 17</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1323.18" n="C" level="2"> Of a state of mind, <hi rend="ital">even</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unruffled</hi>, <hi rend="ital">calm</hi>, <hi rend="ital">composed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tranquil</hi>, <hi rend="ital">patient</hi>, <hi rend="ital">enduring</hi> (cf. aequitas, II. B.); <cit><quote lang="la">esp. freq. with animus or mens: animus aequos optumum est aerumnae condimentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 3, 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">concedo et quod animus aequus est et quia necesse est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quodadest memento Componere aequus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:29:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 29, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tentantem majora, fere praesentibus aequum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 17, 24</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and so, aequam memento rebus in arduis Servare mentem, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 2, 3, 1</bibl></cit>.—Esp. freq. in the <hi rend="ital">adv. abl.</hi>: aequo (aequiore, aequissimo) animo, <hi rend="ital">with even mind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with equanimity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">patiently</hi>, <hi rend="ital">calmly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quietly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with forbearance</hi>: ego, nisi Bibulus adniteretur de triumpho, aequo animo essem, nunc vero <foreign lang="greek">ai)sxro\n siwpa=n</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">carere aequo animo aliquā re,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferre aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Dion. 6:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dion. 6, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Orig. 6:3" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Orig. 6, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">accipere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 3, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tolerare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo aequiore animo Germanicus celerem successionem operiretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:25" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">testem se in judiciis interrogari aequissimo animo patiebatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Aug. 56</bibl></cit>.—In eccl. Lat. = bono animo: <cit><quote lang="la">aequo animo esto,</quote> <trans><tr>be of good cheer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,013:21:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Reg. 21, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequo animo (aliquis) est? Psallat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Jacob. 5, 13</bibl></cit>.—Hence: aequi bonique facere aliquid, <hi rend="ital">to regard as fair and reasonable</hi> (prop., <hi rend="ital">a gen. of value</hi>, Roby, § 1191), <hi rend="ital">to put up with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">be content with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">submit to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">acquiesce in</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">istuc aequi bonique facio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:5:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 5, 40</bibl></cit>: tranquillissimus animus meus totum istuc aequi boni <pb n="59" /> <cb n="AEQU" /> facit, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 22 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequi istuc faciam,</quote> <trans><tr>it will be all the same to me</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:189" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 189</bibl></cit>.—So also: <cit><quote lang="la">aequi bonique dicere,</quote> <trans><tr>to propose any thing reasonable</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:4:3:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 4, 3, 32</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">aequē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">in like manner</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equally</hi>, <hi rend="ital">just as</hi> = ex aequo, pariter, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">i)/sws, o/moiws</foreign> (indicating the entire equality of two objects compared, while <hi rend="ital">similiter</hi> denotes only likeness): <cit><quote lang="la">eā (benevolentiā) non pariter omnes egemus ... honore et gloriā fortasse non aeque omnes egent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:8:30" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 8, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non possum ego non aut proxime atque ille aut etiam aeque laborare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 13, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">universa aeque eveniunt justo et impio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,030:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccl. 9, 2</bibl></cit>. </sense><sense id="n1323.19" n="1" level="3"> In the comic poets with <hi rend="ital">cum</hi> or the <hi rend="ital">comp. abl.</hi> (cf. adaeque); in Cic. and good class. authors gen. with <hi rend="ital">et</hi>, <hi rend="ital">atque</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ac</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ac si;</hi> less class. with <hi rend="ital">quam</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ut</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quam ut;</hi> in Petr. with <hi rend="ital">tamquam.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1323.20" n="(a)" level="5"> Aeque—cum: <cit><quote lang="la">animum advorte, ut aeque mecum haec scias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:2:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 2, 66</bibl></cit>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:prol. 47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. prol. 47</bibl>: novi aeque omnia tecum, Ter Phorm. 5, 9, 43. But in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:4:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 4, 1, 26</bibl>, tecum una postea aeque pocla potitet, una belongs with tecum to potitet, and aeque is put <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> (sc. ut tu).—</sense><sense id="n1323.21" n="(b)" level="5"> Aeque with <hi rend="ital">comp. abl.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullus est hoc meticulosus aeque,</quote> <trans><tr>as this person</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 137</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui me in terrā aeque fortunatus erit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:2:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 1, 2, 51</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1323.22" n="(g)" level="5"> Aeque—et or aeque— que (as in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">i)/son kai/, i)/sa kai/</foreign>, Soph. Oed. Tyr. 611; <cit><quote lang="la">Thuc. 3, 14). nisi aeque amicos et nosmet ipsos diligamus,</quote> <trans><tr>equally as ourselves</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:20:67" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 20, 67</bibl></cit>. versūs aeque prima et media et extrema pars attenditur, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:50:192" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 50, 192</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Com. 1, 2</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:13:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 13, 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:69:195" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 69, 195</bibl>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:26:62 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 26, 62 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod Aeque neglectum pueris senibusque nocebit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 26</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1323.23" n="(d)" level="5"> Aeque—atque, —ac, —ac si, <hi rend="ital">as ... as; as much as</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as</hi>: vide ne, quem tu esse hebetem deputes aeque ac pecus, is, etc., Att. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:22:45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 22, 45</bibl>: pumex non aeque aridus atque hic est senex, Plaut Aul. 2, 4, 18; <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm 1, 2, 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:8:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 8, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi haberes, qui illis aeque ac tu ipse gauderet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:6:22" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 6, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed me colit et observat aeque atque patronum suum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 13, 69</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:71:248" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 71, 248</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:40:116" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 40, 116</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 6, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:12 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 12 al.</bibl>: aeque ac si. with the <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">just as if. altogether as if</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Egnatii absentis rem ut tueare, aeque a te peto ac si mea negotia essent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:43:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 43, 3</bibl></cit>; Auct Her 2, 13, 19: quo factum est, ut jumenta aeque nitida ex castellis educeret ac si in campestribus ea locis habuisset, Nep <bibl default="NO"><author>Eum.</author> 5</bibl>. 6; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 7, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:22:5 al" default="NO" valid="yes">44, 22, 5 al.</bibl>—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) Aeque— quam (only in Plaut. and prose writers from the Aug. per.; <cit><quote lang="la">neither in Cic. nor in Cæs.),</quote> <trans><tr>as ... as</tr>, <tr>in the same manner as</tr>, <tr>as well ... as</tr>, <tr>like</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:5:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 5, 55</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">nullum esse agrum aeque feracem quam hic est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epid. 2, 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil aeque eos terruit quam robur et color imperatoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:26:14:5:6:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 26, 14, 5, 6, 11</bibl></cit>; so 5, 3, 4; 31, 1, 3; <cit><quote lang="la">in navibus posita aeque quam in aedificiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:196" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 81, 83, § 196</bibl></cit>; so 2, 70, 72, § 180; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 2, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:64:89" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 64, 89</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:4 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Galb. 4 al.</bibl>—（<foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>) Aeque—ut, a rare combination, and unworthy of imitation (in authors of the class. per. its reception rests, for the most part, upon false readings for aeque et or aeque ac), <hi rend="ital">as much as</hi>, <hi rend="ital">like</hi>, cui nihil aeque in causis agendis ut brevitas placet, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:1:20:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 1, 20, 1</bibl> Keil. accinctus aeque ut discinctus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,013:20:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Reg. 20, 11</bibl>. Possidebitis eam (terram) singuli aeque ut frater suus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:47:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Ezech. 47, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">idemque proficeret aeque ut rosaceum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 23, 4, 45, § 89</bibl></cit>, where Jan reads <hi rend="ital">proficeret quod rosaceum.</hi>—In Plaut. once aeque—quasi for the class. aeque ac. quem videam aeque esse maestum quasi dies si dicta sit, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 5, 1, 11</bibl> Fleck.—（<foreign lang="greek">h</foreign>) Sometimes aeque—aeque, <hi rend="ital">as well as</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as much as.</hi> aeque pauperibus prodest, locupletibus aeque, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeque discordiam praepositorum, aeque concordiam subjectis exitiosam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1323.24" n="2" level="3"> The comparison is often to be supplied from the whole sentence or context; hence, aeque stands <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> for aeque ac, etc. (ante-class. freq.; also in Cic. and Liv.), <hi rend="ital">equally</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as much as</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as</hi>: eadem oratio non aeque valet, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:11:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 11, 4</bibl> (from Eurip. Hec. 295: <foreign lang="greek">lo/gos ... ou) tau)to\n sqe/nei</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">satin habes, si feminarum nullast quam aeque diligam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 3, 11</bibl></cit>: Aetna mons non aeque altus, <cb n="AERA" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:2:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 4, 2, 73</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 7, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:3:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 1, 3, 85</bibl>, etc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:3:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 3, 3, 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 6, 1</bibl>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:33:62" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 4, 33, 62</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeque sons,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:19:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 19, 2</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so 29, 19, 4 al.: aeque non est dubium,</quote> <trans><tr>it is as little doubtful</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 15, 13, § 68</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1323.25" n="3" level="3"> With omnes, uterque, and definite numerals, to indicate that a thing applies equally to all the objects designated, <hi rend="ital">equally</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">non omnia eadem aeque omnibus suavia esse scito,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 3, 51</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:2:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 2, 1, 2</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:8:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 8, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:27:75 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 4, 27, 75 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">etsi utrique nostrum prope aeque gratae erant (litterae),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 13, 18</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 28, 86</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:118" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 118</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:8:33" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 3, 8, 33</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fast. 1, 226</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeque ambo pares,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:9:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 5, 9, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">duae trabes aeque longae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:101" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 101</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n1323.26" n="4" level="3"> Sometimes <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, with several substantives, <hi rend="ital">alike</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equally</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tragici et comici Numquam aeque sunt meditati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 4, 2, 4</bibl></cit>. imperium bonus ignavus aeque sibi exoptant, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 11</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1323.27" n="5" level="3"> In <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:5:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 5, 42</bibl>, nec est mihi quisquam, melius aeque cui velim, <hi rend="ital">melius velle</hi> is, perhaps, to be taken together as a phrase, and the comp. considered as used in a restricted sense, as in <hi rend="ital">melius est.</hi> Others consider the comp. as used for the simple positive; cf. adaeque.—</sense><sense id="n1323.28" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Justly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with equity</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi id aeque factum arbitror,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:5:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 5, 22</bibl></cit> dub. (Ritschl: jureque id factum arbitror).— <hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: ferro quam fame aequius perituros, <hi rend="ital">more willingly</hi>, Sall. H. Fragm.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequissime jus dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Epit. 11:2" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Epit. 11, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">judicas ut qui aequissime,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> 15</bibl></cit>, Ep. 11.!*? An old adverb. form, <orth extent="full" lang="la">aequĭter</orth>, also occurs: praeda per participes aequiter partita est, Liv. Andr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 512, 31</bibl>; so Pac. ib., Att. ib., and Plaut. acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 1010</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
aer: <entryFree id="n1324" type="main" key="a_e_r"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āēr</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">āĕris</orth>, <gen>m.</gen> (in Enn. once <sense id="n1324.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:13:20:14" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 13, 20, 14</bibl>, as also <foreign lang="greek">a)h/r</foreign> in Gr., in the earliest per, was <hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>, Gr. <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> aëros, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:2:693" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 2, 693</bibl>; Gr. <case>acc.</case> aëra, Cic., Sen., Plin.; <cit><quote lang="la">pure Lat. form, āĕrem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:10:65" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, 10, 65</bibl></cit>; Cato ap. Serv ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:184" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 184</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 1, 1, § 3</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">plur nom.</hi> and <case>acc.</case> āĕres, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 11</bibl>; later āĕra, Ven. Fort. Carm 9, 1, 141, <case>dat.</case> āĕribus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:289" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 289</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:643" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 643</bibl>), = <foreign lang="greek">a)hr</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the air</hi>, properly <hi rend="ital">the lower atmosphere</hi> (in distinction from <hi rend="ital">aether</hi>, the upper pure air): <cit><quote lang="la">istic est is Juppiter quem dico, quem Graeci vocant Aërem, qui ventus est et nubes, imber postea, Atque ex imbre frigus, ventus post fit, aër denuo, Enn. ap. Varr L. L. 5, § 65 Müll. (Epicharm. v. 9 Vahl.,: terra circumfusa undique est hac animall spirabilique naturā, cui nomen est aër, Graecum illud quidem, sed perceptum jam tamen usu a nostris, tritum est enim pro Latino,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:36:91" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 36, 91</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">itaque aër et ignis et aqua et terra primae sunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 1, 7, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Anaximenes aëra Deum statuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aërem in perniciem vertere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:3 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 1, 1, § 3 al.</bibl></cit>—Also in <number>plur.</number>: aëribus binis, Lucr 4, 291: aëres locorum salubres aut pestilentes, Vitr 1, 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n1324.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1324.2" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: aër summus arboris, <hi rend="ital">the airy summit</hi>, for <hi rend="ital">the highest point</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:123" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 123</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:99" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 99</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1324.3" n="B" level="2"> Also <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">a cloud</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vapor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mist</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Venus obscuro gradientes aëre sepsit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:411" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 411</bibl></cit>: aëre septus, Val Fl. 5,401—</sense><sense id="n1324.4" n="C" level="2"> With limiting <pos>adj.</pos> = <hi rend="ital">the weather</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">crassus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 25, 81</bibl></cit>. fusus et extenuatus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:39" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 39</bibl> purus et tenuis, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 16</bibl> temperatus, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div 2, 42</bibl></sense><sense id="n1324.5" n="1" level="3"> † <orth extent="full" lang="la">aera</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">dissyl.</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)ra</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a weed among grain; darnel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tare</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">cockle</hi>, Lolium temulentum, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:156" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 17, 44, § 156</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aera: <entryFree id="n1325" type="main" key="aera" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aera</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> [from aera, <sense id="n1325.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">counters;</hi> v. aes, 2. E., later Lat. </sense><sense id="n1325.1" n="I" level="1"> In math., <hi rend="ital">a given number</hi>, <hi rend="ital">according to which a reckoning</hi> or <hi rend="ital">calculation is to be made</hi>, Vitruvius (Vetrubius) Rufus ap. Salmas. Exercc. I. p. 483.— </sense><sense id="n1325.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Anitem of an account</hi> (for the class. aera, plur. of aes, Ruf. Fest. in Breviar. <hi rend="ital">init.</hi> The passage of Lucil. cited by <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 2, 42</bibl>, aera perversa, is also prob. plur.).—</sense><sense id="n1325.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An era</hi> or <hi rend="ital">epoch from which time is reckoned</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 5, 36</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> II. p. 374</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeramen: <entryFree id="n1326" type="main" key="aera_men"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerāmen</orth>, <itype>inis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>aes</etym>, a late form for <sense id="n1326.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">aes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">copper</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bronze;</hi> aeramen aut marmora, Cod. Th. 15, 1, 37: <cit><quote lang="la">ferri vel aeraminis purgamenta,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> 1, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aeramentum: <entryFree id="n1327" type="main" key="aera_mentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerāmentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1327.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that is prepared from copper</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bronze;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">a copper</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bronze vessel</hi> or <hi rend="ital">utensil</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 5, 30, § 94</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:182" default="NO" valid="yes">35, 15, 51, § 182</bibl>. <cb n="AERA" /></sense></entryFree>
aeraria: <entryFree id="n1328" type="main" key="aera_ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerārĭa</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">aerārĭum</orth>, v. aerarius, under B. and C.</entryFree>
