aerarius: <entryFree id="n1329" type="main" key="aera_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aes</etym>. <sense id="n1329.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">That pertains to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">is made of copper</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bronze</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">aerarium metallum,</quote> <trans><tr>a copper-mine</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 5, 26, § 86</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">fornaces,</quote> <trans><tr>smelting-furnaces</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 11, 36, 42, § 119</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fabrica,</quote> <trans><tr>the preparation of copper</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:197" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 56, 57, § 197</bibl></cit> faber, <hi rend="ital">a coppersmith</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:8:19:6:section=61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 8, 19, 6, § 61</bibl> (also aerarius alone; v. below).—</sense><sense id="n1329.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to money</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">propter aerariam rationem non satis erat in tabulis inspexisse quantum deberetur,</quote> <trans><tr>on account of the standard of coin</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hinc dicuntur milites aerarii, ab aere quod stipendia facerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=181" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 181</bibl></cit> Müll.: tribunus, <hi rend="ital">who superintended disbursements of the public treasury</hi>: aerarii tribuni a tribuendo aere sunt appellati, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=2" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 2</bibl> Müll.; <cit><quote lang="la">or, acc. to Varr.: ab eo, quibus attributa erat pecunia, ut militi reddant, tribuni aerarii dicti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=181" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 181</bibl></cit> Müll.; v. tribunus.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aerārĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> </sense><sense id="n1329.2" n="1" level="3"> (Sc. faber.) <hi rend="ital">One who works in copper</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">a coppersmith</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aerariorum officinis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 6, 8, § 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aerariorum marculi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:57:6" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 57, 6</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4140</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1329.3" n="2" level="3"> (Sc. civis.) <hi rend="ital">A citizen of the lowest class</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who paid only a poll-tax</hi> (aera pendebat), <hi rend="ital">and had no right of voting.</hi> Other citizens, upon the commission of great crimes, were degraded by the censors into this class, and deprived of all previous dignities. (Cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:12" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 12</bibl> and 29; Drak. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:18:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 18, 6</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">Smith's Dict. Antiq., and Nieb. Röm. Gesch. 2, 63 and 452.) Referre aliquem in aerarios,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 43</bibl></cit>. eximere aliquem ex aerariis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 66</bibl> <hi rend="ital">ext.;</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes, quos senatu moverunt, quibusque equos ademerunt (censores) aerarios fecerunt et tribu moverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:10 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 42, 10 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1329.4" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">aerārĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> </sense><sense id="n1329.5" n="1" level="3"> (Sc. fodina, like argentaria and ferraria, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">auraria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:19 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 19 al.</bibl></cit>) <hi rend="ital">A mine</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">multis locis apud eos (sc. Aquitanos) aerariae structuraeque sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 21</bibl></cit> Herz. —</sense><sense id="n1329.6" n="2" level="3"> (Sc. officina.) <hi rend="ital">A smelting</hi> or <hi rend="ital">refining house</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 8:33" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 8, 33</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1329.7" n="3" level="3"> (Sc. fornax.) <hi rend="ital">A smelting-furnace</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 13, 33, § 128</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1329.8" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">aerārĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (sc. stabulum), <hi rend="ital">the place in the temple of Saturn at Rome</hi>, <hi rend="ital">where the public treasure was kept</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the treasury</hi>: <foreign lang="greek">to\ tamiei=on, to\ koino/n</foreign>: Aerarium sane populus Romanus in aede Saturni habuit, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=2" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 2</bibl> Müll.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:92" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 92</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">referre pecuniam in aerarium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 27</bibl></cit> (for which deferre is often used in Liv. q.v.): <cit><quote lang="la">dare alicui pecuniam ex aerario,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 70</bibl></cit>.—Also for <hi rend="ital">the public treasure</hi> or <hi rend="ital">finances</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">C. Gracchus, cum largitiones maximas fecisset et effudisset aerarium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:20:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 20, 48</bibl></cit>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Arist. 3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Arist. 3, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 8</bibl>.—In the time of the emperors the <hi rend="ital">aerarium</hi> (public treasure) was distinguished from <hi rend="ital">fiscus</hi> (the wealth of the emperor): <cit><quote lang="la">bona Sejani ablata aerario, ut in fisco cogerentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:36" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 36</bibl>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:16" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vesp. 16</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">v. fiscus. In the treasury the public archives were kept: factum senatus consultum, ne decreta patrum ante diem decimum ad aerarium deferrentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 51</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:94" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 94</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:28" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Caes. 28</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and also the standards: signa ex aerario prompta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 22</bibl></cit>.—The Quaestores aerarii (under Augustus and his immediate successors the Praetores) presided over the aerarium, with whom the Tribuni aerarii were associated as assistants; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Quaestor and Tribunus.—The aerarium contained also a fund, established after the invasion of Gaul, and augmented by the immense booty acquired in the wars with Carthage, Macedonia, Corinth, etc., as well as by the tribute of the manumissi, which could be used only in cases of extreme public necessity, hence with the epithet sanctius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aurum vicesimarium, quod in sanctiore aerario ad ultimos casus servaretur, promi placuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 10</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 63</bibl> (of the Syracusans). Hence trop., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:3:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 3, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aerarium militare, destined by Aug. for defraying the expenses of war,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 78</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:49" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 49</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:92:1" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 92, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeratus: <entryFree id="n1330" type="main" key="aera_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> <etym>from aero, āre, found in no example, and only mentioned in Priscian: a metallorum quoque nominibus solent nasci verba, ut ab auro, auro, as, <pb n="60" /> <cb n="AERO" /> ab aere, aero, as; unde auratus et aeratus. p. 828 P.</etym>. <sense id="n1330.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Furnished</hi> or <hi rend="ital">covered with copper</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bronze</hi>: ratis, Naev. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=23" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 23</bibl> Müll. (Bell. Punic. v. 59 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">lecti,</quote> <trans><tr>having bronze feet</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:26:section=60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 26, § 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naves,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:16:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 16, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">porta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:785" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 785</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">acies,</quote> <trans><tr>armed ranks</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:463" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 463</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1330.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Made of bronze</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">catenae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:13:11" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 13, 11</bibl></cit>.—*</sense><sense id="n1330.2" n="III" level="1"> Sarcastic. of a <hi rend="ital">rich</hi> man: <cit><quote lang="la">tribuni non tam aerati quam aerarii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:16:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 16, 8</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aereus: <entryFree id="n1331" type="main" key="aere^us1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerĕus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">trisyl.</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aes</etym>. <sense id="n1331.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Made of copper</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cornua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:615" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 615</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">clavus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 10, 20, § 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tabulae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vesp. 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vasa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,012:8:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Reg. 8, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1331.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Furnished</hi> or <hi rend="ital">covered with copper</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bronze</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">clipeus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:541" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 541</bibl></cit>; so (<hi rend="ital">with copper</hi>) <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:17:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 17, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">puppis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:198" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 198</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">aeratae naves,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:16:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 16, 21</bibl></cit>).— <orth extent="full" lang="la">aerĕus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (sc. nummus), <hi rend="ital">a bronze coin</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aereos signatos constituere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 3, 1</bibl></cit>.— <orth extent="full" lang="la">aerĕum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a copper color</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:212" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 52, 78, § 212</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
<entryFree id="n1332" type="main" key="a_e^re^us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āĕrĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. aërius.</entryFree>
aerifer: <entryFree id="n1333" type="hapax" key="aeri^fer"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerĭfer</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">trisyl.</orth>), <itype>fĕra, fĕrum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aes-fero</etym>, <sense id="n1333.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">bearing copper</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bronze</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">bronze cymbals</hi>, of the attendants of Bacchus: <cit><quote lang="la">manus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:740" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 740</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aerifice: <entryFree id="n1334" type="main" key="aeri^fi^ce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerĭfĭcē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>aes-facio</etym>, <sense id="n1334.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">with the art of the worker in bronze</hi>: Musae (i. e. Musarum statuae), quas aerifice duxti, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 69, 30</bibl>, and 283, 31.</sense></entryFree>
aerificium: <entryFree id="n1335" type="gloss" key="aeri^fi^ci^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerĭfĭcĭum</orth>: <sense id="n1335.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">dictum, quod fit ex aere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 69, 28</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aerifodina: <entryFree id="n1336" type="spur" key="aeri^fo^di_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerĭfŏdīna</orth> <itype>ae</itype>, a false read. in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=7" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 7</bibl>.</entryFree>
aerinus: <entryFree id="n1337" type="main" key="aeri^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerĭnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>1. aera</etym>, <sense id="n1337.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of darnel</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cockle</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 25, 58, § 125</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:100" default="NO" valid="yes">24, 11, 59, § 100</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeripes: <entryFree id="n1338" type="main" key="aeri^pes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerĭ-pes</orth>, <itype>pĕdis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aes</etym>. <sense id="n1338.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Bronzefooted</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">tauri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:12:93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 12, 93</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cerva,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:802" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 802</bibl></cit> (since, acc. to fable, they had feet of bronze; hence we need not, with <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 249</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 437</bibl> P., and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1321,001:page=449" default="NO"><author>Pomp.</author> p. 449</bibl> Lind., take aeripedes for aëripedes from aër, the air, and pes).—</sense><sense id="n1338.1" n="II" level="1"> Metaph., <hi rend="ital">strong of foot;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">swift of foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">swiftfooted</hi> (as in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">xalko/pous</foreign> sometimes = <foreign lang="greek">i)sxuro/pous</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">cervi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Idyll. 11, 14</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aerisonus: <entryFree id="n1339" type="main" key="aeri^so^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerĭ-sŏnus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">quadrisyl.</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aes</etym>, <sense id="n1339.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sounding with bronze</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">antra,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>in which the Curetes beat their bronze shields</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:2:93" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 2, 93</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mons,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:3:28 al" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 3, 28 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
aerius: <entryFree id="n1340" type="main" key="a_e^ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āĕrĭus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">quadrisyl.</orth>), more rar. <orth extent="full" lang="la">āĕrĕ-us</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)e/rios.</foreign> <sense id="n1340.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Pertaining to the air</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aërial</hi> (a <usg type="style">poet.</usg> word, which Cic. uses only in higher flights of speech): <cit><quote lang="la">volucres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:825" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 825</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Univ. 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">volatus avium atque cantus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:chapter=20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Top. 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aërias vias carpere,</quote> <trans><tr>their way in the air</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 2, 44</bibl></cit>: aërias tentăsse domos, <hi rend="ital">the heavens</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:28:5 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 28, 5 al.</bibl>—Hence aërium mel, because the bee was believed to collect its honey from falling dew, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 1</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n1340.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Rising aloft</hi>, <hi rend="ital">airy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">high.</hi>—So esp. of mountains: <cit><quote lang="la">Alpes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:474" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 474</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:226" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 226</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aërio vertice Taurus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:7:15" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 7, 15</bibl></cit> (<hi rend="ital">aetherio</hi>, Müll.): <cit><quote lang="la">cacumen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:240 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 240 al.</bibl></cit> —Of trees: <cit><quote lang="la">quercus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:680" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 680</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ulmus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:1:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> E. 1, 59</bibl></cit>.—Of other things: <cit><quote lang="la">arces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:291" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 291</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(capra) cornibus aëriis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:119" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 119</bibl></cit>.—*</sense><sense id="n1340.2" n="B" level="2"> Aëria spes, <hi rend="ital">airy</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">quickly flying away</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fleeting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">transitory</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 2, p. 86</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aerizusa: <entryFree id="n1341" type="greek" key="a_e^ri_zu_sa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āĕrīzūsa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)eri/zousa</foreign> (<mood>Part.</mood> from <foreign lang="greek">a)erizw</foreign>, to imitate or resemble air, to be as pure as air), <sense id="n1341.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of precious stone;</hi> acc. to Salmas., <hi rend="ital">the turquoise</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 8, 37, § 115</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aero: <entryFree id="n1342" type="main" key="aero1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aero</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, v. aeratus.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1343" type="greek" key="aero2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aero</orth> (also written <orth extent="full" lang="la">ēro</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)/rw</foreign>, <sense id="n1343.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a braided</hi> or <hi rend="ital">wicker basket</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hamper</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aerones ex ulva palustri facti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 5, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeronibus harenae plenis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 14, 21, § 96</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:19:2:31" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 19, 2, 31</bibl>; cf. Don. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:1:2:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 1, 2, 72</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeroides: <entryFree id="n1344" type="greek" key="a_e^ro^i_de_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āĕrŏīdēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)eroeidh/s</foreign>, <sense id="n1344.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of the color of the air</hi>, <hi rend="ital">like air</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sky-blue</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">berylli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 5, 21, § 77</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aeromantia: <entryFree id="n1345" type="greek" key="a_e^ro^manti_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āĕrŏmantīa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)eromantei/a</foreign>, <sense id="n1345.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">divination from the state of the air</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aëromancy</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 8, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aerope: <entryFree id="n1346" type="main" key="A_e^ro^pe_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Āĕrŏpē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Āĕrŏpa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aero/ph</foreign>, <sense id="n1346.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the wife of Atreus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:2:391" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 2, 391</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 86:88" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 86, 88</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aerophobus: <entryFree id="n1347" type="greek" key="a_e^ro^pho^bus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āĕrŏphŏbus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)erofo/bos</foreign>, <sense id="n1347.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one that fears the air</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Acut. 3:12" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Acut. 3, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aerosus: <entryFree id="n1348" type="main" key="aero_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aes</etym>, <sense id="n1348.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">full of copper</hi>:<cb n="AERU" />  Cyprus, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=20" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 20</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">aurum,</quote> <trans><tr>gold that contains many parts of copper</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 5, 29, § 93</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:143" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 14, 41, § 143</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecunia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:46:3:102" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 46, 3, 102</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aeruca: <entryFree id="n1349" type="main" key="aeru_ca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerūca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aes</etym>, <sense id="n1349.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of verdigris</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aerugino: <entryFree id="n1350" type="main" key="aeru_gi^no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerūgĭno</orth>, <itype>avi, atum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>aerugo</etym>, <sense id="n1350.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to become rusty</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cankered</hi> (eccl.): <cit><quote lang="la">aurum et argentum vestrum aeruginavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,020:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jac. 5, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1350.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">sicut aeramentum, aeruginat nequitia illius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:12:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccli. 12, 10</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aeruginosus: <entryFree id="n1351" type="main" key="aeru_gi^no_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerūgĭnōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1351.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">full of copper-rust</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rusty</hi> (perh. only in Seneca): manus, Contr. 1, 2 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lamellae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. Vit. 12</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aerugo: <entryFree id="n1352" type="main" key="aeru_go"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerūgo</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aes, as ferrugo from ferrum</etym>. <sense id="n1352.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Rust of copper</hi>: aes Corinthium in aeruginem incidit, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 8, 8, § 34</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:160" default="NO" valid="yes">34, 17, 48, § 160</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1352.1" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1352.2" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The verdigris prepared from the same</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aeruginis quoque magnus usus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 11, 26, § 110</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1352.3" n="2" level="3"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">rust of gold and silver</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aerugo eorum (auri et argenti) in testimonium vobis erit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,020:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jac. 5, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1352.4" n="3" level="3"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg> (as pars pro toto, and sarcastic.), <hi rend="ital">money</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:13:60" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 13, 60</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1352.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1352.6" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Envy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">jealousy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ill-will</hi> (which seek to consume the possessions of a neighbor, as rust corrodes metals): <cit><quote lang="la">haec est Aerugo mera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:4:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 4, 101</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">versus tincti viridi aerugine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:33:5" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 10, 33, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:2:61:5" default="NO">2, 61, 5</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1352.7" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Avarice</hi>, which cleaves to the mind of man like rust: <cit><quote lang="la">animos aerugo et cura peculi Cum semel imbuerit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:330" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 330</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aerumna: <entryFree id="n1353" type="main" key="aerumna"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerumna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype> (pleb. <orth extent="full" lang="la">er-</orth>), <gen>f.</gen> <etym>contr. from aegrimonia; as to the suppressed <hi rend="ital">g</hi>, cf. jumentum from jugum, Doed. Syn. IV. p. 420. Others explain aerumna (with Paul. ex Fest. s. v. aerumnula, p. 24 Müll.) orig. for a frame for carrying burdens upon the back; hence trop.</etym>, <sense id="n1353.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">need</hi>, <hi rend="ital">want</hi>, <hi rend="ital">trouble</hi>, <hi rend="ital">toil</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hardship</hi>, <hi rend="ital">distress</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tribulation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">calamity</hi>, etc. (objectively; while <hi rend="ital">aegrimonia</hi>, like <hi rend="ital">aegritudo</hi>, denotes, subjectively, the condition of mind, Doed. 1. c.; for the most part only ante-class., except in Cic., who uses it several times, in order to designate by one word the many modifications and shadings of the condition of mental suffering; in Quintilian's time the word was obsolete, v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:26" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 26</bibl>): tibi sunt ante ferendae aerumnae, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:20:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 20, 40</bibl> (Ann. v. 47 Vahl.); cf.: Ilia dia nepos, quas erumnas tetulisti, id. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 70</bibl> P. (Ann. v. 56 ib.): quantis cum aerumnis exantlavi diem, id. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 292, 8</bibl> (Trag. v. 127 ib.): <cit><quote lang="la">uno ut labore absolvat aerumnas duas (of the pains of parturition),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 2, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus aequos optimum est aerumnae condimentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 2, 3, 71</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:2:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 10</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">so,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:5:4:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 5, 4, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:2:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 1, 2, 54</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:1:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 1, 1, 1</bibl>: lapit cor cura, aerumna corpus conficit, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 23, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 1, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 50</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aerumna gravescit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1065" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 1065</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo pacto adversam aerumnam ferant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 1, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">maeror est aegritudo flebilis: aerumna aegritudo laboriosa: dolor aegritudo crucians,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:8:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 8, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Herculis aerumnas perpeti: sic enim majores nostri labores non fugiendos tristissimo tamen verbo aerumnas etiam in Deo nominaverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:35" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 35</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 32, 95</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mors est aerumnarum requies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 51:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 51, 20</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 13:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 13, 22</bibl>: Luculli miles collecta viatica multis Aerumnis, ad assem Perdiderat, <hi rend="ital">with much difficulty</hi>, * <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">multiplicabo aerumnas tuas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:3:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 3, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in labore et aerumnā (fui),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,008:11:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 2 Cor. 11, 27</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1353.1" n="II" level="1"> In later Lat. for <hi rend="ital">defeat</hi> (of an army), <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 15, 4</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 15, 8 al.</bibl>!*? At a later period, also, ĕrumna was written with short <hi rend="ital">e</hi>, Paulin. Petric. Vit. D. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:1:66" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 1, 66</bibl>. Hence, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 76</bibl> P. derives it from eruere (quod mentem eruat). Cf. Doed. Syn. IV. p. 420.</sense></entryFree>
aerumnabilis: <entryFree id="n1354" type="main" key="aerumna_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerumnābĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aerumna</etym>, <sense id="n1354.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that may be regarded as wretched</hi> or <hi rend="ital">miserable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">full of trouble</hi>, <hi rend="ital">calamitous</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:123" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 123</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 1, p. 102</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">8</bibl>, p. 205.</sense></entryFree>
aerumnosus: <entryFree id="n1355" type="main" key="aerumno_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerumnōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1355.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">full of trouble</hi> or <hi rend="ital">misery</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suffering</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wretched</hi>, <hi rend="ital">miserable</hi>: salum, Att. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:28:67" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 28, 67</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">inopes, aerumnosae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:1:4:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 1, 4, 39</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:4:1:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 4, 1, 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">miseros, afflictos, aerumnosos, calamitosos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:38:82" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 38, 82</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:chapter=2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Par. 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:3:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 3, 23 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>, once also in his Orations: <cit><quote lang="la">infelix et aerumnosus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 62</bibl></cit>: nihil est aerumnosius, Sen. de Ira, 2, 7.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: non huic aerumnosissimo<cb n="AES" />  venenum illud fuisset, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:71:201" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 71, 201</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:3:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 3, 23</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aerumnula: <entryFree id="n1356" type="gloss" key="aerumnu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerumnŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>aerumna, q. v.</etym>, <sense id="n1356.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a traveller's stick for carrying a bundle</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=24" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 24</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
aeruscator: <entryFree id="n1357" type="hapax" key="aerusca_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aeruscātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (aerusco], <sense id="n1357.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who roves about the country</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and obtains his living by exhibiting sleight-of-hand tricks; an itinerant juggler</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:14:1:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 14, 1, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aerusco: <entryFree id="n1358" type="main" key="aerusco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aerusco</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>aes</etym>, <sense id="n1358.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to get money by going about and exhibiting tricks of legerdemain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to play the juggler</hi>: aeruscare: aera undique, id est pecunias, colligere, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=24" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 24</bibl> Müll.—Esp., of mendicant philosophers, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:9:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 9, 2</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Clem. 2:7:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Clem. 2, 7, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aes: <entryFree id="n1359" type="main" key="aes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aes</orth>, <itype>aeris</itype> (often used in <sense id="n1359.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">plur. nom.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">acc.; abl.</hi> aeribus, Cato ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=27" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 27</bibl> Müll., and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:636" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 636</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> AERVM, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3551</bibl>), <gen>n.</gen> <etym>cf. Germ. Eisen = iron, Erz = copper; Goth. aiz = copper, gold; Angl.Sax. ar, ær = ore, copper, brass; Eng. iron, ore; Lat. aurum; with the com. notion of brightness; cf. aurora, etc.</etym>. </sense><sense id="n1359.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Any crude metal dug out of the earth</hi>, except gold and silver; esp., </sense><sense id="n1359.2" n="a" level="4"> Aes Cyprium, whence cuprum, <hi rend="ital">copper</hi>: scoria aeris, <hi rend="ital">copper dross</hi> or <hi rend="ital">scoria</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 11, 24, § 107</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeris flos,</quote> <trans><tr>flowers of copper</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 11, 24, § 107</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">squama aeris,</quote> <trans><tr>scales of copper</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 12 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aes fundere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 5, 30, § 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">conflare et temperare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:197" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 56, 57, § 197</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">India neque aes neque plumbum habet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:163" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 17, 48, § 163</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aurum et argentum et aes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Ex. 25, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1359.3" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">An alloy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">for the most part of copper and tin</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bronze</hi> (brass, <hi rend="ital">an alloy of copper and zinc</hi>, was hardly known to the ancients. For their bronze coins the Greeks adhered to copper and tin till B.C. 400, after which they added lead. Silver is rare in Greek bronze coins. The Romans admitted lead into their bronze coins, but gradually reduced the quantity, and, under Calig., Nero, Vesp., and Domit., issued pure copper coins, and then reverted to the mixture of lead. In the bronze mirrors now existing, which are nearly all Etruscan, silver predominated to give a highly reflecting surface. The antique bronze had about 87 parts of copper to 13 of tin. An analysis of several objects has given the following centesimal parts: <figure /> statua ex aere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:9:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 9, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">simulacrum ex aere factum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 4, 9, § 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">valvas ex aere factitavere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 3, 7, § 13</bibl></cit>.—Hence: <cit><quote lang="la">ducere aliquem ex aere,</quote> <trans><tr>to cast one's image in bronze</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 37, 38, § 125</bibl></cit>; and in the same sense <usg type="style">poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ducere aera,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 240</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aes Corinthium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 2, 3</bibl></cit>, §§ 5-8; v. Corinthius.—</sense><sense id="n1359.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1359.5" n="A" level="2"> (Esp. in the poets.) For <hi rend="ital">everything made</hi> or <hi rend="ital">prepared from copper</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bronze</hi>, etc. (<hi rend="ital">statues</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tables of laws</hi>, <hi rend="ital">money</hi>), and (as the ancients had the art of hardening and tempering copper and bronze) <hi rend="ital">weapons</hi>, <hi rend="ital">armor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">utensils of husbandry</hi>: aes sonit, franguntur hastae, <hi rend="ital">the trumpet sounds</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 504, 32</bibl> (Trag. v. 213 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">Et prior aeris erat quam ferri cognitus usus: Aere solum terrae tractabant, aereque belli Miscebant fluctus et vulnera vasta serebant, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1287" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1287</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae ille in aes incidit, in quo populi jussa perpetuasque leges esse voluit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 1, 17</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 12, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 14</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 4, 40</bibl>: aere (<hi rend="ital">with the trumpet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">horn</hi>) ciere viros, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:165" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 165</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non tuba directi, non aeris cornua flexi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 98</bibl></cit> (hence also rectum aes, the <hi rend="ital">tuba</hi>, in contr. with the crooked <hi rend="ital">buccina</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:2:118" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 2, 118</bibl>); <hi rend="ital">a brazen prow</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 35</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">the brazen age</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:16:64" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 16, 64</bibl>.—In <number>plur.</number>: aera, Cato ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=27" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 27</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:734" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 734</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:8:2 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 8, 2 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n1359.6" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Money</hi>: the first Roman money consisted of small <hi rend="ital">rude masses</hi> of copper, called aes rude, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 3, 13, § 43</bibl>; afterwards as <hi rend="ital">coined</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aes signatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 3, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 3, 13, § 43</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">so aes alone: si aes habent, dant mercem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:3:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 3, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ancilla aere suo empta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 3, 2, 26</bibl></cit>: aes circumforaneum. <hi rend="ital">borrowed from the brokers in the forum</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 1</bibl>: Hic meret aera liber Sosiis, <hi rend="ital">earns them money</hi>, Hor. A. P. <pb n="61" /> <cb n="AESC" /> 345: <cit><quote lang="la">gravis aere dextra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 1, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">effusum est aes tuum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Ez. 16, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque in zona aes (tollerent),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Maarc. 6, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam aureos nummos aes dicimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:16:159" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 50, 16, 159</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1359.7" n="1" level="3"> Aes alienum, lit. <hi rend="ital">the money of another;</hi> hence, in reference to him who has it, <hi rend="ital">the sum owed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a debt</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:3:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 3, 1, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">habere aes alienum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aes alienum amicorum suscipere,</quote> <trans><tr>to take upon one's self</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">contrahere,</quote> <trans><tr>to run up</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 13, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">conflare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 14:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 14, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:24:3" default="NO" valid="yes">24, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aes alienum incidere,</quote> <trans><tr>to fall into debt</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aere alieno esse,</quote> <trans><tr>to be in debt</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:4:section=6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 4, § 6</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">aere alieno oppressum esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:chapter=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Font. 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:22:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 22, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">laborare ex aere alieno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">liberare se aere alieno,</quote> <trans><tr>to get quit of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 2</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">aes alienum dissolvere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:chapter=56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aere alieno exire,</quote> <trans><tr>to get out of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:11:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 11, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1359.8" n="2" level="3"> In aere meo est, trop., <hi rend="ital">he is</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as it were</hi>, <hi rend="ital">among my effects</hi>, <hi rend="ital">he is my friend</hi> (only in the language of common conversation): <cit><quote lang="la">in animo habui te in aere meo esse propter Lamiae nostri conjunctionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 62</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">15, 14</bibl>.—*</sense><sense id="n1359.9" n="3" level="3"> Alicujus aeris esse, <hi rend="ital">to be of some value</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 18, 5</bibl>.—*</sense><sense id="n1359.10" n="4" level="3"> In aere suo censeri, <hi rend="ital">to be esteemed according to its own worth</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 87" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 87</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1359.11" n="C" level="2"> Sometimes = as, <hi rend="ital">the unit of the standard of money</hi> (cf. as); hence, aes grave, <hi rend="ital">the old heary money</hi> (as weighed, not counted out): <cit><quote lang="la">denis milibus aeris gravis reos condemnavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">indicibus dena milia aeris gravis, quae tum divitiae habebantur, data,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 60</bibl></cit>; so, aes alone and in the <hi rend="ital">gen. sing.</hi>, instead of assium: <cit><quote lang="la">aeris miliens, triciens,</quote> <trans><tr>a hundred millions</tr>, <tr>three millions</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 3, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui milibus aeris quinquaginta census fuisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 11</bibl></cit>.—Also for coins that are smaller than an as (quadrans, triens, etc.): <cit><quote lang="la">nec pueri credunt, nisi qui nondum aere, i. e. quadrante, lavantur (those who bathed paid each a quadrans),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:2:152" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 2, 152</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">dum tu quadrante lavatum Rex ibis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:3:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 3, 137</bibl></cit>).—</sense><sense id="n1359.12" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Wages</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pay.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1359.13" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A soldier's pay</hi> = stipendium: <cit><quote lang="la">negabant danda esse aera militibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 4</bibl></cit>. And soon after: annua aera habes: annuam operam ede.— Hence in <number>plur.</number>, = stipendia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:13:section=33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 13, § 33</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1359.14" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Reward</hi>, <hi rend="ital">payment</hi>, in gen., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:125" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 125</bibl>: nullum in bonis numero, quod ad aes exit, <hi rend="ital">that has in view</hi> or <hi rend="ital">aims at pay</hi>, <hi rend="ital">reward</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 88" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 88</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1359.15" n="E" level="2"> In <number>plur.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aera</orth>, <hi rend="ital">counters;</hi> hence also <hi rend="ital">the items of a computed sum</hi> (for which, later, a <number>sing.</number> form <orth extent="full" lang="la">aera</orth>, <itype>ae</itype> (q. v.), came into use): si aera singula probāsti, summam, quae ex his confecta sit, non probare? Cic. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 3, 18</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aesacus: <entryFree id="n1360" type="main" key="Aesa^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesăcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, and Gr. <orth extent="full" lang="la">-os</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/sakos</foreign>, <sense id="n1360.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a son of Priam</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:762" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 11, 762</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aesalon: <entryFree id="n1361" type="greek" key="aesa^lo_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aesălōn</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)sa/lwn</foreign>, <sense id="n1361.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a species of falcon</hi> or <hi rend="ital">hawk;</hi> acc. to Billerbeck, <hi rend="ital">the rust-kite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">moor-buzzard</hi>, Falco aeruginosus, Linn., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:205" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 74, 95, § 205</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aesar: <entryFree id="n1362" type="main" key="Aesar"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesar</orth>. <sense id="n1362.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A name of God among the Etruscans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:97" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 97</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1362.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesar</orth>, <itype>ăris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a river in Lower Italy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in the neighborhood of Crotona</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Esaro</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 23</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesărĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Æsar</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 54</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeschines: <entryFree id="n1363" type="main" key="Aeschi^nes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeschĭnes</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai\sxi/nhs</foreign>. <sense id="n1363.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A disciple of Socrates</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 1, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:11:27" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 11, 27</bibl>.—But more celebrated, </sense><sense id="n1363.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The orator Æschines</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rival to Demosthenes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 23</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:1:17" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 1, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:22" default="NO">10, 1, 22</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n1363.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A physician of Athens</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 4, 10, § 44</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeschrologia: <entryFree id="n1364" type="greek" key="aeschro^lo^gi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aeschrŏlŏgĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai\sxrologi/a</foreign>, in rhet., <sense id="n1364.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an expression improper on account of its ambiguity</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 445</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
aeschylus: <entryFree id="n1365" type="main" key="Aeschy^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeschylus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)sxu/los</foreign>. <sense id="n1365.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The first great tragic poet of Greece</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the originator of the Greek drama</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:278" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 278</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1365.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A rhetorician of Cnidos</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a contemporary of Cicero</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=95" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 95</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeschynomene: <entryFree id="n1366" type="greek" key="aeschy_no^me^ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aeschȳnŏmĕnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ai)sxunome/nh</foreign> (ashamed), <sense id="n1366.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant which shrinks when touched</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a sensitive plant</hi>, Mimosa pudica, Linn., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:167" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 17, 102, § 167</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aesculanus: <entryFree id="n1367" type="main" key="Aescu^la_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aescŭlānus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, sc. deus [aes], <sense id="n1367.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the god of copper</hi> or <hi rend="ital">copper money</hi>, Aug. Civ. Dei, 4, 21.</sense></entryFree>
aesculapium: <entryFree id="n1368" type="main" key="Aescu^la_pi_^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aescŭlāpī^um</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)asklhpi/eion</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">*)asklh/pion</foreign>, <sense id="n1368.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a temple of Æsculapius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7 praef" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7 praef.</bibl>—From</sense></entryFree>
aesculapius: <entryFree id="n1369" type="main" key="Aescu^la_pi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aescŭlāpĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)asklhpio/s</foreign>, acc. to fable, <sense id="n1369.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the son of Apollo and the nymph <cb n="AESO" /> Coronis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">deified after his death on account of his great knowledge of medicine</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:22" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1 praef" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 1 praef.</bibl> He had a temple at Rome, on the island in the Tiber. Upon the kind of worship paid to him, and his attributes, v. Festus, p. 82. Huic gallinae immolabantur, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:ib" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl> The principal seat of his worship in Greece was Epidaurus. In his temple there was a magnificent statue of ivory and gold, the work of Thrasymedes, in which he was represented as a noble figure, resembling that of Zeus. He was seated on a throne, holding in one hand a staff, and with the other resting on the head of a dragon (serpent), and by his side lay a dog. There were also other representations, one even as beardless, very common at an earlier period, Müll. Archaeol. d. Kunst, S. 534 and 535. Serpents, prob. as symbols of prudence and renovation. were everywhere connected with his worship; cf. Spreng. Gesch. d. Medic. 1, 205.!*? <hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">anguis Aesculapius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 29, 4, 22, § 72</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aesculetum: <entryFree id="n1370" type="main" key="aescu^le_tum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aescŭlētum</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">esc-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>aesculus</etym>, <sense id="n1370.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a forest of winter</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Italian oaks</hi>, and <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, in gen., <hi rend="ital">an oak-forest</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:22:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 22, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1370.1" n="II" level="1"> Esp.: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aescŭlētum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a place in Rome</hi>, acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=152" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 152</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 10, 15, § 37</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aesculeus: <entryFree id="n1371" type="main" key="aescu^le^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aescŭlĕus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">esc-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1371.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of the Italian oak</hi>, and <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, in gen., <hi rend="ital">of oak</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aesculeae capiebat frondis honorem,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>an oaken garland</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:449" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 449</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aesculinus: <entryFree id="n1372" type="hapax" key="aescu^li_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aescŭlīnus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">esc-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, = aesculeus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 1</bibl>.</entryFree>
aesculus: <entryFree id="n1373" type="main" key="aescu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aescŭlus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">esc-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>may be connected with edo = to eat, as fagus = beech, <foreign lang="greek">fhgo/s</foreign> = oak, with <foreign lang="greek">fagei=n</foreign>, but the diphthong presents a difficulty; v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:page=187" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> p. 187</bibl></etym>, <sense id="n1373.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the tallest species of oak</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the winter</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Italian oak</hi> (<hi rend="ital">with edible acorns</hi>), <hi rend="ital">sacred to Jupiter</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 16</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">291</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">ef. Voss. ad h. l.: nec mollior aesculo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:10:17 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 10, 17 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
aesernia: <entryFree id="n1374" type="main" key="Aeserni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesernĭa</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Es-</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1374.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Samnium</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the river Vulturnus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Isernia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 11</bibl>, D, § 2; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:14" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Epit. 72:73 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> Epit. 72, 73 al.</bibl>—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesernīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj. pertaining to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a native of</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Æsernia</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ager,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">turma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 44, 40</bibl></cit>.—Also <hi rend="ital">a surname of M. Marcellus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who was taken prisoner there by the Samnites</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Epit. 73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> Epit. 73</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 1, 5, § 12</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesernīni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Æsernia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 10</bibl>. —Aeserninus was also <hi rend="ital">the name of a renowned gladiator;</hi> hence the proverb: Aeserninus cum Pacidiano, <hi rend="ital">one champion against another</hi>, when two equally great men are compared together or engaged in mutual conflict, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 393, 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,041:Orat. 6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Opt. Gen. Orat. 6</bibl> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Bitho Bacchius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:7:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 7, 20</bibl></cit>).</sense></entryFree>
aesis: <entryFree id="n1375" type="main" key="Aesis1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1375.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Umbria</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:241" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 42, 97, § 241</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1376" type="main" key="Aesis2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1376.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Umbria on the river Æsis</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">COL. AESIS,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3899</bibl></cit>.—Whence, </sense><sense id="n1376.1" n="I" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesinas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Æsis</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">caseus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:241" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 42, 97, § 241</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1376.2" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesinātes</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Æsis</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:113" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 14, 19, § 113</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeson: <entryFree id="n1377" type="main" key="Aeso_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesōn</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/swn</foreign>, <sense id="n1377.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Thessalian prince</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brother of king Pelias</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and father of Jason</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who</hi>, <hi rend="ital">according to fable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">was in extreme old age transformed by the magic arts of Medea into a youth</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 2</bibl>.— Whence, </sense><sense id="n1377.1" n="I" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesŏnĭdes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <hi rend="ital">patr. m.</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)soni/dhs</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a male descendant of Æson</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Jason</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:164" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 164</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Phasias Aesoniden, Circe tenuisset Ulixem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. A. 2, 103</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mobilis Aesonide,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:6:109 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 6, 109 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1377.2" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesŏnĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Æsonian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">heros,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Jason</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:156" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 156</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">domus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:12:134" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 12, 134</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aesopicus: <entryFree id="n1378" type="main" key="Aeso_pi^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesōpĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Aesopus</etym>, <sense id="n1378.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Æsopic.</hi> Acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 1, 39</bibl>, fables are either Æsopic or Libystic (from <hi rend="ital">Libys</hi>, a writer of fables, mentioned by Hesych.); Æsopic, when brute beasts or things inanimate are represented as discoursing together; Libystic. when the discourse is between men and brutes.</sense></entryFree>
aesopius: <entryFree id="n1379" type="main" key="Aeso_pi_us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesōpīus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesōpēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1379.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Æsopic</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Æsopian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fabulae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 4</bibl></cit> prol.: <cit><quote lang="la">trimetria,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 16, 74</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aesopus: <entryFree id="n1380" type="main" key="Aeso_pus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesōpus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/swpos</foreign>. <sense id="n1380.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Æsop</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the Greek fabulist of Phrygia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in the time of Crœsus;</hi> cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 5</bibl> prol. The difference <cb n="AEST" /> between Æsopic and Libystic fables, v. under Aesopicus.—Cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:11:19" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 11, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:29" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 29</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1380.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A tragic actor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">friend of Cicero</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">noster Aesopus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 82</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:25" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:37" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 37</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aesquiliae: <entryFree id="n1381" type="main" key="Aesquiliae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesquiliae</orth>, v. Esquiliae.</entryFree>
aestas: <entryFree id="n1382" type="main" key="aestas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>akin to <foreign lang="greek">ai)/qw</foreign> = to burn, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=9" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 9</bibl>; cf.: aestus, aether, aethra; Sanscr. indh = to kindle, iddhas = kindled; O. H. Germ. eiten = to heat; Germ. Hitze = heat</etym>, in an extended sense, <sense id="n1382.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the summer season</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as one half of the year</hi>, <hi rend="ital">from March twenty-second to September twenty-second</hi> (the other half was <hi rend="ital">hiems</hi>, the winter season); cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:43:19" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 43, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestas et hiems, nox et dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:8:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 8, 22</bibl></cit>: in a restricted sense, <hi rend="ital">the summer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the three months from the entrance of the sun into Cancer to the autumnal equinox</hi> (the entrance into Libra): <cit><quote lang="la">Arabes campos et montes hieme et aestate peragrantes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:42" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(formica) parat in aestate cibum sibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:6:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Prov. 6, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestate ineunte,</quote> <trans><tr>at the beginning of summer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nova,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:430" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 430</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">media,</quote> <trans><tr>midsummer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:12:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 12, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam adulta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 23</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Caes. 32:3" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Caes. 32, 3</bibl> Arntz.: <cit><quote lang="la">summa,</quote> <trans><tr>the height of summer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exacta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">finita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,049:8:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jer. 8, 20</bibl></cit>: cum affecta jam prope aestate uvas a sole mitescere tempus est, Cic. Oecon. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 161, 2</bibl>.— <cit><quote lang="la">With anni,</quote> <trans><tr>summer-time</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:21" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestate anni flagrantissima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 19, 5</bibl></cit>.—Since war among the ancients was carried on only in summer, aestas is sometimes (like <foreign lang="greek">qe/ros</foreign> in Gr.) used by the histt. for, </sense><sense id="n1382.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A year</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:47" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:82" default="NO">82</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae duabus aestatibus gesta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 39</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so. te jam septuma portat omnibus errantem terris aestas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:756" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 756</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1382.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Summer air</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">per aestatem liquidam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 59</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:707" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 6, 707</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1382.3" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Summer heat</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:17:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 17, 3</bibl></cit>.— *</sense><sense id="n1382.4" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Freckles</hi> as caused by heat: <cit><quote lang="la">aestates,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:185" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 12, 50, § 185</bibl></cit>, where Jan. reads <hi rend="ital">testas.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aestifer: <entryFree id="n1383" type="main" key="aesti^fer"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestĭfer</orth>, <itype>fēra, fĕrum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aestus-fero</etym> <sense id="n1383.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bringing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">causing</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">producing heat</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:663" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 663</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:612" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 612</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">canis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:353" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 353</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,060:chapter=111" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Arat. 111</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:1:194" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 1, 194</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:585 al" default="NO">14, 585 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n1383.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">heated</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sultry</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hot</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Libyum arva,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:206" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 206</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">campi Garamantum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:17:448" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 17, 448</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
