aestii: <entryFree id="n1384" type="main" key="Aesti^i"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aestĭi</orth> (the correct read., not <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aestŭi</orth>), <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1384.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Germanic people on the southeast</hi> or <hi rend="ital">east of the Baltic</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the Esthen</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 45</bibl> Halm.</sense></entryFree>
aestimabilis: <entryFree id="n1385" type="hapax" key="aesti^ma_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestĭmābĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aestimo</etym>, <sense id="n1385.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">worthy of estimation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">valuable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">estimable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestimabile esse dicitur id, quod ... aliquod pondus habeat dignum aestimatione, contaque inaestimabile, quod sit superiori contrarium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:6:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 3, 6, 20</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aestimatio: <entryFree id="n1386" type="main" key="aesti^ma_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestĭmātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>. <sense id="n1386.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The estimating a thing according to its extrinsic</hi> (money) <hi rend="ital">value</hi>, <hi rend="ital">valuation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">appraisement</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in censu habendo potestas omnis aestimationis habendae censori permittitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 53</bibl></cit>: aestimatio frumenti, <hi rend="ital">the determination of the prœtor</hi> (<hi rend="ital">legate</hi> or <hi rend="ital">quœstor</hi>), <hi rend="ital">how much ready money one should pay</hi>, <hi rend="ital">instead of the corn which he was to furnish</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 92</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">erat Athenis reo damnato, si fraus non capitalis esset, quasi poenae aestimatio,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>a commutation of corporal punishment for a fine</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:54:232" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 54, 232</bibl></cit>.—So esp. litis or litium aestimatio, in Roman civil law, <hi rend="ital">an estimating</hi>, <hi rend="ital">valuation of the contested matter;</hi> in criminal law also, <hi rend="ital">the stating how much the convicted person had to pay</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an assessment of damages</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:41:116" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 41, 116</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:18:section=45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 18, § 45</bibl> (cf. lis aestimata, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 13</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">lex de multarum aestimatione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 30</bibl></cit>.— After the civil war, Cæsar, in order to enable debtors to cancel the demands against them, decreed an aestimatio possessionum, i. e. <hi rend="ital">an estimation</hi> or <hi rend="ital">appraisement of real estate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">according to the value which it had before the war</hi>, and compelled the creditors to take this in payment instead of money; they were also obliged to deduct from the sum demanded any interest that had been paid; v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 1</bibl>; and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:42" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 42</bibl>. Hence, in aestimationem accipere, <hi rend="ital">to accept</hi> or <hi rend="ital">agree to such a valuation</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">payment by real estate at a high price</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">a Marco Laberio C. Albinius praedia in aestimationem accepit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 8</bibl></cit>.—And meton., with an allusion to the law of Cæsar: aestimationes <pb n="62" /> <cb n="AEST" /> = praedia, <hi rend="ital">the real estate received in payment</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quando aestimationes tuas vendere non potes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 18</bibl></cit>. Since the creditor was a loser by this regulation, aestimationem accipere, <hi rend="ital">to suffer injury or loss</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 16</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1386.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1386.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A valuation</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">an estimation of a thing according to its intrinsic worth</hi> (while <hi rend="ital">existimatio</hi> denotes the consideration, regard due to an object on account of its nominal value): <cit><quote lang="la">bonum hoc est quidem plurimi aestimandum, sed ea aestimatio genere valet, non magnitudine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:10:34" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 3, 10, 34</bibl></cit>; so 3, 13, 44; <cit><quote lang="la">3, 6: semper aestimationem arbitriumque ejus honoris penes senatum fuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">semper infra aliorum aestimationes se metiens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:127" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 127</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:97" default="NO">97</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 67</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestimatione rectā severus, deterius interpretantibus tristior habebatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:14 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 14 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1386.3" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the worth</hi> or <hi rend="ital">value of a thing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quod me non movet aestimatione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:12:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 12, 12</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aestimator: <entryFree id="n1387" type="main" key="aesti^ma_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestĭmātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>aestimo</etym>. <sense id="n1387.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">One that estimates a thing according to its extrinsic value</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a valuer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">appraiser</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">frumenti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 35 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">callidi rerum aestimatores prata et areas quasdam magno aestimant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:6:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Par. 6, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1387.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">an estimator</hi> or <hi rend="ital">valuer of a thing according to its intrinsic worth</hi> (while <hi rend="ital">existimator</hi> is a judge): <cit><quote lang="la">nemo erit tam injustus rerum aestimator, qui dubitet, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,032:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Marcell. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">justus rerum aestimator,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:chapter=41" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">immodicus aestimator sui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:1 al" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 1 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
aestimatorius: <entryFree id="n1388" type="main" key="aesti^ma_to_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestĭmātōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aestimator</etym>, <sense id="n1388.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">regarding a valuer</hi> or <hi rend="ital">taxer</hi>, only in the jurists: <cit><quote lang="la">actio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:19:3:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 19, 3, 1</bibl></cit>; and <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aestĭmātōrĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:21:1:43:section=6" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 21, 1, 43, § 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestimatorium judicium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:Fragm. 18 al" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Fragm. 18 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
aestimatus: <entryFree id="n1389" type="main" key="aesti^ma_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestĭmātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>aestimo</etym>, = aestimatio; found only in the <case>abl.</case>: <sense id="n1389.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">aetatis,</quote> <trans><tr>in valuing</tr>, <tr>considering</tr>, <tr>the time</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 16</bibl></cit>: in aestimatu est mel e thymo, <hi rend="ital">in value</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">much esteemed</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 15, 15, § 38</bibl> (cf. in pretio habere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 5</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
aestimia: <entryFree id="n1390" type="gloss" key="aesti^mi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestĭmĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, = aestimatio, acc. to Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=26" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 26</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
aestimium: <entryFree id="n1391" type="main" key="aesti^mi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestĭmĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, = aestimatio (late Lat.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:de Limit. p. 152" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> de Limit. p. 152</bibl> Goes.; so besides only <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:de Colon. p. 127" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> de Colon. p. 127</bibl> ib.</entryFree>
aestimo: <entryFree id="n1392" type="main" key="aesti^mo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestĭmo</orth> (arch. <orth extent="full" lang="la">aestŭ-</orth>), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>from aes, with the termination -tumo, which also appears in autumo; cf.: legitumus, finitumus, maritumus; later, legitimus, finitimus, maritimus; compare the Goth. aistjan, to estimate</etym>. <sense id="n1392.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To determine</hi> or <hi rend="ital">estimate the extrinsic</hi> (<hi rend="ital">money</hi>) <hi rend="ital">value of a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to value</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">appraise;</hi> constr. with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> or <case>abl.</case> (v. of price, Zumpt. §§ <cit><quote lang="la">444 and 456): domum emit prope dimidio carius quam aestimabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frumentum III denariis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid tenuissime,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prata magno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:6:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Par. 6, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perfecit (Aratus) aestimandis possessionibus, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:23:82" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 23, 82</bibl></cit>; hence, litem alicui or alicujus, <hi rend="ital">to estimate the value of an object in question</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and thus determine how much the convicted person shall pay</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to estimate</hi> or <hi rend="ital">assess the damages;</hi> cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0803,001:ad Cic. Verr. 1:13:38" default="NO"><author>Ascon.</author> ad Cic. Verr. 1, 13, 38</bibl>, and Beier ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Oratt. Fragm. Exc. IV. p. 265</bibl>; Cic. Verr. l. l.—</sense><sense id="n1392.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to estimate the intrinsic</hi> (<hi rend="ital">moral</hi>) <hi rend="ital">worth of a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to weigh</hi>, <hi rend="ital">value</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hold</hi>, etc. (while <hi rend="ital">existimare</hi>, as a consequence of <hi rend="ital">aestimare</hi>, signifies to judge a thing in any way after estimating its value: ex pretio rei judicare; cf. Burm. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 3, 4</bibl>; Herz. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 17</bibl>; Corte and Kritz ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 8:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 8, 2</bibl>; Gronov. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:2" default="NO" valid="yes">34, 2</bibl>; and aestimator).— Constr. </sense><sense id="n1392.2" n="(a)" level="5"> That which serves as a standard by which a thing is estimated with <hi rend="ital">ex</hi> or the <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">vulgus ex veritate pauca, ex opinione multa aestimant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:chapter=10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Com. 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem ex artificio comico,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum in Aquitaniam pervenisset, quae pars, ex tertiā parte Galliae est aestimanda, etc.,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>is to be reckoned as a third part</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amicitias inimicitiasque non ex re, sed ex commodo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 10:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 10, 5</bibl></cit>.—With simple <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">virtutem annis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 48</bibl></cit>: aliquid vitā, <hi rend="ital">to measure a thing by life</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to hold it as dear as life</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:5" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 5, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec Macedonas veteri famā, sed praesentibus viribus aestimandos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:30:4" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 30, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1392.3" n="(b)" level="5"> The value attached to a thing in estimating it, in the <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> or <hi rend="ital">abl. pretii</hi> (cf. I.); <usg type="style">poet.</usg> also with <case>acc.</case> nihil: <cit><quote lang="la">auctoritatem alicujus magni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 15</bibl></cit>: quod non minoris aestimamus quam quemlibet triumphum, <cb n="AEST" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Cat. 1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Cat. 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid unius assis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 5, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid permagno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:7:section=13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 7, § 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non magno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:3:11" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 3, 3, 11</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:4:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 3, 4, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non nihilo aestimandum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:23:62" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 4, 23, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magno te aestimaturum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magno aestimantibus se,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 40, 41</bibl></cit>. And with definite numerals which give the price-current for which a thing may be had; cf. Zumpt. § 456; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:Fragm. p. 974" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> Fragm. p. 974</bibl> Corte: <cit><quote lang="la">denis in diem assibus animam et corpus aestimari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">emori nolo, sed me esse mortuum nihil aestimo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:8:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 8, 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1392.4" n="(g)" level="5"> Among the histt. with a <hi rend="ital">rel. clause.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestimantibus, quanta futuri spe tam magna tacuisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 18 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quantopere dilectus sit, facile est aestimare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:57" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 57</bibl></cit> (but in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 31:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 31, 19</bibl>, the correct read. is <hi rend="ital">existumabitis</hi>, Dietsch).</sense></entryFree>
aestiva: <entryFree id="n1393" type="main" key="aesti_va"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestīva</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, v. aestivus, II.</entryFree>
aestivalis: <entryFree id="n1394" type="main" key="aesti_va_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestīvālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = aestivus, <sense id="n1394.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to summer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">summer-like</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">circulus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the tropic of Cancer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Astr. 3:24" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Astr. 3, 24</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aestive: <entryFree id="n1395" type="main" key="aesti_ve_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestīvē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. aestivus <sense id="n1395.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aestivo: <entryFree id="n1396" type="main" key="aesti_vo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestīvo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>aestivus</etym>, <sense id="n1396.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to spend</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pass the summer in a place</hi> (like hiemo, to pass the winter; so in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">qeri/zw</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">xeima/zw</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi greges in Apuliā hibernabant, qui in Reatinibus montibus aestivabant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:ib. 2:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">intra saepem aestivant pastores opacam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 5, 11, § 22</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:4" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Vesp. 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:4:4:22" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 4, 4, 22</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aestivus: <entryFree id="n1397" type="main" key="aesti_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aestas</etym>, <sense id="n1397.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to summer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">summer-like</hi>, <hi rend="ital">summer</hi> (freq. and class.): <cit><quote lang="la">Quo pacto aestivis e partibus Aegocerotis Brumalīs adeat flexus,</quote> <trans><tr>turns from the hot region of heaven to the wintry sign of Capricorn</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:615" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 615</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:639" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 639</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestivos menses rei militari dare, hibernos juris dictioni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempora, dies,</quote> <trans><tr>summer time</tr>, <tr>summer days</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sol,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:22:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 22, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">umbra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:793" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 793</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:8:61" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 8, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per aestivos saltus deviasque calles exercitum ducimus,</quote> <trans><tr>through woods</tr>, <tr>where flocks were driven for summer pasture</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aves,</quote> <trans><tr>summer birds</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animalia,</quote> <trans><tr>the insects of summer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 47, 71, § 154</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">expeditiones,</quote> <trans><tr>which were undertaken in summer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:114" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 114</bibl></cit>: castra, <hi rend="ital">a summer camp</hi> (constructed differently from a winter camp), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:1" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 1</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1397.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aestīva</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> </sense><sense id="n1397.2" n="A" level="2"> For <hi rend="ital">a summer camp</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">ta\ qerina/</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum in aestivis essemus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 2, 13</bibl>: aestiva praetoris, of <hi rend="ital">a pleasure-camp</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pleasurehouse</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 37</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1397.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The time appropriate for a campaign</hi> (cf. aestas; often continuing until December; v. Manut. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 7</bibl>); <cit><quote lang="la">hence,</quote> <trans><tr>a campaign</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 40</bibl></cit>: aestivis confectis, <hi rend="ital">after the campaign was ended</hi> (which did not take place until the Saturnalia, XIV. Kal. Januar.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 9 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">perducere aestiva in mensem Decembrem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:105" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 105</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1397.4" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Summer pastures for cattle</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">per montium aestiva,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 6, 19, § 28</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Meton.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">the cattle themselves</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nec singula morbi Corpora corripiunt, sed tota aestiva,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:472" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 472</bibl></cit>.— Hence, * <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aestīvē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">in a summer-like manner</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as in summer</hi>: admodum aestive viaticati sumus, <hi rend="ital">we are furnished in a very summer-like manner with money for our journey</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">we have but little</hi> (the figure taken from the light dress of summer; <cit><quote lang="la">or, acc. to others, from the scanty provisions which soldiers took with them in summer),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:1:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 2, 1, 30</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aestuabundus: <entryFree id="n1398" type="hapax" key="aestu^a_bundus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestŭābundus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aestuo</etym>, <sense id="n1398.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">foaming</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fermenting</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">confectio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 11, 17</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aestuans: <entryFree id="n1399" type="main" key="aestu^ans"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestŭans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of aestuo.</entryFree>
aestuarium: <entryFree id="n1400" type="main" key="aestu^a_ri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestŭārĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>aestus</etym>. <sense id="n1400.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A part of the sea-coast which</hi>, <hi rend="ital">during the flood-tide</hi>, <hi rend="ital">is overflowed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but at the ebb-tide is left covered with mud</hi> or <hi rend="ital">slime</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a marsh</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">a)na/xusis</foreign>: aestuaria sunt omnia, quā mare vicissim tum accedit, tum recedit, Gloss. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=380" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 380</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">pedestria esse itinera concisa aestuariis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adfunditur autem aestuarium e mari flexuoso meatu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 1, 1, § 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:9:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 9, 23</bibl>.— Also, </sense><sense id="n1400.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A channel extending inland from the sea</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and only filled with water at floodtide</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a creek</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inlet</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:17" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aestuaria ac paludes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 28</bibl></cit> Herz.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 8</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 22</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1400.2" n="III" level="1"> In mining t. t., <hi rend="ital">an air-hole</hi>, <hi rend="ital">air-shaft</hi>: secundum puteum<cb n="AEST" />  dextra ac sinistra fodiunt aestuaria, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 3, 28, § 49</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:8:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 8, 7</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 9, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aestuatio: <entryFree id="n1401" type="main" key="aestu^a_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestŭātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aestuo</etym>, <sense id="n1401.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a boiling up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">foaming;</hi> trop., <hi rend="ital">trouble</hi> or <hi rend="ital">agitation of mind</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 1, 1, § 5</bibl>, where Jan reads <hi rend="ital">aestimatione.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aestuo: <entryFree id="n1402" type="main" key="aestu^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestŭo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>aestus</etym>, <sense id="n1402.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be in agilation</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in violent commotion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to move to and fro</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to rage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to toss</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to boil up.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1402.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1402.2" n="A" level="2"> Of fire, <hi rend="ital">to rage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">burn</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestuat ut clausis rapidus fornacibus ignis,</quote> <trans><tr>as the fire heaves and roars in the closed furnaces</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:263" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 263</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tectus magis aestuat ignis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 64</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1402.3" n="2" level="3"> Of the effect of fire, <hi rend="ital">to be warm</hi> or <hi rend="ital">hot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to burn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">glow;</hi> both objectively, <hi rend="ital">I am warm</hi> (Fr. <hi rend="ital">je suis chaud</hi>), and subjectively, <hi rend="ital">it is warm to me</hi>, <hi rend="ital">I feel warm</hi> (Fr. <hi rend="ital">j'ai chaud</hi>). </sense><sense id="n1402.4" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Object.</hi>: nunc dum occasio est, dum scribilitae aestuant (<hi rend="ital">while the cakes are warm</hi>) occurrite, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:prol. 43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. prol. 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 107</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">torridus aestuat aër,</quote> <trans><tr>glows</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:24:3" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 24, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 16</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n1402.5" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Subject.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to feel warmth</hi> or <hi rend="ital">heat</hi> (weaker than <hi rend="ital">sudare</hi>, to sweat, and opp. <hi rend="ital">algere</hi>, to be cold, to feel cold; <cit><quote lang="la">v. Doed. Syn. 3, 89): Lycurgi leges erudiunt juventutem esuriendo, sitiendo, algendo, aestuando,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:14:34" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 14, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille cum aestuaret, umbram secutus est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sub pondere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:514" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 514</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:103" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 103</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1402.6" n="B" level="2"> Of the undulating, heaving motion of the sea, <hi rend="ital">to rise in waves</hi> or <hi rend="ital">billows</hi> (cf. aestus): <cit><quote lang="la">Maura unda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:6:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 6, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gurges,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:296" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 296</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1402.7" n="C" level="2"> Of other things, <hi rend="ital">to have an undulating</hi>, <hi rend="ital">waving motion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be tossed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to heave</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in ossibus umor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:308" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 308</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ventis pulsa aestuat arbor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1097" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1097</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:11:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 17, 11, 5</bibl>. —Of an agitated crowd, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> 11, 228</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1402.8" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1402.9" n="A" level="2"> Of the passions, love, desire, envy, jealousy, etc., <hi rend="ital">to burn with desire</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be in violent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">passionate excitement</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be agitated</hi> or <hi rend="ital">excited</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be inflamed</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod ubi auditum est, aestuare (hist. inf.) illi, qui dederant pecuniam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae cum dies noctesque aestuans agitaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 93</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">desiderio alicujus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">invidiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingens in corde pudor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:666" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 666</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">at rex Odrysius in illa Aestuat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:490" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 490</bibl></cit> (cf. uri in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:7:22" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 22</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and ardere in id,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 9, 724</bibl></cit>); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:9:23" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 9, 23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestuat (Alexander) infelix angusto limite mundi (the figure is derived from the swelling and raging of the sea when confined),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:169" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 169</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:6:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 6, 63</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1402.10" n="B" level="2"> Esp. in prose, <hi rend="ital">to waver</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to vacillate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to hesitate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be uncertain</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in doubt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be undecided</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dubitatione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 30</bibl></cit>: quod petiit, spernit; repetit quod nuper omisit; <cit><quote lang="la">Aestuat et vitae disconvenit ordine toto,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 99</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sic anceps inter utramque animus aestuat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:7:33" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 7, 33</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:4" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestuante rege,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:10" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 1, 10</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aestuosus: <entryFree id="n1403" type="main" key="aestu^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestŭōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aestus</etym>, <sense id="n1403.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">full of agitation</hi> or <hi rend="ital">heat.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1403.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Very hot</hi>: aura, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 710</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">aestuosa et pulverulenta via,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:16:62" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 16, 62</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">auster,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 47, 48, § 119</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestuosissimi dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:116" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 12, 28, § 116</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Syrtes,</quote> <trans><tr>the burning Syrtes</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:22:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 22, 5</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence, Oraclum Jovis inter aestuosi,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>of Jupiter Ammon in the Libyan desert</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 7, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1403.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Great ly agitated</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in violent ebullition</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">freta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:7:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 7, 16</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aestŭōsē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">hotly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">impetuously</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:3:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 3, 3, 67</bibl>.— <hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:3:18" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 3, 18</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> prob. not used.</sense></entryFree>
aestus: <entryFree id="n1404" type="main" key="aestus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aestus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype> (archaic <sense id="n1404.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> aesti, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0116,001:97" default="NO"><author>Pac.</author> 97</bibl> Rib.; rare form of <hi rend="ital">nom. plur.</hi> aestuus). <gen>m.</gen> <etym>kind. with aestas and Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ai)/qw</foreign>; v. aestas</etym>, <hi rend="ital">an undulating</hi>, <hi rend="ital">boiling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">waving</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tossing; a waving</hi>, <hi rend="ital">heaving</hi>, <hi rend="ital">billowy motion.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1404.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1404.2" n="A" level="2"> Of fire; hence, in gen., <hi rend="ital">fire</hi>, <hi rend="ital">glow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">heat</hi> (orig. in relation to its flashing up; while <hi rend="ital">fervor</hi> denotes a glowing, <hi rend="ital">ardor</hi> a burning, and <hi rend="ital">calor</hi> a warming heat; yet it was early used for warming heat; <cit><quote lang="la">v. the following example): nam fretus ipse anni permiscet frigus et aestum,</quote> <trans><tr>heat and cold are blended</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:364" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 364</bibl></cit> (for which calor, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:368:371 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 368, 371 al.</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">multa aestu victa per agros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 1104</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exsuperant flammae, furit aestus ad auras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:759" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 759</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caniculae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:17:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 17, 18</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 8, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">labore et aestu languidus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 51</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque frigora neque aestus facile tolerabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:81" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 81</bibl></cit>.—So of <hi rend="ital">midday heat</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestibus at mediis umbrosam exquirere vallem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:331" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 331</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 22</bibl>: ille cum aestuaret, umbram secutus est).—And of the heat of disease (of <pb n="63" /> <cb n="AETA" /> wounds, fever, inflammation, etc.): ulceris aestus, Att. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:7:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 7, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">homines aegri cum aestu febrique jactantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 13</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1404.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The undulating</hi>, <hi rend="ital">heaving motion of the sea</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the swell</hi>, <hi rend="ital">surge</hi>: fervet aestu pelagus, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 39</bibl>; hence, meton. for <hi rend="ital">the sea in agitation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">waves</hi>, <hi rend="ital">billows</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">delphines aestum secabant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:674" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 674</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">furit aestus harenis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 107</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestus totos campos inundaverant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:9:9:18" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 9, 9, 18</bibl></cit>.—In Verg. once of <hi rend="ital">the boiling up of water in a vessel</hi>: exsultant aestu latices, Aen. 7, 464.—</sense><sense id="n1404.4" n="C" level="2"> Esp., <hi rend="ital">the periodical flux and reflux</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ebb and flow of the sea</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the tide</hi> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 9:19" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 9, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:3:1" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 3, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestus maris accedere et reciprocare maxime mirum, pluribus quidem modis, sed causa in sole lunāque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:97:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 97, 99</bibl></cit>); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 3, 6</bibl>: quid de fretis aut de marinis aestibus dicam? quorum accessus et recessus (<hi rend="ital">flow and ebb</hi>) lunae motu gubernantur, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 14 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">crescens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:219" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 100, 97, § 219</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">decedens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ib" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">recedens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:220" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 98, 101, § 220</bibl></cit>: secundus, <hi rend="ital">in our favor</hi>, Sall. Fragm. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:26:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 10, 26, 2</bibl>: adversus, <hi rend="ital">against us</hi>, id. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 138, 8</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n1404.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1404.6" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The passionate ferment</hi> or <hi rend="ital">commotion of the mind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the fire</hi>, <hi rend="ital">glow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ardor of any</hi> (<hi rend="ital">even a good</hi>) <hi rend="ital">passion</hi> (cf. aestuo, II. A.): <cit><quote lang="la">et belli magnos commovit funditus aestus (genus humanum),</quote> <trans><tr>has stirred up from their very bottom the waves of discord</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1434" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1434</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">civilis belli aestus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 47</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:7:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 2, 7, 15</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">repente te quasi quidam aestus ingenii tui procul a terrā abripuit atque in altum abstraxit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hunc absorbuit aestus quidam gloriae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=81" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">stultorum regum et populorum continet aestus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perstet et, ut pelagi, sic pectoris adjuvet aestum,</quote> <trans><tr>the glow of love</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:16:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 16, 25</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1404.7" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A vacillating</hi>, <hi rend="ital">irresolute state of mind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">doubt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uncertainty</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hesitation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">trouble</hi>, <hi rend="ital">embarrassment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anxiely</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui tibi aestus, qui error, quae tenebrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:in Caecin. 14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. in Caecin. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vario fluctuat aestu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:486" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 486</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amor magno irarum fluctuat aestu,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 532</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestus curaeque graves,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 2, 110</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1404.8" n="C" level="2"> In the Epicurean philos. lang. of Lucretius, <hi rend="ital">the undulatory flow</hi> or <hi rend="ital">stream of atoms</hi>, <hi rend="ital">atomic efflux</hi>, as the cause of perception (cf. affluo, I.): <cit><quote lang="la">Perpetuoque fluunt certis ab rebus odores, Frigus ut a fluviis, calor ab sole, aestus ab undis Aequoris, exesor moerorum litora propter, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:926" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 926</bibl></cit>; and in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1002 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 1002 sq.</bibl>, <hi rend="ital">the magnetic fluid</hi> is several times designated by aestus lapidis.</sense></entryFree>
aesula: <entryFree id="n1405" type="main" key="Aesu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesŭla</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Aesŏl-</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1405.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in the neighborhood of Tibur</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:29:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 29, 6</bibl> (Aefula, Müll.); cf. Müll. Roms Campagn. 1, 272.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesŭlānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Æsula</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">arx,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 9</bibl></cit> Madv.; and <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aesŏlāni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Æsula</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 69</bibl> Jan.</sense></entryFree>
aetas: <entryFree id="n1406" type="main" key="aetas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aetas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>contr. from the anteclass. aevitas from aevum, q. v.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 595</bibl> P.; cf. Welsh oet</etym> (<sense id="n1406.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> aetatum; <cit><quote lang="la">but freq. also aetatium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 43</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:17" default="NO" valid="yes">9, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:9" default="NO" valid="yes">26, 9</bibl>; cf. Oud. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:31" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:89" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 89</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Brev. Vit. 12:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Brev. Vit. 12, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:14:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 14, 1</bibl>). </sense><sense id="n1406.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The period of life</hi>, <hi rend="ital">time of life</hi>, <hi rend="ital">life</hi>, <hi rend="ital">age</hi> (divided, acc. to Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Censor.</author> 14</bibl>, into <hi rend="ital">pueritia</hi>, from birth to the 15th year; <hi rend="ital">adulescentia</hi>, from that time to the 30th; <hi rend="ital">juventus</hi>, to the 45th; the age of the <hi rend="ital">seniores</hi>, to the 60th; and, finally, <hi rend="ital">senectus</hi>, from that time till death. Others make a different division, v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1</bibl> prooem.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 11, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:28" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 10, 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:20" default="NO">15, 20</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">a primo tempore aetatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:4:13" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 4, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prima aetas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:13" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ineuntis aetatis inscientia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 34</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so 2, 13: flos aetatis,</quote> <trans><tr>the bloom of life</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:49" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 49</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">bona aetas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 14</bibl></cit>; and <usg type="style">poet.</usg> in the <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambo florentes aetatibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 7, 4</bibl></cit>: quamquam aetas senet, satis habeo tamen virium, ut te arā arceam, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 1, 10</bibl>; id. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 159, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mala aetas,</quote> <trans><tr>old age</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 5, 2, 6</bibl></cit>; and <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: aetas, aevitas = senectus, <hi rend="ital">old age</hi>, SI MORBVS AEVITASVE VITIVM ESCIT, Fragm. of the XII. Tab. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:1:25" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 1, 25</bibl>: aetate (<hi rend="ital">through age</hi>) non quis obtuerier, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:2:154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 3, 2, 154</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 3, 130</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 3, 3, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed ipse morbo atque aetate confectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">graves aetate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 39</bibl></cit>.—Sometimes also <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> = adulescentia, <hi rend="ital">youth</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fui ego illā aetate et feci illa omnia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:10:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 10, 4</bibl></cit>; id. <cb n="AETE" /> Most. 5, 2, 27: <cit><quote lang="la">damna, dedecora aetas ipsius pertulit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tua autem aetas (of his son),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:13" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(mulier) non formā, non aetate, non opibus maritum invenerit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">expers belli propter aetatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 8</bibl></cit>: aetas consularis, <hi rend="ital">the legal age for the consulship</hi>, i. e. the 43d year, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 5, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">id aetatis jam sumus,</quote> <trans><tr>we have now reached that time of life</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:20:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 6, 20, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1406.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1406.3" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">the lifetime of man</hi>, <hi rend="ital">without reference to its different stages; life</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:2:16" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 18, 2, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aetas acta honeste et splendide,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:25" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gerere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:5 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 4, 5 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempus aetatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=19" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aetatem consumere in studio aliquo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">conterere in litibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">degere omnem in tranquillitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:35" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 35</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:53 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 53 al.</bibl>—In <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 188</bibl>, aetas = centum annos.—</sense><sense id="n1406.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A space of time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an age</hi>, <hi rend="ital">generation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">time</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">heroicae aetates,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:3:7" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec aetas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 3, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:27:101" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 27, 101</bibl></cit> Beier: <cit><quote lang="la">nostrā aetate,</quote> <trans><tr>in our times</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:4:20" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 4, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum primis aetatis suae comparabatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Iphicr. 1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Iphicr. 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:16" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">incuriosa suorum aetas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia fert aetas,</quote> <trans><tr>time</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:9:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 9, 51</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:9:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 9, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">crastina aetas,</quote> <trans><tr>the morrow</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:3:562" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 3, 562</bibl></cit>. —<hi rend="ital">Of the four ages of the world</hi> (<hi rend="ital">the golden age</hi>, <hi rend="ital">silver age</hi>, etc.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:89 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 89 sq.</bibl>; v. aureus, argenteus, etc.—</sense><sense id="n1406.5" n="C" level="2"> Abstr. pro concreto, <hi rend="ital">the time</hi> or <hi rend="ital">period of life</hi>, for <hi rend="ital">the man himself</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the age</hi>, for <hi rend="ital">the men living in it</hi> (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, and in prose after the Aug. per.; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">saeculum): sibi inimicus magis quam aetati tuae, i. e. tibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:4:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 4, 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vae aetati tuae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 105</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid nos dura refugimus Aetas?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:35:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 35, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:16:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epod. 16, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">veniens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:639" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 639</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnis aetas currere obviam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnis sexus, omnis aetas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">innoxiam liberorum aetatem miserarentur, i. e. innocentes liberos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 3, 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sexum, aetatem, ordinem omnem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:4" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1406.6" n="D" level="2"> Also of things without life, e. g. of wine, its <hi rend="ital">age</hi>: bibite Falernum hoc: annorum quadraginta est. Bene, inquit, aetatem fert, <hi rend="ital">it keeps well</hi>, Cic. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 2, 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 23, 1, 20, § 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:7" default="NO" valid="yes">15, 2, 3, § 7</bibl>.—So of buildings: <cit><quote lang="la">aetates aedificiorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:30:58" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 30, 58</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1406.7" n="E" level="2"> Aetatem, a dverb. (ante-class.). </sense><sense id="n1406.8" n="1" level="3"> = semper, perpetuo, <hi rend="ital">through the whole of life</hi>, <hi rend="ital">during lifetime</hi>, <hi rend="ital">continually</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut aetatem ambo nobis sint obnoxii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 2, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">at tu aegrota, si lubet, per me aetatem quidem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:4:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 4, 3, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quid, malum, me aetatem censes velle id adsimularier,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:3:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 3, 38</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1406.9" n="2" level="3"> = diu, longo tempore, <hi rend="ital">an age</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a long time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a long while</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">an abiit jam a milite? Jamdudum aetatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 5, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod solis vapor aetatem non posse videtur efficere,</quote> <trans><tr>what the heat of the sun cannot perhaps effect for years</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:236" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 236</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1406.10" n="F" level="1"> In aetate, adverb. (ante-class.). </sense><sense id="n1406.11" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">At times</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sometimes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now and then</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 1, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1406.12" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">At any time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">always</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ever</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 61</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aetatula: <entryFree id="n1407" type="main" key="aeta_tu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aetātŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>aetas</etym>, <sense id="n1407.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a youthful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tender</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">effeminate age</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in munditiis, mollitiis deliciisque aetatulam agere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 2, 40</bibl></cit>: integra, Caecil. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:23:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 23, 10</bibl> (Com. Rel. p. 52 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">in primis puerorum aetatulis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:20:55" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 20, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">monuit, ut parcius aetatulae indulgeret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:16" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 16</bibl></cit> (cf. Galb. 20: cupide fruaris aetate tuā).</sense></entryFree>
aeternabilis: <entryFree id="n1408" type="main" key="aeterna_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aeternābĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aeterno</etym>, <sense id="n1408.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that can last forever</hi>, <hi rend="ital">everlasting</hi>: divitia, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 475, 24</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 143 Rib.): urbs, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Rome</hi>, Cod. Th. 11, 20, 3 (cf. aeternus, II. A.).</sense></entryFree>
aeternalis: <entryFree id="n1409" type="main" key="aeterna_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aeternālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aeternus</etym>, <sense id="n1409.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">enduring forever</hi>, <hi rend="ital">everlasting</hi> (often in inscrr.): <cit><quote lang="la">aeternali somno sacrum,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to death</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 752, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">domus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4518</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">luctus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 4604</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">memoria,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 200</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lex temporalis et aeternalis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Jud. 6</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aeternālĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">forever</hi> (late Lat.), Ad. ad H. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> March, p. 245</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeternitas: <entryFree id="n1410" type="main" key="aeterni^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aeternĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1410.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">eternity.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1410.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1410.2" n="A" level="2"> Of the past and future: <cit><quote lang="la">fuit quaedam ab infinito tempore aeternitas, quam nulla temporum circumscriptio metiebatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:9" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 9</bibl></cit>: Tempus generale, quia nec initium nec finem habet, <hi rend="ital">aeternitas</hi> est, quam Graeci <foreign lang="greek">ai)w=na</foreign> appellant, Victorin. in L<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tempus est pars quaedam aeternitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:26:39" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 1, 26, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">immutabilis aeternitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tim. 5</bibl></cit>: deum nihil aliud <cb n="AETE" /> in omni aeternitate cogitantem, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:41" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 41</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec dicit excelsus et sublimis (Deus) habitans aeternitatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:57:15 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 57, 15 al.</bibl></cit> —</sense><sense id="n1410.3" n="B" level="2"> Of the past: ex or ab aeternitate, <hi rend="ital">from eternity</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc est verum ex aeternitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,054:chapter=14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fat. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod semper ex omni aeternitate rerum fuerit, id esse fatum (dicitis),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si negas esse fortunam et omnia, quae fiunt quaeque futura sunt, ex omni aeternitate definita dicis esse fataliter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex omni aeternitate fluens veritas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si nihil fieri potest, nisi quod ab omni aeternitate certum fuerit, quae potest esse fortuna,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">egressus ejus ab initio, a diebus aeternitatis (fuerunt),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,038:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Mich. 5, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1410.4" n="C" level="2"> Of the future: <cit><quote lang="la">aeternitas animorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:17:39" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 17, 39</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">immortalitas animorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 50</bibl></cit>): <cit><quote lang="la">de aeternitate (animorum) dicere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 33, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quorum (sc. Herculis, etc.) cum remanerent animi atque aeternitate fruerentur, rite di habiti sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:24:62" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 24, 62</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Confer nostram longissimam aetatem cum aeternitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:39:94" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 39, 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in diem aeternitatis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> 2</bibl></cit> Pet. 3, 18; and <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">in perpetuas aeternitates,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,056:12:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Dan. 12, 3</bibl></cit>: in domum aeternitatis suae, <hi rend="ital">to his everlasting home</hi> (of death), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,030:12:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Eccl. 12, 5</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1410.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, of the future, <hi rend="ital">duration</hi>, <hi rend="ital">durability</hi>, <hi rend="ital">immortality</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cedri materiae aeternitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 5, 11, § 53</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1410.6" n="III" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of the future. </sense><sense id="n1410.7" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi populus Romanus aeternitatem immortalitatemque donavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 3</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:14:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 14, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quidquid ex Agricola amavimus, manet mansurumque est in aeternitate temporum, famā rerum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cupido aeternitatis perpetuaeque famae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:55 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 55 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1410.8" n="B" level="2"> Spec., in the time of the emperors, <hi rend="ital">a title of the emperor</hi> (like divinitas, majestas, and the like), <hi rend="ital">Eternity</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rogatus per aeternitatem tuam, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:10:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 10, 87</bibl></cit> ad Trajan.: <cit><quote lang="la">adoratus aeternitatem nostram, Imp. Const. Cod. 11, 9, 2: Quae nostra sanxit aeternitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0594,001:35" default="NO"><author>Nov.</author> 35 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
aeterno: <entryFree id="n1411" type="main" key="aeterno_1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aeternō</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. aeternus <sense id="n1411.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi> 3.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1412" type="main" key="aeterno2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aeterno</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>aeternus</etym>, <sense id="n1412.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to perpetuate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to immortalize</hi> (rare, perh. extant only in the two foll. exs.): litteris ac laudibus aeternare, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 75, 20</bibl>: virtutes in aevum, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:14:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 14, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeternus: <entryFree id="n1413" type="main" key="aeternus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aeternus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>contr. from aeviternus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=11" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 11</bibl> Müll., from aevum, with the termination -ternus as in sempiternus, hesternus</etym>, <sense id="n1413.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">without beginning or end</hi>, <hi rend="ital">eternal</hi> (sempiternus denotes what is perpetual, what exists as long as time endures, and keeps even pace with it; aeternus, <hi rend="ital">the eternal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">that which is raised above all time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and can be measured only by œons</hi> (<foreign lang="greek">ai)w=nes</foreign>, indefinite periods); <cit><quote lang="la">for Tempus est pars quaedam aeternitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:27:39" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 1, 27, 39</bibl></cit>. Thus the sublime thought, without beginning and end, is more vividly suggested by <hi rend="ital">aeternus</hi> than by <hi rend="ital">sempiternus</hi>, since the former has more direct reference to the long duration of the eternal, which has neither beginning nor end. <hi rend="ital">Sempiternus</hi> is rather a mathematical, <hi rend="ital">aeternus</hi> a metaphysical, designation of eternity, Doed. Syn. I. p. 3). </sense><sense id="n1413.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1413.2" n="A" level="2"> Of the past and future, <hi rend="ital">eternal</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">deus beatus et aeternus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:27:88" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 27, 88</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil quod ortum sit, aeternum esse potest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">O Pater, o hominum rerumque aeterna Potestas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">di semper fuerunt, nati numquam sunt, siquidem aeterni sunt futuri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:32:90" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 32, 90</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">idem legis perpetuae et aeternae vim Jovem dicit esse,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 15, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nomen Domini Dei aeterni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:21:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 21, 33</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:16:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Rom. 16, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeternum tempus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:582" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 582</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">causae immutabiles eaeque aeternae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,054:12:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fat. 12, 48</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n1413.3" n="B" level="2"> Of the future, <hi rend="ital">everlasting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">endless</hi>, <hi rend="ital">immortal</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">natura animi ... neque nata certe est et aeterna est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">virorum bonorum mentes divinae mihi atque aeternae videntur esse,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rab. 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeternam timuerunt noctem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:468" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 468</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quod semper movetur, aeternum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quidquid est illud quod sentit ... caeleste et divinum ob eamque rem aeternum sit, necesse est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut habeam vitam aeternam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:19:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 19, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Joan. 3, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Rom. 2, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in sanguine testamenti aeterni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,019:13:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Heb. 13, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu Juppiter bonorum inimicos aeternis suppliciis vivos mortuosque mactabis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ibunt in supplicium aeternum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:25:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 25, 46</bibl></cit>: <pb n="64" /> <cb n="AETH" /> aeternas poenas in morte timendumst, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 111</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mitti in ignem aeternum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:18:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 18, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1413.4" n="C" level="2"> Of the past: <cit><quote lang="la">ex aeterno tempore quaeque Nunc etiam superare necessest corpora rebus,</quote> <trans><tr>from eternity</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:578" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 578</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">motum animorum nullo a principio, sed ex aeterno tempore intellegi convenire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:6" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1413.5" n="D" level="2"> Spec. of objects of nature, which the ancients regarded as stable and perpetual, <hi rend="ital">everlasting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">eternal</hi>: aeterna templa caeli, Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:11, p. 77" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, 11, p. 77</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">aeternam lampada mundi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:402" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 402</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">micant aeterni sidera mundi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:514" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 514</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeterna domus, i. e. caelum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 6, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">donec veniret desiderium collium aeternorum,</quote> <trans><tr>the everlasting hills</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:49:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 49, 26</bibl></cit>;
